author: {'steamid': '76561198094021929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 976, 'last_played': 1590549328}
review:
One rainy day in early spring I bought this game because it was on sale and I love a robot that wears a hat. I didn't know how glorious the next couple hours would be!

Deeply atmospheric, and a desperate stealth challenge (at least the first time you play it). I recommend against reading any strategy guides, just sit back and enjoy the natural arc of the game.

You'll hide amid the post-apocalyptic ruins of the English countryside, hunted by a variety of mechanical nightmares wielding blunderbusses and quipping in robotic posh accents.

You can definitely replay this game a couple times and still have a good time - but once you have figured out how all the different hunters behave, it becomes pretty easy. 

The multiplayer mode was fun playing with friends. I joined a random server one time and the settings the host was running were so extreme, and the PvP was so toxic, that I have no desire to try again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047675493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 318, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1710775174}
review:
First off, why write a review for a ten year old game? Well, it's still being sold, it's being included in sales, and perhaps people want to still buy it. Also it's worth writing when the game is good.

I've been thinking about [i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i] on-and-off for a decade. My history with the game started in the year of its release, 2013. The then newish Macbook Pro I had wasn't up to the task of running the game properly, so I had to give up and let the game wait until I was in possession of some actual game playing hardware. Even though short, the time I spent with [i]Sir[/i] back then proved me that the game in its sneakiness wanted to convey something similar to my then and present favourite [i]Thief[/i]. But [i]Thief[/i] it is not.

Looking at the game now with a decade worth of playing, thinking about, and making games I can more clearly see that [i]Sir[/i] aims to be first and foremost about survival. Sneaking just happens to be something you need to do in order to succeed in surviving. It's also a game about its environment. The sense of place the game gives the player is strong, with definite love and interest to such real world places from the developers shining through.

As good as it generally is, some aspects of the game feel a bit off. Why for example give the player the opportunity to loot useless junk and even eat some of it, if the consequences are always just going to be bad? I get it in an aesthetics sense, in reality the world would be filled with junk and spoiled food and it's fun for the player to fail in finding something useful, but this leaves me thinking that more could've been done with these items.

Saving being possible only in certain places is good as it emphasizes the aspects of survival. The player has to take risks and when they pay off its well worth it. But it can get frustrating trying to sneak through an island for the fifth time after being helplessly murdered by the crack shot enemies. After gaining weapons and ammo battling the robots became more of a viable tactic of survival and I started to hope for silent ways of taking the enemies down. Something like this might take the game into a wrong direction tho.

Enemy spawns are randomized each time the player loads a save, disincentivizing planning. Killing the enemies feels a bit redundant too, as they will spawn back in, latest when you have to load. As the game progresses the enemies will start to patrol in higher numbers, making the sneaky retrieval of the game's MacGuffin pieces harder. About half-way in I had enough and lost all desire to finish the game. Perhaps I'll return to the archipelago one day or perhaps I'm finally done thinking about this game.

-

During the years after [i]Sir's[/i] release its mechanics of sneaking and survival horror have been both taken further and executed better by other developers. Sometimes in the same game, like Gloomwood! Compared to either older classics or newer indie games [i]Sir[/i] feels a bit rough. Nonetheless it has a charming style of its own, the world is well thought out and the vibes of the English countryside are so pleasant that sometimes I forgot that I actually was being hunted.

If you're a fan of sneaking around, the tender pressure of constantly finding food to eat, and blasting robots into pieces you will enjoy your time with [i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i]. Just don't be afraid to call it quits when you've had your fill.

review: Great little survival stealth game! This is a marathon not a race! Confidence is key but don't let your ego get in the way of progress because you will be humbled. There are save options but only in certain areas. Also has a multiplayer option however I have been unable to test that as I am the only person I know who owns this game. Variety of enemies each with their own tactical characteristics. A simple but very functional game with a bit of sass. Class options also available at start of a new world.

review: Ive played this game for years off and on, at first on a friends pc then on my own here and there. If you love the simple thrill of the chase or usually play hunting games/tactical shooters, try being the prey animal for once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198339401910', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 274, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1699901752}
review:
"Sir, you are being hunted" is a game where a sir or madam(you have an option to change how the game adresses you right in the main menu) got stuck in a world/dimension full of robotic "Ye old hunting British" gentlemen that, as you could guess by now, are hunting you. You are given the mission to survive and find parts of a machine that will send you back home, which sadly are scattered across the entire arcipelago(5 Islands in total, which have different biomes by your choise).
Stealthing in this game really gives you a suspence feel, the damn beeping noises and sadistic laughs and comments that the robot chaps make gives a nice tension while you are trying to stealth the hell out of there. I can happily say that the AI is well done, I won't spoil much here, the the variety of enemies is well done and original.
You can loot various houses for food(you need to eat also in order to survive), traps, tools and if you are really lucky, you might find a gun, changing the ties of who is the hunter and who is being hunted. You can hunt small game and cook them to replendish your hunger, but houses seem a better source of food.

Overall is a nice game, give it a try will ya?

author: {'steamid': '76561198304880726', 'num_games_owned': 6575, 'num_reviews': 1717, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1699314469}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988812463', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1701965359}
review:
I don't know, maaan.

The game's perfectly alright gameplay-wise, the humor is there, the atmosphere and aesthetic are very strong. And if you squint hard enough or choose to get really in-character, I suppose you might miss the game's most obvious flaw: you are, in fact, not being hunted.

Now, are you being searched for? Yes. It absolutely feels like the robots are traversing the land with hopes of stumbling upon you. But they do nothing more to catch you. No following tracks, no systematic area searching, no spreading out, no laying low to get the jump on you, no ambushes, no traps, nothing. The first session of the game feels like you're being hunted, the following ones, when you learn the basics of avoiding (the very loud and visible) patrols, just like a rather bare bones stealth game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11095, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1698223845}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a 10 year old first person stealth/survival game with a few problems.  There's a quirky English upper class theme as you're hunted on procedurally generated islands by homicidal robots hunting people for sport.  Certainly a different spin on the genre.

Gameplay consists of inventory management, stealthing around a lot and using objects like alarm clocks and so on to generate noise and befuddle your hunters.  The goal is to collect a number of shards and put them into standing stones, one for each island, so you can escape.  And that's a problem, because having a goal directly defies the developers own insistence that this is a contentless "sandbox" game.  It's unclear why they chose to mislead gamers in their marketing, but in this case I think it's just a case of bungling.  This is not a sandbox game.  That's actually a good thing.

You can set your own resolution and there's some lightweight graphical tweaks, so this will work on modern PCs to some extent.  But, it is 10 years old and showing a lot of age already, the game assets weren't AAA tier when the game launched back in 2013 and they look worse now. 

The game features no proper level design or game/story flow/plot, as they opted to try to use samey repetitive procgen algorithms as a substitute for adding such content to the game, to avoid doing the important job of level/map design.  As a result, the game doesn't actually have any content worth mentioning, just endless, boring, repetitive, soulless algorithmically generated sameyness.  Developers must learn that procedural generation is not an acceptable substitute for content.

The game is quite buggy, despite all this time the developer had to fix bugs.  Within 5 minutes of starting my first round, I was stuck on terrain and had to terminate the game.  Developers really need to do their jobs properly and test their games before launching on Steam... and they certainly should fix known bugs like this if they intent to keep holding their hand out for your money for a 10 year old game.

Sir, You Are Being Hunted has the gamer gouging price of $20 USD, for which you could easily get any number of older AAA games.  That's right, this costs more than Red Dead Redemption 2 and Grand Theft Auto 5.  That's a ludicrous price for a 10 year old game riddled with bugs, dated graphics, and zero real content because the developer throught procgen algorithms are a perfectly okay substitute for them doing their jobs.  This is also competing with over 9,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.  Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014752983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1669262703}
review: This game can be really tough and the procedural generation leads to some pretty wonky situations (for better and worse). But I really enjoyed the aesthetic and the stealth gameplay can be downright intense! Learning how to use all the items was a joy and the difficulty ramping up the further you get makes for a nice steady incline in difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010994781', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2170, 'last_played': 1692141817}
review:
This game is extremely challenging, especially if you are trying to do a no-kill stealth play through.
The biggest downside is that sometimes the game is impossible to complete. Typically this only happens if you try a 'custom' level generation. The primary objective of the game is to collect pieces of a machine to escape the islands, however sometimes these pieces generate inside of a boulder/building other structure, and are completely unobtainable. This has only ever happened to me twice but is a serious downside and very frustrating if you've already made it close to the end.
That being said, I enjoy this game a lot. it's very replayable with quite a few approaches to finishing. You can hoard weapons and ammo while going on a robot slaughter, or try to stay completely invisible to attempt a passive stealth completion. Requires a lot of patients generally, so if you get frustrated easily or have severe ADD I really wouldn't recommend this game to you. If you like scavenging for items and playing a more "guerrilla" style combat, you will enjoy this quite a bit.
Overall I think this game is very underrated and gets a lot less attention than it deserves. Modding the game is possible, but requires some real technical skill, specifically C# programming. Not many mods exist and the ones that do only modify values for things like "infinite ammo" or similar. I'd love to see that change in the future, as I feel like this game has some serious potential if people could more easily add things into it.
I give it an 8/10, mainly because I really enjoy this type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035710262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1691124334}
review: The reason I stopped at 12.7 hrs was because I simply wanted more that wasn't there. However, I'm writing this review before picking it back up in anticipation for the remake, which I will be buying. The lore is awesome, I loved learning about every little nook and cranny and I simply could't keep going until there was more. The gameplay itself has this charmingly clunky feeling to it, similar to Pathologic 2. Like it shouldn't be nearly as important as it is, yet it absolutely is. This reminds me of the actual burden of using older fashioned firearms, their weight, short capacity, and long reloads, all add to the horror of facing a numerically superior foe. I desperately wish there were more games like this, and with the same dynamic.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198050351772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1690401053}
review: I only played for a couple hours so maybe I'm missing why this game has generally positive reviews. In my opinion hiding in long grass and the use of noise devises to lure enemies away wasn't enough to keep me entertained. I did like the different types of robot enemies and the scenery had a creepy vibe, but in the end the world felt empty for its size, on top of only being able to save in limited spots, after dyeing a few times I didn't want redo the progress I lost.

author: {'steamid': '76561199061583007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1688816504}
review:
Also ich hab das Spiel jetzt zwar nicht sehr lange gespielt, aber schon mehrere Anl√§ufe gehabt. Das Spiel AN SICH, die Grundidee finde ich klasse f√ºr ein Casual-Game, das man immer wieder mal aus der Schublade holen und zocken kann. Allerdings ist mir der Schwierigkeitsgrad zu hoch. Daf√ºr gibt es drei einfache Gr√ºnde:
1. Die Roboter laufen fast immer in Gruppen rum, wenn man sich nicht wirklich gut anstellt bei einer Konfrontation, ist man sehr schnell tot. Und das immer wieder.
2. Die Artefaktfragmente erscheinen wirklich SEHR SEHR SELTEN auf den einzelnen Inseln, also mir pers√∂nlich ist das deutlich zu lange, wie viel Zeit ich brauche um √ºberhaupt mal ein Teil davon zu finden.
3. Ich hab das Spiel gerade eben erst wieder mit dem Sheriff oder Officer oder wie er hei√üt gespielt, das hei√üt man besitzt von Anfang an eine sehr gute Schusswaffe mit der man √ºber Distanz die Feinde eigentlich gut wegmachen kann. Laut Spiel unterst√ºtzt dies den einfachsten Schwierigkeitsgrad. Trotzdem muss ich sagen, leider immer noch recht schwierig, zus√§tzlich ist die Munition ja auch beschr√§nkt.

Also ich werde nicht ganz gl√ºcklich mit dem Spiel, wenn auch die Grundidee hervorragend ist. Am Ende des Tages muss jeder f√ºr sich selbst entscheiden. F√ºr mich trotz allem einen Daumen nach unten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046469142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1883, 'last_played': 1684489753}
review:
Sir is a phenomenally well-designed stealth/survival experience that's got some real rough edges.  The game has been out (and in my library, unplayed) for around a decade now, and its age certainly shows.  It opens with a 'Made with Unity' logo (probably from back before such a thing was even considered silly) and has a somewhat stiff UI for moving items around.  I had an entire play session where my camera would get locked due-north at a flat angle every time I used melee or drank alcohol, which (to be brief) was a virtual death sentence and instant soft-lock.  It went away the next time I launched the game, and never happened again.

All that being said, this game was bonkers fun to pick up and run through even in 2023.  Very minimally-designed, with only a handful of item and enemy types that have virtually zero overlap.  Hell, they could even stand to throw in one or two more (extraordinarily ripe for a sequel, I'd say).  These few components combine to create a genuinely riveting stealth/survival environment that borders on feeling like a sandbox.  The expert design of its enemies and environments does a stunning job of putting you into the headspace of a frightened little prey animal scurrying through the underbrush, and the atmosphere is top-notch.

Big recommend, but with a warning:  this game is ice-cold, and has no innate sense of mercy or justice.  It will command your attention and demand your caution.  So listen, and understand.  It can't be bargained with.  It can't be reasoned with.  It doesn't feel pity, or remorse, or fear.  And it absolutely will not stop, ever, until you are dead.

author: {'steamid': '76561199093989590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1703429991}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is an Old Game by now sure, However i still to this day have never seen another Game like it. It's rather Unique in the fact that it is a Procedurally Generated Stealth / Survival Game which allows a brand new Experience every time you play that isn't just a copy and pasted Map that gets Boring Overtime. There's a Lack of Story, for sure, and the Ending isn't quite what you'd Expect but this does Not Hinder from the Experience. The End Goal is very simple and is your One and Only Task: Collect all Fragments and Return them to the Standing Stones on the Central Island, this may seem easy but Fortunately this is Not the Case as when the Game Introduces the Robots it Becomes more and more Interesting the Longer you play throwing New Challenges at the Player.

Overall, is this Game worth Purchasing? Absolutely, it's a Fun little Experience with lots of Charm and Exciting Moments that made me love this Game. I can't wait for the Remaster that i Myself will Certainly Buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211503816', 'num_games_owned': 655, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1680382124}
review: I don't know what I was expecting, but unsurprisingly its just a little busted-ass indie game from 2014. Making games is hard, and I think that this game was pretty early to the indie game party, so it didn't have years of bangers to take notes from. The odds were very much stacked up against this game and it really just isn't fantastic. The tone doesn't really make sense, the enemy AI is pretty bad, save points are placed half an hour of playtime away from one another to pad the game length, and it's not exactly a looker. It was a commendable effort on the developers part, but you could really do yourself a favor by skipping this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971838196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1679332301}
review:
Spielwertung: 8/10
Spielzeit: ca. 5 Stunden
Spieldurchl√§ufe: 1 (Ende)

Bravo. Der Nervenkitzel der Jagd hat definitiv funktioniert. Nur leider waren wir der Gejagte.

In Erinnerung ist mir eine Rezension geblieben, in dem jemand das Spiel abgewertet und nicht empfohlen hat. Wenn ich mich richtig entsinne, ging der Vorwurf etwa: F√ºr 5 Stunden oder so ganz nett, aber was danach? Total langweilig...
Meine Antwort auf diese/n SchreiberIn w√§re: Was denn noch? 

Die Idee des Spiels ist toll. Ohne gro√üe Erkl√§rung werden wir in eine Welt geworfen. Eine Stimme erkl√§rt uns, dass wir nicht zur√ºckkehren k√∂nnen, weil der Mechanismus zerst√∂rt wurde. Ganz beil√§ufig werden wir mit den Worten entlassen: Ach ja, Sir/Madam, sie werden gejagt (auch das noch!)

Das ganze Spiel ist wie die (klischeehafte Vorstellung von Festlandeurop√§ern) F*chsjagd (das Wort wird ernsthaft zensiert...) von britischen Snobs. Das Problem ist nur: Die J√§ger sind Roboter, sie haben (nat√ºrlich) Schusswaffen und wir passen (neben dem √∂rtlichen Wildbret) in ihr Beuteschema. 
Noch gr√∂√üere Probleme (je nach Klassenwahl): Wir haben KEIN INVENTAR. Keine Waffen, nichts zur Verteidigung, gar n√ºscht. Besonders lustig ist das, wenn man irgendwo am Anfang nur eine Falle findet, den ersten Roboter m√ºhsam dorthin lockt, dieser zwar in Gefangenschaft nicht mehr schie√üt, aber 1. wir ihn weder mit unseren H√§nden noch sonstwas attackieren k√∂nnen und er 2. sich irgendwann wieder von selbst befreit. 

Trotzdem versteht man das Prinzip schnell: Wir m√ºssen H√§user looten (was in diesem Spiel nicht durch Betreten und Anklicken passiert, sondern mit einem Klick auf die T√ºr wird alles verf√ºgbare des Geb√§udes aufgelistet). Sobald wir unsere erste Axt finden, wird das Spiel bedeutend einfacher. Auch die erste Waffe wird gefeiert. Nur leider gilt: Munition ist absolute Mangelware und selbst von verschrotteten Robotern gibt es keinesfalls garantiert Nachschub. Manchmal finden wir auch nur eine zerst√∂rte, unbrauchbare Knarre und einen Sch√§del (?). Trotzdem ist es durch exzessives Looten (und Nahkampft√∂tungen mit der Axt) sehr gut m√∂glich, dass wir 60+ Revolverschuss pder 20+ Schrotflintenmunition zusammenraffen.
Neue Probleme: 1. Nichts in diesem Spiel ist stapelbar. 6 Schuss Revolver oder 2 Schuss Schrot sind 1 Inventarslot. Irgendwann m√ºssen wir uns also entscheiden: Schie√üen, Wegwerfen oder irgendwo zwischenlagern (aber das Zeug holt man eh nie wieder ab...). 
Noch mehr Probleme: Die zu sammelnden Questitems sind teils RIESIG und verbrauchen Inventarslots wie bl√∂d. Auf der Zentralinsel kann man nach jedem Fund noch schnell zur√ºck zum Steinkreis laufen, aber auf den 4 Inseln geht man schon am besten nach dem Motto vor: alle 3 suchen, finden, zur√ºck ins Boot und direkt ab in den Steinkreis. 

Halten wir also fest: Das Spielziel ist es, auf 5 Insel insgesamt 4x3 und 1x5 "Teile" zu finden. Diese verbrauchen manchmal wenig, manchmal super viel Platz im Inventar, bis wir sie am Steinkreis abgeben. Positiv: Rauchs√§ulen verraten ihre Position schon von Weitem. Negativ: Fast immer werden diese Stellen bewacht. Einfach hinlaufen und looten f√§llt also meistens weg, ist aber, mittels Ablenkung, m√∂glich. 

Daneben kommen nat√ºrlich die J√§ger ins Spiel. Die KI ist √ºberschaubar, reizt man sie aber zu stark, wird es gnadenlos. Gegen 1-3 kommt man, entsprechend bewaffnet, noch gut klar, solange man in Deckung geht und m√∂gliche Blutungen sofort behandelt, aber wenn erstmal 5+ auf dich zust√ºrmen, kannst du kaum mehr wegrennen. Das geht fast immer schief. Die einzige Hoffnung ist dann noch das Versteck in hohem Gras. 

√úberhaupt die Umgebung: Die Graphik ist von diesem Sandbox-Spiel eher d√ºrftig, aber 1. ist das Spiel ja schon fast 10 Jahre alt und 2. war es schon damals kein Hingucker. Trotzdem versteht man erstaunlich schnell, wie die "Sichtbarkeitsanzeige" funktioniert. Somit wird "Sir" beinahe zu einem Stealthspiel, wo es um das "unsichtbar-Werden" geht. 

Auch sorgt es f√ºr Abwechslung, das immer neue, "h√§rtere" Roboter-J√§ger mit der Zeit auftauchen und auch die "Jagdgruppen" gef√ºhlt gr√∂√üer werden. 

Ich h√§tte mir etwas mehr Munition f√ºr das "Gewehr" gew√ºnscht, denn davon habe ich genau "1" Patrone gefunden, aber vielleicht ist die Waffe auch zu stark. Daf√ºr ist der Revolver etwas schwach. Manchmal haben nicht mal 6 Kugeln auf die "Standard-J√§ger" gereicht", da hab ich mich h√§ufig gefragt, warum ich jede einzelne Patrone mitschleppe, wo es eine solide Axt gegen 1-3er Gruppen doch auch tut. 

Fazit: Die Anspannung, selbst die Beute zu sein, packt dich, egal wie die Graphik aussieht. Der Tag- und Nachtwechsel sorgt f√ºr Atmosph√§re, denn nachts bist du zwar unsichtbarer, findest aber selbst kaum mehr die T√ºren von H√§usern und tags√ºber kannst du weiter sehen. Im Kopfkino, so schnell wie m√∂glich die Teile von jeder Insel zu finden, gleichzeitig aber stets genug Bandagen, frisches Essen und Munition zu haben, vermischen sich zu einem prickelnden Cocktail. Findet man neue Gegenst√§nde (Dynamit...), will man sie unbedingt ausprobieren, egal wie klug es erscheint so viel "L√§rm" zu machen. Am Anfang zahlt man auch gerne mal Lehrgeld mit dem ein oder anderen "faulen" Gegenstand. Hin und wieder bei√üt man ins Gras, √ºberrascht von einer Horde Roboter-J√§gern oder von deren Treffsicherheit/Schaden. Der ganz gro√üe "Thrill" l√§sst zwar rasch nach und man versucht routiniert die Aufgabe zu Ende zu bringen, aber die Zeit war auf jeden Fall gut angelegt. Um zu meinem Eingangsgedanken zur√ºckzukommen: Ja, nach den 5 Stunden, was macht man dann? Ich h√§tte keine Idee, noch mal (vielleicht mit neuer Klasse) einen neuen Run zu wagen, obwohl Level und Gegner wohl zuf√§llig sind bzw. eingestellt werden k√∂nnen. Aber wozu auch, das Spiel hat seinen Zweck erf√ºllt, es kann wunderbar zu den Akten gelegt werden. 
PS: Im Abspann gibt es einen echt netten Song. Passt sehr gut und wurde sicher nur f√ºr das Spiel geschrieben. Sowas sollten viel mehr Entwickler machen.

review: What I like most about this game was the coupling of tone with environment, it nails the whole premise of being hunted. Even though the game world is cohesive enough to make it an immersive experience, I wasn't confident in my attempt at pursuing the objective. author: {'steamid': '76561197995328992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1668830859}
review:
This is a short game that's worth a look if you can get it for a low price.   The most appealing part of it is the atmosphere, which is very well done.  

The gameplay is a fairly routine quest to collect a few items while sneaking past enemies in a randomly-generated map.  I feel it could've been better if it had more content.  As it stands, it was a unique but mostly forgettable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133584551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 4964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4964, 'last_played': 1627149482}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063195469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1699317729}
review: I WANT to like this, I really do, but I just can't. The Atmosphere, the Presentation, and the Premise all intrigue me to no end, but the game itself is a buggy, clunky, and surprisingly shallow mess. And the A.I. jumps between dumb as a Doornail and hard as Hell. I can't really recommend it in its current state, I'd wait until another update drops, if ever, or a Sequel or Remake comes out before picking it up again. I'll have to find something else in the meantime to sate my Steampunk stealth-horror fix, and I've already bought and played Dishonored 1/2 and Gloomwood, so I'm not sure where to go next.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993700702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1897, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5, 'playtime_at_review': 1355, 'last_played': 1709723825}
review:
Well, it's only taken me 9 years since buying this in the early access state to actually play it in earnest, and gosh... what can I say? It's a work of genius game design.

Remarkable game design in fact. How all the elements of game play coalesce into a terrifyingly tight piece of horror, full of tension and demanding of a thoughtful mind, is a wonder to behold.

Yes, there are bugs (I got stuck between a rock unable to move so had to reload at one point) and some of the interface elements are annoying (there seems to be no way of reducing the zoomed in view mouse sensitivity, for example). And, yes, it has terrible texture work and demands a surprising amount from a computer despite very basic meshes... 

...and yet poor static visuals alone do not stop this game from creating an atmosphere of such incredible immersion that at times it truly transcends to a work of beautiful loveliness, almost becoming like an oil painting. And all the while infused with such "Englishness" that I'd burst out laughing with how ridiculous the whole thing was. And yet the tension never falters, the sheer feeling of danger never drops, and the atmosphere never abates. 

Brilliant game. Brilliant design.

Thank you BIg Robot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011522495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1709239415}
review:
C'est vraiment difficile de noter Sir, you are being hunted sans parler du prix. Vu le contenu, il ne vaut clairement pas ses 20‚Ç¨. J'avoue qu'apr√®s mes 9h de jeux pour en faire le tour (sachant que j'ai du afk en laissant tourner le jeu une paire d'heures), je reste sur ma faim. 
Mais je laisse une note positive, parce que le concept et la r√©alisation sont vraiment excellents. 
Etre pi√©g√© sur un archipel british avec des robots chasseurs qui n'ont qu'un ordre, vous tuer, √ßa m'a vraiment plu. L'ambiance y est sombre, stressante parfois (surtout au d√©but quand on y connait rien). On loot pour avoir de quoi se nourrir, faire des diversions, avec un peu de chance on trouve des p√©toires pour riposter dans le but de r√©ussir √† r√©cup√©rer ses fragments de machine qui nous permettrait de quitter cet endroit. Et plus on a de ses fragments, plus le nombre de robots qui patrouille augmente.
Par contre, le jeu se targue d'avoir des cartes proc√©durales... C'est bien, mais comme on les survole, l'int√©r√™t y est limit√©. De plus, pour avoir test√© une deuxi√®me partie, je trouve qu'au final tout s'y ressemble, ce qui limitera la rejouabilit√©.
Si vraiment vous voulez l'acheter mais que vous n'√™tes pas s√ªr, attendez les soldes, il vaudra d√©j√† plus le coup. Et si vraiment vous voulez pimenter l'exp√©rience, recommencez une partie √† z√©ro √† chaque mort. Je pense √ßa justifiera un peu plus le c√¥t√© proc√©durale des maps et √ßa vous fera durer un peu plus sur ce jeu qui au fond n'est vraiment pas mauvais.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048846150', 'num_games_owned': 815, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1566845377}
review:
You scavenge and roam the British lands looking for a few important pieces of a machine which can help you get off the island and get you to safety. Only problem is that YOU are being hunted, good sir. The severity increases with each piece of the machine you find. Oh, and don't forget to eat.

A stealth game with a creepy and unique atmosphere on the British Isle's. Every game is different as the terrain is randomly generated. You can customize and set your difficulty yourself. Play it alone, or with a friend. You decide.

Fun for a few hours in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966550596', 'num_games_owned': 1126, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1657506518}
review:
I wish I liked Sir, You Are Being Hunted because the themes and humor are spot on. Unfortunately the actual gameplay mostly resolves around you just aimlessly wandering around a procgen world looking for a certain number of doodads to beat the game. There's very basic stealth, very basic survival, and very basic combat. If you're seen you'd better have some weapons because you'll be cut down by gunfire extremely quickly.

Everything in this game works fairly well and it still looks nice despite its age. The biggest problem is that none of the procgen environments are all that interesting to play in and explore. This could have been a classic if there were more gameplay systems with levels that were actually properly designed. Give it a shot if you absolutely love survival and stealth games though.

Shoutout to the narrator of the game though, he's legitimately well acted and funny. Love the robot designs and animation too.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994277501', 'num_games_owned': 1123, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1645988953}
review:
Initially the game has a certain charm and eerie atmosphere, but this is rapidly replaced by frustration in the form of not being able to save and that during the end-game, enemies are able to easily overpower you and offensive items are scarce, as well as lots of houses having pointless junk items. The multiplayer aspect of the game is completely worthless and there is no point in playing it co-op with friends.

All and all a fun concept with poor execution and a map that quickly grows lacklustre, despite being randomly generated. It becomes tedious really quickly. Wouldn't recommend it for 20$.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054206096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1514340732}
review:
[h1] Hunted by the very things that usually serves mankind oh the irony... [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Variety Of Enemies 
+ Randomly Generated Open World
+ Survive With A Friend!

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Your always being hunted by robots.
- The Scare Crow 0_0

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
[i] You are a inventor that invents a portal that accidentally breaks on you and teleports you to a land where machines hunt you down. Can you find all the pieces of the teleporter to repair it and go home or is your fate with your head on a mantle in a robots hunting lodge the choice is yours. [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]
[i] You alone or with friends have to find pieces of your device and piece back together your teleportation beacon to be brought back to safety before getting killed by one of the many different robots that will be looking for you throughout multiple islands. Do remember you are being actively hunted though stealth is a recommended option you can go offensive and attack back if ya don't get swarmed by reinforcements. [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
 I would not buy this full price but on sale this game will give a good couple of hours of fun. Especially if you have a friend to play with! 

[h1] Final Score 67/100  Ranking D Tier [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198137076399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1651259340}
review:
I've tried a couple times now to get into Sir because the creepy-funny world is great and the concept is amazing. Unfortunately, it's executed quite badly. While the robots are certainly very scary and their hunting AI seems great, the majority of the game is just: walk to a place, loot something (be it one of the fragments you need to win or just some supplies), walk around the robots or use something to distract them and then walk around them again. That really is it, there's no diversity in approach to sustain the game. The tension wears off and becomes boredom. What is needed is a variety of tools and gadgets to manipulate and avoid the increasingly dangerous robots; we can still be left low on supplies at all times and dramatically underpowered, it's just that the translation into moment-to-moment gameplay needs to be more than 'throw a bottle' and 'walk slowly through this field.' Again, the slow pace is something I often enjoy in games, but there needs to be more. 

Looking at reviews, it seems the game was essentially abandoned in Alpha and a 'full-release' label slapped onto the game. I think that shines through -- with more diversity of content, this game could have been incredible.

BUT... I do think it's worth a try if you can get it very cheap, if only because some people seem to wind up loving it. Just don't prioritise the game over much because of its cool premise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198312356089', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 915, 'last_played': 1681145140}
review:
[h1]‚≠ê Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a refreshing take on the stealth survival genre! ‚≠ê[/h1]

Be warned! After 30 minutes into this game, you will have ordered yourself a tweed suit, a pipe, and a bottle of single malt whisky before cracking on with attempting to escape your robotic pursuers üòÇ.

With the aptly named, procedurally-generated British landscape, you will have to explore the 5 biomes: castle, industrial, rural, mountainous, and fenland in order to track down your means of escape!

The game rewards your progress by causing ever more relentless and dangerous enemies to spawn, which systematically increases the game's difficulty. I, for one, couldn‚Äôt wait to see what enemies popped up next, from the Land Owner to The Rider, and you certainly walk away with a real sense of achievement upon completion, safe in the knowledge that your hard work paid off and that you adapted to the dangers that were presented to you and were successful due to your newly found skill.

I highly recommend this game and cannot wait for the reinvented edition to be released, so if you enjoy this, get it on your wish list! Well done, Big Robot!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xabR4bqMJNM&t=1s

author: {'steamid': '76561198119283106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1649711068}

author: {'steamid': '76561198272060473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1685720961}
review: This game is some of the most fun I have had in a video game, for all the comedic trappings this world is immersive and can leave you feeling more scared than any horror game has ever left you. (seriously I can't run my 3D printer while i sleep because the sounds it makes are too similar to the robots that it freaks me out). The game is old and clearly some parts are incomplete, but it is still good fun, though if you want a wide selection of weapons and enemies you should probably look elsewhere, but if you want a funny and terrifying survival experience this game is it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971880699', 'num_games_owned': 2839, 'num_reviews': 418, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1648961581}
review:
I'm playing this and Stardew Valley right now. 

Two games could not be so completely different.  Well, maybe Super Hexagon and Chess.

Where Stardew Valley is the ultimate in chill out time. No pressure in the world.  I tend to play a day or two every evening.  Getting near the end of my second year.  Building a Cellar (because I can) and I'm about to get married.  No survival, you don't even need to eat, unless you run low on energy.  Even the "economy" is so easy to make heaps of cash out of.  Totally casual with everyone liking me because I give them presents...

...Sir, you are being Hunted, is the exact opposite.  Everyone (Crazy robots) wants to kill me.  It's hard just to keep oneself fed, let alone make any progress.  With save points only at the starting location and the boats connecting the 5 islands, I find playing very tense and stressful.  After about 30 minutes I'm emotionally exhausted and I need to stop!  

But there are two similarities, and that is the save system.  Neither game can you save at any time, but you need to finish the day/run. That, and they both start with the letter "s" :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198062265037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 345, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1642133279}
review:
I thought this game was alright when I tried it out a few years ago, but evidently since then they've changed devs and tried to make it multiplayer friendly and now it is so buggy that there's no point in playing. Look at the forums and you'll see what I mean. I don't know how this has any positive reviews at all.

The bugs which stopped me in my 20 minutes of recent play were:

Unable to bring up the map, which is extremely important in a game like this.

Inventory mouseover quickly stopped working. This also matters a lot because while you find a lot of food the majority of it is poisonous and you can't necessarily recognize this from just the picture. The mouseover text tells you if it is edible.

As far as the gameplay goes you have a hunger mechanic which drops like a rock - I've never seen a hunger mechanic that harsh before. The robots were easy to avoid, so provided the game even works for you most of the game you're going to be fighting hunger and scrounging for food as opposed to actually getting hunted.

So, no. And as I understand it the dev is working hard on a sequel to this, which takes an extraordinary amount of nerve given the state they left this game in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984228901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1641652325}
review:
Not a bad game, but a tedious one, Sir, You Are Being Hunted has good ideas and an interesting world, but the repetitive gameplay loop tries the patience a little too much.

The core objective is to find all the pieces of a teleporter and return them to your spawn point, all the while being stalked by robot hunters. The idea is here, but the lack of any real innovation is what keeps the game from being more than a few hours of fun. Sneaking is slow and mundane, looting isn't very rewarding whether from a killed hunter or a building, environments are mostly clusters of building or shrubs to hide behind, gunplay is deliberately inaccurate but once you collect enough ammo thats pretty much all you'll be doing is shooting to speed up the game. Enemy variety is slightly varied, but a clean sniper shot brings most of them down, and even if you want to conserve ammo, a bear trap with an axe and bottle to lead them into it is a very effective strategy.

For what its worth, im happy they are making a sequel/remaster, the game isn't bad by any means, but could use more innovation to keep the game from feeling boring. Avoid this version and wait for the reinvented edition, but obviously wait for reviews to see if it isn't a train wreck, cause that's the era of gaming we live in now where nearly everything is half-baked on release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144847295', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1592528936}
review:
Can't really recommend this game as a solo experience - it's kind of empty and the depth isn't really there. You just kind of walk around, crouch, and pick up pieces of the spaceship. You pick 'em all up, you win. 

Multiplayer, however, is another story. While the mechanics are mostly the same, the last person to put in a piece wins alone. This means when playing with your friends, there are temporary alliances, betrayal, and strategy to make sure you win. Literally all of my hours are from multiplayer, and every session has always been a fun mess of selling people out and getting out of tight spots. if nothing else, buy this to play with your friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979177060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1675633648}
review: What I love about this game is that it is a game captures the spooky nature of the British landscape. Hiding in hedgerows and sprinting across moorland in pursuit of artefacts that will allow you to get home, all the while being pursued by various types of tweed-clad robots hunters (who complain about taxes) is thrilling because you constantly trying to work out a survivable level of peril you can subject yourself to. Every action seems a gamble.  The islands are randomly generated so each new game will give you a different landscape, and you get some control over what's generated (fens, mountains, etc).  I'm terrible at computer games and I've had this for ages and never been able to best it! Not bothered though, as it is still a great deal of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061737345', 'num_games_owned': 788, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1577419077}
review:
[h1]Am I? Is that what's happening?[/h1]
Are you sure that I'm being hunted? Because the last time I checked, there were just a bunch of robots patrolling around the vicinity of random abandoned buildings.

In [i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i], you are - supposedly - being hunted. You find yourself isolated on a randomly generated island, with little but your wits about you, and nary an objective but to survive. The issue is that there's not a whole lot to say about the game. 

[b]G A M E P L A Y[/b]
You sprint around the empty moorland until you see a hostile robot on the horizon, usually guarding some sort of derelict building, sneak past them to loot said building, then leave. This chain of events repeats itself over and over, and is pretty much half of the gameplay. Otherwise, you're intended to hunt down 'fragments' and bring them back to the standing stones which you spawn by at the beginning of the game. The storyline is vague, and doesn't really have any bearing on the events that occur, but the 'fragments', when assembled, allow you passage off of the island, and completion of the game. There's not much else to it.

[b]G R A P H I C S[/b]
Textures are blurry and the whole atmosphere (perhaps by design, in the spirit of Britain) is dreary. It's not great to look at. Inventory items look as though they're from a different game, perhaps even being representative of what the developers had intended the world to resemble.

[b]G R A P H I C S[/b]
The sound design doesn't leap out as being particularly exceptional in any regard.

Overall 'Sir, You Are Being Hunted' may have been a strong entry into the survival genre 8 years ago, but it just feels kind of weak today. There's a remaster on the horizon for 2022, so perhaps it's worth holding out for that. Some additional world-building could go a long way for the remaster, and I'm hoping that there are some sort of narrative elements and characters introduced into the world. The original just feels like a bare-bones survival game that leans too heavily on its quirky upper-crust English gentleman aesthetic.

4.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198063019128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1632413482}
review:
BEAUTIFUL WORLD. HORRIBLE STEALTH GAMEPLAY.  The stealth in this game sucks.  It is impossible to distract those robots for long enough, far enough away that I can go in and grab the artifact.  They don't stay distracted for long enough, there's still no guarantee that they won't spot you when you HAVE TO expose yourself to grab the artifact, I cannot get them to move far enough away from the artifact, and if they spot you it is nearly impossible to run away if you have to stop to heal yourself, you will be spotted again.
Throwing objects for distraction is tricky at best because you have no idea how far you can throw it or where exactly it will land, which just complicates the whole process of distraction.  That bottle didn't land far enough away? OOPS guess your fucked now.
Traps are worthless because the robots move in very unpredictable ways.  Guns shouldn't be an option because this is a stealth game, not DOOM, but even then these robots are terminators and take damage unreliably.

The thing that pisses me off about this game is that there are little hints of brilliance in here.  I love the look of the game, the environments feel like real places and I love the atmosphere, especially the industrial zones.  Exploration is the best part of the game, the stealth is the worst.  I want to like this game, I want to LOVE it, but I can't.  It's raw, it's fucked, it's alpha and it sucks.  And now they're coming out with updates that fix everything BUT the gameplay?  Fuck you.  You cannot tell me that the developers actually played their own game because these problems are so frustrating they cannot go unnoticed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198225604700', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1632412009}
review:
I haven't played for too long and went in basically blind since this looked so good, but I already adore this! The stress of being hunted is actually exciting unlike my usual anxiety, which I almost never feel but this game keeps me on edge that the robots are on my tail no matter what I do! I absolutely will keep playing this game and try to finally survive through a whole session again and again :))

Also I was able to giggle a little cuz the robots can say things like "These taxes are outragously high!" which i didn't expect them to do, still absolutely horrified that they're about to skin me for a human coat but certainly something to keep me around for more

author: {'steamid': '76561198008981680', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1631827712}
review:
I played this game a little when it first came out. I was maybe 14 at the time. I didn't really understand it and was terrible at it but I appreciated what it was trying to do. I thought the very middling reviews it got were unfair despite not having much experience with it.

After coming back to it a few days ago having seen the update and remaster announcement, I realised I was absolutely correct and I will never forgive the bastard from PC gamer who gave this absolute gem a 63/100.

The atmosphere in this game is masterful. Each of the island biomes is absolutely oozing with this very unique not-so-merry England aesthetic. Being born and raised in the middle of buttfuck nowhere in the west country myself, some of these environments feel eerily familiar to me. The rolling fields, desolate scrubland, thorny hedgerows and leafless pockets of forest are all very accurate yet grimdarkified reflections of the countryside that lays right outside my house. It almost feels like if you have not experienced life in a rural area of the UK, you will not fully understand exactly how good this game's environments and atmosphere is. Hell, I'm pretty sure some of the randomly generated signs have shown the names of actual villages I've visited in real life.

Gameplay wise, Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a very tense experience. Given you start the game with the aristocrat loadout like a true Bri'ish Chad, you are largely defenceless until you find a weapon. From what I've seen, the weapons available are: the shotgun (found on the hunters), revolver (found on the squires but also spawn in houses), blunderbuss (found on the poachers), the hatchet (found in various loot containers) and the rifle which I only ever found ammo for. The combat is serviceable. The guns feel fine to use but aiming feels a little janky sometimes. The hatchet on the other hand is extremely clunky and slow. Normally this would be a fairly damning indicator that a game is in fact not very good, however, in this case it actually works spectacularly in Sir, You Are Being Hunted's favour. Hatchets are quite common, guns are quite the opposite. I found a revolver in a house once in my last run, any other guns I found after that were on the corpses of enemies I killed with said revolver. Ammo is very scarce. You can occasionally find ammo for all the guns in houses or on enemies but usually in very small quantities. On top of this, ammo can take up a lot of inventory space. You can only stack 2 shotgun shells in 1 slot, 6 revolver bullets in 1 slot and 10 rifle bullets in 2 slots. This makes combat very risky. You likely wont even have enough ammo to take on more than 3 or 4 enemies at any given time. As a result, stealth is more often than not the most sensible option for getting past groups of enemies. To assist you in your sneaking efforts, you can find items such as empty bottles and alarm clocks with which to distract your foes. Stealth in this game feels like a genuinely rewarding and intense experience. I have had many close calls, saved by my sudden remembrance that I still have a bottle in my inventory and promptly throwing it in the opposite direction of where I want to go. The pieces that you need to retrieve to progress the game are always closely watched by at least 2 hunters so you may need to engage in combat at some point in your run but with a combination of clever inventory management and maybe a bit of luck you should have enough tools at your disposal to allow to slip in and out, unseen.

The enemies in this game are all intimidating in their own unique ways. The hunters are a rather formidable force in large enough numbers and can see you pretty easily. The dogs may not do much damage but they pin you down and add and extra level of terror to combat encounters. The squires are just rather pleasant chaps given you don't steal anything from the villages they patrol (trust me, they will know) and even fight with the other enemies sometimes. The poachers are really cute and I wish they didn't hate me. The scarecrows never gave me any trouble but you do need to be wary of them. The riders can eat shit and die and the landowner is a fat fuck. I think I've covered all the enemies there. There's also a bloke in a hot air balloon who patrols the island but he's very slow and the most he does is alert nearby enemies to your location if he sees you. I've also seen a tentacled robot sea monster pop up fairly frequently along the coasts of the islands but it's never attacked me.

My only real complaint is that this game has almost fuck all lore. You get a short cutscene when you start in which a man who I can only assume is the player character's butler explains that you have accidentally teleported to this strange archipelago after some kind of scientific experiment gone wrong. You start at a stone circle in the middle of the central island. You must locate parts of a device used in this experiment and return them to this stone circle. That's just about all the info you are given. No explanation for why these islands are inhabited by robots, no explanation as to why these robots are posh and no clues as to what your experiment even was. Now, there are letters which can be found in houses you come across but they are very few and far between. Some of the letters don't even reveal anything related to the game's lore and none that I've found link to any of the other letters. This is very frustrating. I'm usually most sucked into a game and immersed when it has some good juicy lore to uncover. This game just teases you with it's letters which don't really reveal anything and I feel the player is actually blocked off from finding a lot of them as so many villages are patrolled by increasingly large parties of enemies. I hope in the remaster that there will maybe be some additions which make the lore a little more obvious, or at least increase the spawn rate of the letters so the player actually has a good chance to read them all.

Overall I love this game. I can forgive the lack of meaningful story for it's sheer magnificence in the atmosphere and gameplay department. If I had to score it I'd say it is a very solid 8/10 at the very least. Fuck you guy who reviewed this for PC gamer in 2014, I hope you got fired.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085150472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1630972987}
review: Sir, You Are Being Hunted is an exercise in patience and avoidance. It's a goofy mixture of resource management and doodad fetching. You must explore and survive across 5 islands that are populated with metal clad miscreants. As you locate and return doodads to a central collection point the game seems to scale up in difficulty which I found to be very challenging. Weapons and ammunition are scarce so attempting to brawl with these chaps is not often a wise choice, rather distracting them with a mixture of alarm clocks and shattered beer bottles in a clever way yields better results.

review:
Unfortunately the game feels empty.

All you do is traverse empty environments to get to the same four buildings and loot them. Most of the loot is useless and pointless. The stealth system is fine, but there is no interaction besides that. Combat is kinda clunky, you can either melee enemies or shoot them. You have to kill enemies to get some vague plot device. That's it, that's the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249015684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1628976032}
review:
I think this is a great game with one or two short comings. I have enjoyed it very much, and it is loads of fun with friends. That being said, I will go into my gripes with the game first.
My main issue with the game is that it gets stale fast. The game-play loop basically boils down to wander aimlessly until you see a smoke cloud, then grab the monolith piece, and return. There is some looting to be had, but outside of getting a few bits of food and a half decent weapon, you will mostly be hauling it to just get the fragments and get out. Enemies often form large groups, making combat a distant second to stealth and running away. Ultimately, the issue is there is too little variety. More ways to interect with this quirky world and its enemies are sorely needed. 
However, I will say the core game is well built. Health and vitality are well balanced, combat never felt unfair, aside from maybe fighting 10 enemies in the first place. Stealth is clearly explained to the player, the robots are suitably terrifying to make hiding from them fun. 
Like I said it gets boring fast, but with friends, or in short, spread out sessions (like the game you play once every few months) it is quite enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198998262497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 437, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1626313126}
review:
SIR, YOU ARE BEING HUNTED

I was disappointed with this title, I found it boring and empty, the land all looks the same, you can't go into buildings and the loot grid system is a major pain.

I came across three buildings all named the same like it was some kinda asset flip, the funny thing is that they we're right beside each other, very lazy.

Hiding from the robots seem like a boring chore rather then a man hunt.. all for what, to collect these stone things to get off the islands.

I wish I could have played longer but my tolerance for boring survival is spent... 40 mins was enough

Ugly looking
Boring 
Empty

The concept was interesting though...

4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198070615521', 'num_games_owned': 329, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1701559469}
review:
I finished two runs in this game, and while I did enjoy this game (enough to do 2nd run and finish it in 1 hour and 25 minutes..), it felt like something was missing from it. The guns, first off, feel genuinely terrible except maybe the rifle. Sometimes it felt like STALKER guns when you play on the easiest mode.

Items don't respawn, so if you get a horrible spawn (I've heard of people hardly getting any ammo, weapons, or sometimes even food) you might just have to suck it up and remake.

Despite this, I felt stimulated. I felt horrified and nervous - and the atmosphere of the game genuinely had me invested. I liked the slight breaks of bleakness with occasional funny robot lines and weird, funny letters, they were hilarious but didn't break the feel of the game. I enjoyed this a lot more than I thought I would. Unexpected, predictable, and unique.

review:
You're runnin around, collecting stuff to do """progression""" and you are being hunted by uncanny robots and flying machines. Oh, and the entire thing is done in charming posh old english with tea and biscuits and british towns to explore. I think they added mulitplayer too so.... [winking/grinning emoji]

Maybe a bit too janky and dated for today's world though. It's been a while and it never used to be a very polished experience.

If you like "Oh... Sir!" you'll like this game as well

author: {'steamid': '76561199156554836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1622296706}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted √® sicuramente un'esperienza videoludica che consiglierei a tutti di fare. Attingendo a piene mani dal racconto di Richard Connell "La preda pi√π pericolosa" e rivisitandolo in salsa fantascientifica, il gioco riesce a fare ci√≤ che promette fin dal titolo: farvi sentire una preda. 
Piccolo consiglio prima di giocare: meno sapete del gioco e meglio √®. Per questo rimarr√≤ abbastanza vago nella recensione.
A prescindere dal "kit" con cui abbiamo scelto di iniziare (io consiglio l'aristocratico, per un immersione completa) ci ritroveremo in continuazione a sgattaiolare in mezzo a campi di grano, rovine di antichi castelli e cittadine fantasma in cerca di cibo o qualsiasi cosa possa tornarci utile per sopravvivere ai nostri inseguitori. Pi√π volte mi sono ritrovato immobile stretto in un angolo buio sperando che i robotici cacciatori  alle mie calcagna non mi trovassero.
All'inizio il gioco sar√† abbastanza semplice: pochi cacciatori in giro per la mappa e poche tipologie, con la conseguente possibilit√† di correre dove vogliamo, lootando senza paura. Con l'avanzare del tempo (e della missione principale) i nemici sulla mappa aumenteranno e ne incontreremo di diversi tipi. Una delle cose che ho amato di pi√π in questo gioco √® stata quella di ritrovarmi davanti un robot-cacciatore  che non avevo mai incontrato prima e provare da un lato curiosit√† e dall'altro paura di cosa potesse farmi se mi avesse visto.
Ora, io vorrei dirvi che andando pi√π avanti nel gioco i ruoli si ribaltano e saremo noi quelli a cacciare ma... molto probabilmente non sar√† cos√¨. Io non amo i giochi stealth ma molte volte, nonostante avessi un'arma e un sufficiente numero di munizioni, ho preferito giocarmela in sicurezza, usando sotterfugi e nascondendomi per evitare il nemico. Ricordate: sparare attirer√† altri cacciatori verso la vostra posizione. 
Detto ci√≤, il gioco non √® perfetto. Io lo considero un gioco con enormi possibilit√† solo parzialmente messe in atto, ed √® un vero peccato. La trama poteva essere un po pi√π dettagliata e nonostante ci siano in giro lettere o libri che spiegano gli eventi, ho scoperto che non sar√† possibile trovarli tutti alla prima partita. Anche la mancanza di interni (oltre alle rovine del castello) si fa sentire dopo qualche ora. Mancanza parzialmente compensata dalle ottime atmosfere e dai biomi ben distinti fra di loro.
Comunque finito il gioco sono stato contento di averlo comprato e per questo ve lo consiglio.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163559624', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1671110248}
review: I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073436583', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1621028540}
review:
Basic review:

Sir you are being hunted is a quirky survival game with robust combat, stealth and inventory management mechanics. 

It marries all of these elements well together leading to interesting and unique encounters even after many hours of game play.

The procedural environments (a engine component that was all the rage when this game came out) works incredibly well. Unlike others Ames that use a similar system, the environments and the assets in them make sense and are pleasing to look at and discover.

My personal review:

This game does a really good job of lampooning British culture in many ways. Mainly mocking common archetypes of the British middle class and landed gentry, it really gives a great number of nods to lots of different things.

From English-little-village place names (all complete with their own war memorial) to the very reason that you can stealth being because you are wearing tweed!

I think that this game is possibly 20% more enjoyable to me simply because I‚Äôm English and can appreciate the frequent tiny (but not insignificant) gags and Easter eggs (looking at you dead haggis).

I‚Äôm so happy I redownloaded this and so happy I paid for it after pirating it when I was much younger. 

It‚Äôs a total gem, you‚Äôll enjoy it - it‚Äôs worth the price

author: {'steamid': '76561198112596020', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 380, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1616088596}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted. So run across 5 empty maps with random building and go on an annoying easter egg hunt that gets repetitive. The game feels weak in many areas. It stealth is what you would expect from most fps games that do it horribly. Comparable to Farcry... A mediocre stealth system that is seen time and time again. Then you run building to building to hopefully get, the stuff you need. Even the dev said he felt not so happy with it as it didnt flow so well. Its very basic. DEFINITLEY NOT WORTH 20 dollars as well. honestly worth 10. Luckily I got it for as little as nothing. Even then the game feels more like a chore than fun. Even though I did find some of it enjoyable. After collecting little over half of the artifacts I was done with it. It adds alternative starts for replayablity called roles that basically make you start with different stuff. The base mode makes you start with nothing though, so whats the point? To make it easier than that which is recommended you play in the first place? Pointless. I can't recommend it. I can see why most people do though I was kinda teeter tottering on it. Nonetheless I lean more on it being bellow average rather than almost average or average.

4.9/10 The robots are British.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123046489', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 941, 'last_played': 1634440911}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted made me follow Big Robot Ltd for their other games, and really enjoy their work. This game is great, but it does have it's quirks and bugs. They're not major enough to destroy the mood, except for the occasional falling through the ground.

There's a certain pace to this open-world stealth game that make it exciting and scary. Comparing it to their other first-person game, The Signal From T√∂lva, there's also a lot of walking, but both find ways to make it interesting and feel fine. In SYABH, there's so much walking, crouching and waiting, but they made it feel necessary and stimulating. You're measuring distances robots are from you, counting robots in the distance against the amount of bullets you have, watching your vitality drop while you're hiding, and calculating your next move.

The sound design is pretty well done, and there's so much listening in this game - every beep, boop, clank and stomp are felt. You're listening for who's making a noise, how many of them, which direction they are, and if they're coming your way. The ambient music and sound are so appropriate, and I enjoy having that suspense broken by a flock of squawking birds giving away my position or [spoiler]the splashing of water when robot tentacles surface[/spoiler]. The narration and robot banter is also a nice break once in a while as its both charming and humorous.

The character design and how new robots appear as your progress is an excellent escalation. My first encounters with hunters was terrifying, and after I felt like I had a handle of luring, evading, and killing them, they introduce more and challenging robots to deal with. They all fit together in a very interesting way, making nothing feel safe by the end of it all. I personally really enjoy the feeling of terror when I see a large, stalking robot in the distance making noises.

As the maps are randomly generated, there's a decent variation to the biomes they create. One of my few issues with the terrain is not being able to properly identify how concealing a bush will or won't be and climbing up steeper slopes or even rocks has some jankiness to it. I've only tried the multiplayer a couple of times, and both times the other player and me fell through the ground - which I believe had been corrected but I haven't played it since.

Although it's been well over 7 years since this has come out, I just finished it after a few failed runs, and still really enjoy it. It's absolutely possible to go back to, which I find myself doing on and off, but I'm glad to have picked this up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058699167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1615296302}
review:
This game has aged like milk since I first played it on Desura. It felt like an alpha then and it still does after all these years, except now it's up against games like The Long Dark.
The devs have copy-and-pasted the same exact game, just with a different coat of paint. They should've kept working on this one, atleast it had some popularity behind it.

The game is not worth $20 or even $10. If it ever goes on sale for $5 or less, get it if you REALLY like the survival horror genre. Otherwise? Just move on.

Unas casas y edificios que est√°n de adorno, y s√≥lo puedes interactuar con la puerta para recoger objetos absurdos y sin sentido, esperando tener suerte y que te salga alguna arma con la que poder hacer frente a unos robots que quieren darte caza cual jabal√≠.
Los escenarios se generan aleatoriamente, pero tal generaci√≥n se la pod√≠an haber ahorrado, ya que siempre es lo mismo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013498285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1116, 'last_played': 1615582400}
review: One of the best stealth games I've ever played. Speaking as a big fan of the stealth genre, I find it extremely immersive, the tension really racks up as the game progresses and you have to evade multiple patrolling hunting parties as well as fast mounted enemies that produce light. The enemy detection is very harsh but always feels fair: even fully concealed you'll be spotted if enemies get too close and actions such as making a fire or startling a flock of birds will attract enemies from far away ‚Äî something that can be used to your advantage. The "English countryside simulator" looks quite nice in my opinion and the game is quirky and funny. I would also say it's very replayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025819861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 12284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9935, 'last_played': 1677282887}
review:
[h1]Recommended[/h1]
Thoroughly enjoyed this game. Tense without being scary (until you hear the call of the land owner in the distance!).
Loved being able to choose whether to sneak, using distractions, or go in guns blazing.
Keep an eye on your vitality, stock up on food (tea if you can find it), always have a bandage on hand, hope to find a map!
[b]NB change the default build to include one of each biome![/b]

This is an excellent [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=231869541]guide[/url]
And the wiki is useful, especially the [url=https://www.siryouarebeinghuntedwiki.com/wiki/Table_of_Vittles]list of food[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198110320406', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1634882348}
review: Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a fun game. It has a unique "survive, scavenge, and story" type feel to it. Highly customizable in terms of game play. The game revolves around finding pieces of a device to ultimately win the game. There are (15??) pieces to collect and 5 islands to get them all from. You are able to customize all the 5 islands and which enemies spawn at which points in time making the game easier or harder. The game itself isn't too hard until the later stages on just default mode (I played as the default character and put 1 of every kind of island). Great potential for different challenging forms of play. Now to explain why I would NOT recommend this game. As a matter of principle I feel I should mention at the time of purchasing this game I bought it as a Alpha type game. After the developers added a few of the things they said they would add they slapped a "1.0" on it made a couple of "patches" and declared the game "finished". The final game is nothing like what they promised it would be. I cant say it isnt fun as a solo type game but the multiplayer is absolutely horrible. On numerous tries the Host has no issues but the guest will get teleported under the map, fall through the ground resulting in their death, get stuck running in place are some examples of the worst issues. The developers have abandoned this game and do not plan on returning to it after all this time they still insist this is the final product. All in all for a solo 1 or 2 time playthrough its not that bad, but really its just a shadow of the game it was supposed to be. If you are really interested in this game I would HEAVILY suggest you watch some videos of it online and really think about if you wanna spend the money on this game. |Story 2/10| |gameplay 4/10| |atmosphere 6/10| |replayability 3/10 (repetitive gameplay at a harder difficulty just makes the game longer)| too bad it didn't go anywhere huge potential. :(
