author: {'steamid': '76561198125931187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1610435312}
review:
On it's surface, Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a very silly, simple game. The title itself brings an air of silliness to it, an air of silliness which is only exacerbated by the comically British narrator and enemies. 

But this game has quite a lot to offer beyond a laugh or two. Pretty quickly, you learn that the opponents are deceptively powerful, as a small excursion of two or so robots can quickly turn into a mob of near a dozen, all firing at you as you run through the trees. You learn quickly to utilize stealth to gain the upper hand, as your shotgun, pistol, and/or axe aren't going to cut it (no pun intended) when you're faced with enough enemies. And the stealth system is surprisingly robust, too, especially for the time: crouching in darkness or among dense foliage can make you darn near invisible, giving you a sense of pride as you slink between patrols of enemies (that is, until they step on you). Setting up traps or using one of the several different methods of distraction is fun and exhilarating, and well-balanced to allow you enough leeway to get what you need done while still having a smart enough AI that it will punish you for any hubris while you sneak away. If you scare off a group of crows while trudging through the forest, it alerts nearby searching parties, forcing you to evacuate the area before they find you. 

It goes both ways, too; the robots really feel as though they're a part of this world, as they're also vulnerable to many of the pitfalls that you are, such as scaring off crows to give away their position, or running into traps that you've set. It lends itself to be really intuitive when you're trying to sneak past a patrol to loot a town, while also not making it too easy on you. 

The game really ramps up after a couple of hours, when the robots begin to send more and more forces after you. A lot of the negative reviews for this game chastise it for being boring - I don't think many of them actually saw the massive, lumbering Landowner appear from a patch of woods and begin chasing after you, though. The game often throws curveballs like this towards you, and while they may not always be fair (as it is a randomly generated game), it's certainly going to keep you on your toes. 

That being said, the game is simple. But that's okay! Minecraft is simple, too. The reason why games like these are so good is because they take one, core mechanic and they make it click almost perfectly. I wish more games would take the foundation of this game, the robust stealth mechanics, and the unique sense of dread and incorporate it into a larger-scale project and narrative. Smaller indie developers like Big Robot tend to do a great job with this, and I hope they find success implementing these sorts of things into AAA games, too.

review:
Despite it's age, I only heard of this game a few days ago. I love the look, the feel and the dark humour put into your perilous situation by your adviser/butler person. The down side is I am now going to have to buy a game controller as this is the style of game I'd normally play on my Play Station and I can't get used to the mouse and keyboard set up. 
I wish they'd port this to the PS4/5 and XBox, but given the games age, it's probably never gonna happen. I'd buy it (again) in a trice!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031492153', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1609354458}
review: A strong concept that begs for expanding, but the gameplay loop of search, scavenge, and possibly fight wears itself thin rather quickly. I enjoyed all the time I spent with this game, as little as I did, but unfortunately it just doesn't have enough to really make an impact. I find myself thinking of what a sequel would offer more while playing than actually getting into what's here.  I do hope they revisit this concept in the future, as I do love the idea of islands overrun with robots who are bent on killing you. They could call it "Sir, You Are Being Hunted... Again!" and I'd be very interested to see what it would turn out to be. There's lore, aesthetic, and an overall vibe here that really does demand to be explored with more depth, but unfortunately for now we only have this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091705382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1601004401}
review:
This game should cost about 5$ at most.

What you get is a very basic randomized shooting/survivial/stealth game. It looks absolutely great and in my opinion the artstyle/feeling is fantastic. Yet I find myself having 2.5hrs of play, and the top-review I saw had about 2hr of play?

I guess the game just gets boring after an hour of play, how sad is this? Could be easily circumvented by creating some Skills/Perks, investing time in more weapons and enemy types. Maybe a combat with more descisions about it than "who do I shoot first" or some kind of special events or sidequests.

The game has none of this. you run around a big ass island collecting rocks and crushing cocks and thats all you will be doing. its as if skyrim had no NPCs or fauna besides draugs in dungeons and all youd be tasked of doing was to collect dragonclaw #25. youre not gonna find it that interesting after 60 mins.

sad, because I really liked the artstyle and general feeling, but theres just nothing to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042229052', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1498, 'last_played': 1679696666}
review:
It's not a perfect game, and from what I can tell the multiplayer is no longer supported. Still, I enjoy it. It's the funniest survival horror game I know of, and those aren't usually things that go together.

Gameplay-wise it's got a fair bit going for it, lots of different enemies, many items and the option to sneak as much as possible or to be more aggressive (not that you can go in guns blazing).

The random generation is good in the sense that it almost never produces anything that negatively impacts gameplay, although it is largely quite samey, but the numerous different biome types help to break up the monotony.

author: {'steamid': '76561198239377534', 'num_games_owned': 61, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1607562317}
review:
Scary, suspenseful, and challenging. Every feeling you could ever hope to experience in a game of stealth and survival.
If you need a fill of nerve-racking suspense and the challenge of multitasking while travelling back and forth long distances, this game is for you. And if you're not so much a fan of the challenge, you can always tweak the difficulty before you start the game.
If you're looking for a game to play when it's dark out but want horrors other than jumpscares, get this game.

review:
Pretty good game in which you have to avoid robots which want you dead. If you ever get spotted, you better run because just a few shots will kill you in this game (and some will only fire once and you'll be dead).

The only really bad part about this game is the amount of walking you have to do to get around which quickly gets boring and tedious (and it becomes a real pain if you end up needing to find one last piece to complete the game).

author: {'steamid': '76561198005559933', 'num_games_owned': 595, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 988, 'last_played': 1635280048}
review:
If you decide to give this game a go get used to cowering in the shadows.

Took years to get round to giving it a chance but in the end i really enjoyed it. Not a long game but its minimalist ambience and scary robots got me determined to finish it. 

Started out with the controller but i had to switch to mouse and keyboard due to being spotted afew to many times, mouse i found is needed to take robots down efficiently before most of the damn island knows my location.

edit: do play as the aristocrat to get the full knife edge survival vibe, starting out with nothing is the way it should be played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081477001', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1491937620}
review:
Shamelessly British, and even more shamelessly stereotypical in its Britishness.

Contrary to its promotional material, [i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i] is not a funny game - its substance is of mechanics and style, not of words. Yes, enemies are amusing to look at, and using alarm clocks and toy trains as distraction tools can be entertaining, but make no mistake - this game's stealth is rather unforgiving. It does a very good job making an open-world where stealth is a neccessity rather than an option - if you are discovered, more often than not you will be quickly hunted down. That's a feat few manage to accomplish.

The combination of different enemy types and devices in your inventory can lead to uniquely tense situations you will not soon forget. I think I will forever remember how I was hiding in the wheat field, shaking as two jockeys were riding almost over my head and both roads along the field were being partolled by two large squads of robots, and the way that I was supposed to go stood a scarecrow which, if I moved too soon, would surely alert all the scrap-metal gentry in the vicinity. Seeing how few and far between saves are in this game, death matters. I think I only had vaguely similar feelings when I first launched [i]Kenshi[/i]. Same weakness, same vast spaces. Maybe [i]S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Chernobyl[/i] freeplay mod as well. Seeing how Rossignol's second game, [i]Signal from Tolva[/i] is inspired by [i]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.[/i], familiarity comes as no surprise.

I had a really enjoyable time with it for the duration of one run which was about 5 hours (ignore my playtime), but I couldn't really bring myself to come back to it. I think It's worth one go, so it might be a good idea to pick it up on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284429082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1602127870}
review:
I wanted to like this game. I played for the first two hours and vastly enjoyed the experience, but I quickly started noticing several flaws as I moved forward, so glaring that I grew a hatred for the game rather than the passionate liking I originally had. 
The game is super unpolished.
It's been out for 7+ years and the game still feels like it's incomplete, not to mention the creators are moving onto more ambitious projects like The Light game, I can only believe this game was just some passion project.
The menu is confusing to navigate, especially when you're trying to start your first campaign, which feels more like a minecraft world without the passion of building or crafting or mining, just some guy aimlessly wandering until he stumbles across some gems.
All the items are incredibly displeasing to look at, in your inventory and in your hand. It feels like they settled for their first draft of design and never updated it.
There is literally no point to the water. Going in it can get you killed, and there's never a reason to go in it. They didn't even bother adding a swimming mechanic, you just stand in the water to infinatum until you get bored or the bog monster takes you. 
The games lore is unfinished and unpolished, if there even is lore.
Enemies AI is generally okay, but the way you're hunted makes it feel like a constant game of going bush to bush until you find a gem, then bush to bush again. The cooler looking enemies don't provide a lot, there's no reason to become the hunter because killing enemies is virtually unrewarding and time consuming.
You would imagine the hunters, after spotting you, the only thing left to do is finish the job. But the hunters are notoriously bad at killing you. Even at close ranges I find it hillariously easy to strike one down with an axe despite the fact he's wielding a shotgun. Their aim is god awful and they shoot each other more than shoot me, thus creating robot gang violence.
The difficulty scaling is also very unpolished, with timers indicating when certain enemies spawn, and by the "end of the game"m (I say this because once every timers up there is no scaling, just you going around until all the gems are got) you never get room to breathe as hundreds of hunters spawn. Different islands don't get difficult scaling, all the enemies are the same across each island, based on timers and gems.
You kill every single enemy on the first island, leave and come back, and suddenly there's those enemies and more. You don't feel rewarded, you feel cheated. 
The different islands offer little variety save from some textures and structures found, and there's never any unique enemies for different zones. 
The game also takes a long time to load, despite the fact it's held together by string and tape.
There is lots I like about this game too, but it cant overshadow the fact this game is unfinished garbage that they don't intend of fixing any time soon. 
I enjoyed the atmosphere the game creates. 
The sound is very well implemented along with the usage of spatial awareness via sounds like footsteps or speaking. 
The textures on trees, grass and fences and even some of the roads and houses are appealing to look at and really make me feel like I'm being hunted by british robots. 
For what its worth, the purposes of each enemy is fulfilled well. To the Landowners terrifying posture and ever-lasting threat, to the gentleman who guards homes. Each enemy has a purpose it serves, just there's so much that could be added to make this game full. 
Nothing would make me happier than this games multiplayer being updated, unique enemies and better textures which they're clearly capable of. 
I spent 20$ on this game so you don't have to. This would be the only game I actually recommend pirating, or just getting for a dollar. They aren't going to update it, so you have nothing to worry about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036278064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1602118991}

author: {'steamid': '76561198238791406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1610641914}
review:
My only complaint is that the bear traps disappear on player death, if they are placed down in the world. This is probably due to all entities in the world being despawned and spawned, it would seem; so it isn't to hard to understand the reason for this issue. That said, if it could be fixed, that would be great.

Other than the above stated, the game is a fantastic light stealth survival game. I can run it on a 12? year old computer (i stopped counting after 10), so lag won't be an issue. Even with the graphics turned down to the minimum, it still doesn't look horrible.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988001805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1411973694}
review:
Not the best game and rather a short slightly open world survival/stealth where you have to escape the area after finding an item.
Doesn't sound very interesting does it?. But what was interesting was the beautiful and darn right creepy ai robots than stalk you through out the experience. 
You can fight some of the basic enemies but some of them you have to hide or distract in order to get away. Some you outright cannot kill, but it was the atmosphere that i found really made me turn a down vote into a wary up vote.

Watch a video and if the special types of ai don't tickle your interest just pass. The game itself is rather shallow.

review: Very fun game; a solid entry in the stealth genre. Not really replayable in my opinion, however, it's fun for what it is and the length of one play is long enough to satisfy. The downsides are: very repetitive with few enemy types and little reason to engage the more exotic/tough enemy types beyond wanting to challenge yourself. At full price most likely not worth it, but got this at maybe a couple bucks makes it a great value. I want more Big Robot games!

author: {'steamid': '76561198419374960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1695791624}
review: I love the sneaky but also combat mechanics. The music score is fantastic (sadly I've yet to encounter Hungarian dance no.5 as performed in the trailer) and I feel that despite the graphics everything tells a story, the robot lines are hilarious, etc. I do wish that the stereo on the robots are a little better. I have a hard time telling if robots are behind me or in front of me simply by ear. I've yet to travel to other islands but the rural biome is beautiful at day and haunting at night! I love the contrast, although I'd rather it would be fantastic if sir/madam was able to craft items on his/her own.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993870560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3773, 'last_played': 1695420603}
review:
This is a fun game of stealth and patience. I highly recommend it be in your cache of games to play when you just want to relax a little. It also is the funniest game since the original Team Fortress 3. 

Whoever wrote this game must have received from his grandparents the anger and resentment that ordinary English people felt against the ruling classes in the bullshit merry old England of earlier times. The game is a witty satire of rural life around 1900, when everything was utterly splendid, unless you were unemployed, a laborer, a factory worker, a servant, or a tenant farmer. All the robots are rural gentry types: The landowner who sics his dogs on any tenant who can‚Äôt pay his rent, the Squire on the lookout for ‚Äúvagrants‚Äù to arrest for slave labor. The hunter robots seem to be middle-class guests from the City; they wander around trailing pipe smoke, saying every smug clich√©: good sport, what fun, find the trespasser, when I was young this was all fields, move along nothing to see here, I‚Äôve lost the blighter, etc. It's a pleasure to kill them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198799118364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1598978551}
review: Sir if you can hear this then game has gone terribly wrong, This game had promise and potential but ended up being a rushed, buggy and unfinished game, concept was good the final product not so much, I remember seeing this game for the first time years ago, I watched MattShea playthrough the game and I fell in love with it but I forgotten about it until I saw it on sale I instantly bought it remembering how good it looked those years ago, the very moment I started the game I felt a wave of excitement, I started my grand adventure and started collecting the pieces, fought robots and all the good stuff it was fun... for the first playthrough the second time was pretty boring as it was all the same even with different Islands and robot spawn rates it got boring pretty quickly, food was never a problem, the moment you get a weapon the fear you first felt while hiding in the shrubbery from the poachers and hot air balloons disappears and the hunter becomes the hunted, don't event try multiplayer that is just as broken as Cry of Fear's MP and is pretty much a free for all where you can work together for a little bit before it turns into a free for all to put the last piece into the standing stones, The full price of the game is too high in my opinion so wait until you get a hefty discount, oh and do be careful sir you are being hunted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082768434', 'num_games_owned': 357, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1577124208}
review:
Conceptually fine, and I think the content of the game is good, but the overall gameplay loop is boring and repetitive when you succeed, and agonizingly frustrating when you fail. I wish I could recommend it, because I do feel like passion went into it, but I could never really get into it. Reminds me a bit of "We Happy Few" when it originally came out.

If you don't know what that means, let me tell ya. It's not a good thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198382316457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1593470753}
review:
This game is kind of hit and miss. It's fun in quite a few ways, but quite lacking in other areas.

Firstly, despite what the store page says about the replayability of this game, I don't think many people will do more than one play-through. Maybe two if you want to do a speed run or to do it on the highest difficulty. The game lacks anything that makes me want to come back for more.

The actual gameplay is fun and thrilling for the first 2-3 hours, but becomes boring and tedious towards the end game. Once you realise that fighting the robots is the thing that's most likely to get you killed, stealth is really the only option unless you want a real challenge. The difficulty can be changed to suit ones tastes but just using the presets, it wasn't very difficult at all.

I can only recommend this game if you can get it on sale, as it isn't worth the full price, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067906769', 'num_games_owned': 1210, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1592229993}
review:
It kinda oldish in computer game wise but the game play itself has aged well.
I would love to see a modern version of this same concept. Single player game in a very hostile environment where everything is truly against you. 
The feeling of turning against your hunters is impressive.
I mean you really feel satisfaction once you find first weapons and get little edge.
You start to feel like you just might have a change ;)
The game does get harder as it goes along and its a constantly keeping you in your seat.
Even the inventory management is excellent cause its not easy, it makes a very claustrophobic experience.

I dare to recommend it  and I do hope that the makers haven't abandoned this concept cause it works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249202022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1583952957}
review:
You have to understand that I don't know if this is a "good game". I wasn't able to finish it until I turned Most of the enemies completely off and then I fucked around for a while regularly getting scared half to death by the thing that shows up out of the water. So I don't know how balanced the default settings are, but they are extremely customizable, so you're fine either way. In that sense, it's one of the most disability-friendly games in the genre. Probably not so hot if you're colorblind or have very bad eyesight though.

I find the premise charming, and I think it was implemented fairly well. I love that you can shoot the birds and rabbits going about for food, and they're not just there to fill up space. I love the variety of starting states you can pick from. I love the snarky tone of the butler. I love that you can change from "Sir" to "Madam" just because. I love the descriptions of the items, I love that you can store items in certain locations for later and Only Find Them There (unlike games where you put something in a chest and find it in every other iteration of that chest everywhere else).

I do not know if I could Use these mechanics if I was playing on standard difficulty. Probably Not. I am Very Bad at Stealth.  But it's so fun, for a little while. I imagine it's even more fun if you're somewhat skilled.

The one thing I feel is missing is a proper end to wrap it up. You put all the pieces together and nothing happens. It doesn't turn out that the butler set you up to get murdered by bots, or how the bots ended up there, or what experiments you were running. There's lore scattered in the letters, but I never found them all, and I like games with stories, so that was a slight let-down for me.

The credits song is so fun that I sat through the whole thing though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979628961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 285, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1591049568}
review:
ah it started so good while it did not ended completely bad i still deceid to refund it

at first the atmophere is so damn good when you really play like being the weak hunted guy who wants absolutely not get into trouble

the sound is so well made even some triple AAA studios could learn from these guys but thats about it at least for me

as soon as you realize how easy it is to run away from the robots with infinite stamina all the atmosphere is gone and as soon as you find your first gun you will see headshot get them down like in any other game

but you will run out of ammo soon and the run away game starts all over

like i said the first half hour was really a blast so tense but yeah all gone now sadly 

i suggest having a look at generation zero instead wich has a better balance between sneaking shooting and running in my opinion and it also has very good sounds specially the robot sounds are very good and oberall the modern graphics look a lot better

i dont call syabh overall a bad game but for 2020 it has not enough to stay in my library i wish i had played it back then 

if i could i had given a thumb to the side cause im sure one or the other guy out there may have some fun with it

author: {'steamid': '76561198059150296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1632679202}
review:
This is a unique game, you should definitely give it a chance. 

Pros:
-Gameplay
-Atmosphere

Cons:
-Replayability

?
-Multiplayer (never played)

It's an open-world, horror, FPS, adventure type of game with a little bit of survival elements. There are 5 different islands, each with a certain piece of element that you need to get. You need to travel to those islands, find the element, take it and move on. You have to be discrete so that you don't alarm the guards in the islands. Sometimes you have to eliminate them. Sometimes you have to fight them and sometimes you have to run away. 

The uniqueness comes from the difficulty of the game. It requires patience, attention. The sources for weapons are scarce and the inventory is limited, so you have to plan your belongings very well. You cannot save everywhere, so you have to plan your attacks very well. The map is not very informative, so you have to observe your surroundings very well. There are different kind of weapons and enemies which doesn't allow the gameplay to be monotone. 

The game also requires courage. The atmosphere is very dark. You get really scared to go out because they can kill you, but you also have to hurry because the enemy gets stronger with passing time. This way the game doesn't let you rest, it keeps you tense all the time. 

Once the game finishes, you linger there wanting more of it but there is nothing much to do. You can replay with a different character, but you wouldn't want it because the game is already very tense, you wouldn't want to experience the same thing again. I didn't play in multiplayer mode. It could be very good, but I don't think I could find many people playing this.

The graphics are a little bit outdated, but that isn't much of a concern for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995627577', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1584796174}
review:
I was an original Kickstarter backer. The premise was pretty cool, survive by sneaking around Robot gentlemen on a procedurally generated British Isle. This was when procedural generation was more of a selling point, as games tried to recreate Minecraft's genius.

I only just beat the game (going through my backlog quarantined from the Coronavirus) . Took me about 4 hours or so for that playthrough.  I'd say the game is worth one playthrough. It's an interesting moment when you find yourself putting back rifle ammo so you can make room for an alarm clock. At the same time, don't expect to have much more fun beyond that one playthrough. You will have pretty much seen everything. The infinite number of islands are all the same, and at some point the strategy of using a distraction to get your maguffin is rote. If you are a big fan of stealth games, you'll probably recognize this as an interesting experiment.

Also, no online presence as far as I can tell. Another holdover from a slightly older video game age.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137712048', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2600, 'last_played': 1620879181}
review: This. Game. Is. AMAZING. Amazing Concept, Amazing Form, Amazing Gameplay, It all comes together to make an incredible game. Even if this game is 7 years old, It's aged extremely well. Singleplayer Shenanigens, Multiplayer Madness, It'll always be an amazing game of find 17 parts of a machine scattered across 5 islands and try not to be killed by robots who like to drink tea (wat), Act Like Shakespeare with a severed head (also wat), and want to kill you because they can. If you can avoid the Normies, Poachers, Riders, Squires, Dogs, Balloons, Scarecrows (this thing's spooky), and Landowners (also this thing is terrifying) you get to slice, shoot, trap, chuck dynamite to your hearts content! Then, you have the task at hand. Getting out. You have to find all 17 pieces of a shattered device that are spreaded out over the 5 islands,( and luckily, it isn't rogue-like) and put them in one place to survive. So, if you want to get into stealth games, GET THIS GAME!

author: {'steamid': '76561199014102540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1640232241}
review: This is an amazing game! It has great mechanics, great settings, and a great concept for a survival game. You have to be into the depth with this game to make sure your survive. You have to look for food and weaponry to kill any robot that stands in between you and your only way home. I recommend this game full heartedly and hope more learn about this game and make play it to understand how a real survival game is played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198356787706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1582152844}
review:
i hate to give this game a thumbs down, because starting out I actually really liked the idea. The comedy is amusing, the feel of constantly being behind enemy lines is thrilling, and the shooting works surprisingly well for a game that feels so low-budget. My biggest gripe with the game is that I noticed after a while, where the game starts ramping up in difficulty, that the difficulty spike just felt way too steep. 

Basically, you're this high-class British man/woman who has to find pieces to some kind of teleporter machine in order to escape this world filled with murderous machines. You find machine parts throughout different locations, carry them back to the teleporter and eventually after you find enough pieces you can escape. And with every piece you bring back to the machine, more enemies and enemy types spawn in to make the hunt a little more intense. 

The increased difficulty would be perfectly fine, except a few key things make it feel outrageously unfair...

1. There are no health packs to regenerate health, If you get hurt, you have to run and hide until your health regenerates. 

2. Ammo is scarce. Too scarce. Hardly ever in houses, and mostly found on enemies. Sure, you can pull it off enemies you kill, but sometimes their guns get destroyed in the combat which makes you lose any ammo you could have gained. 

3. This lovely bleeding mechanic that can trigger when you get hurt. The more you bleed, the faster your health depletes. The only way to stop bleeding is to apply bandages which you can only use by coming to a dead stop, frantically searching your inventory, and applying the bandages manually. At first, this doesn't seem too bad when there's not that many enemies early in the game, but you really start to notice how inconvenient this mechanic is when you're running for your life from a mob of killer robots (with guns, mind you) while bleeding profusely from bullet wounds. When you start bleeding, you're pretty much screwed because if you run while bleeding, you're dead. And if you stop to bandage yourself, you're dead. 

Now, I know what you're thinking; "Just don't fight the robots then!" Well, here's the catch...after you find so many pieces to the machine, more and more enemies spawn in and it gets to the point where it feels nigh impossible to make any progress without getting into combat. 

The breaking point for me was when I had one more machine part to collect in an area. This particular machine part happened to spawn in this thicket area smack dab in the middle of the island, where a group of robots was guarding the part. To make matters worse, groups of hunters and other enemies were constantly patrolling the area around the thicket. 
In short, couldn't sneak in because there were so many enemies and the thicket made it hard to see where I was going. Fighting wasn't really an option, because I could only find and carry so much ammo and I was severely outgunned anyway. And every time I tried to distract the robots with a noise making device, I tried sneaking away from the sound source only to get spotted by robots anyway because there were so many of these guys patrolling the area. At this point in the game, I'd died about only four times. After trying and failing to get this piece repeatedly, that number bumped up to the 20's.

Now despite my ranting, I'm not saying I hated this game. I actually really enjoyed the concept, and if you like stealth FPS games there's some good fun to be had here. Just understand that this is game does have its flaws that can make it very frustrating to play at times. If you can overlook some of the clunky mechanics and the difficulty curve, then you'll probably enjoy it. Just beware, this game takes a lot of patience. A LOT of patience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050607454', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1674695005}
review:
Brilliant, punishing psychological horror. Absolutely chilling experience, really makes you feel like helpless prey, even as you approach a state where you think you are starting to even the odds...

The hunters remind to whom the fields really belong.

If you want to know what it's really like to wage a secret saboteur war against trigger happy occupiers, here is your chance, sir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028263188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1605121089}
review:
Always torn about this game, in one sense of the world, masterful.

I really enjoyed the stealth aspect of the game, and that killing everything isnt the answer, HOWEVER.

The reason im going to be having to give this a thumbs down (Developers choice imo) Is because in order to save, You need to go back to the structure you're collecting (Manually, by walking!) and if not, and you need to go, sadly your progress is lost. Maybe this is fun for people that don't have an agenda for the day, and are willing to commit themselves into a game like that, but that's not me.

If this was optional, would've given it a thumbs up I guess

author: {'steamid': '76561198287649260', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1609020866}
review:
A relatively simple stealth game with a charming but incredibly tense atmosphere. You have used a strange machine that has malfunctioned and taken you into an alternative reality where robots have taken over, and your Butler advises you to find the pieces of the machine and bring them back to the standing stone on the center island. The gameplay is similar to that of the Thief series but using brush and foliage rather than shadows. There's an inventory and you need to find tea and biscuits every once in a while so you won't starve.

The procedurally generated 5 islands are individually striking and, for what the graphics are, they are pretty, mimicking the British countryside and environs. As it's different in each playthrough it does make for some replayability, but you have to give it some time, because there's not much beyond the survival element and looking for the machine pieces.

This game has little story, if any, but I personally didn't mind. I was too busy sneaking around the countryside, running from robots with guns and their robodogs, up to my nose in mud and beartraps, my heart in my throat the whole time. This game is really meant for people who get something out of the experience, the gameplay, the immersion, the fear and sneaky satisfaction. It's mesmerizing, but if it seems too slow or you don't see any point in it then this game isn't for you. There's no cinematics or saving the world. It's just saving your hide. From Gentlemen Robots.

There is an adjustable difficulty for each enemy type, and there are several to keep an eye on, and the islands become unforgivingly crowded near the end. Brutally funny is the perfect description.

It has it's scary moments for such a whimsical idea but this game is absolutely fantastic! It was 100% worth the money and is one of my favorites, very satisfying to finish. This is a very underrated title, and if anyone cares, Gloomwood looks like it'll be very similar sneaky, creepy, gentleman game. This game is up there on my list of greats because, although there's not much to it, the simple wonders of stealth is strong with this one. I would advise a podcast in the background while you play, especially a funny one, because this game is rather tongue-in-cheek... But beware, the gameplay is 100% serious, and Sir, You ARE Being Hunted, after all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970147831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 2690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2300, 'last_played': 1664314953}
review: Theres a very particular kind of thrill that I adore in Sir You are being hunted,  crawling through the fields of wheat,   peeking over hedgerows and glancing between the trees all to avoid the unwanted advances of hostile tweed clad robots.   This game possesses beautifully opressive atmosphere through it's choice of british winter tones, it's sullen moody soundtrack and the swift,  terrible cracks of a hunters shotgun as you realise you've wandered just that little bit too close to the worlds Bronze clad misanthropic automatons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047328877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2089, 'last_played': 1656773843}
review:
A stealth game that's fun for people who do not enjoy stealth games, that's how I'd describe 'Sir, you are being hunted'. The atmosphere is the best part of the game, and the sound design makes sneaking up to robots incredibly tense. Every beep and boop has you on edge, and you don't know whether you've been spotted until the guns start to go off! 

It is perfect for some casual playing for fun - watching the intro, spying on the robots, getting a piece or two, visiting one of the other islands to get a change in surroundings... But the game becomes more monotonous as you keep going, until the final stretch ends up being a bit of a chore with enemies that aren't so much challenging as they are annoying. 
For dedicated stealth-game players/lovers, I don't think this game is for you. Hiding options are limited to crouching and breaking the line of sight, and the maps are very open. Hiding behind a tree or rock is about as complex as it is going to get. Your standard distraction items are present - a trumpet to make noise, a toy train to make noise that moves, a clock to make noise after some time, a rock to make noise, and a glass bottle to make noise. Every encounter to get hold of a machine piece will quickly start looking the same. See piece, assess robots, throw distraction, grab piece, done. Escaping from robots is simple as well, if you are not right at their feet - a brisk sprint is enough to keep you alive. 

There is a rudimentary survival system in place that allows you to hunt rabbits and other game and cook them for recovery items, but once you learn how to circumvent the basic robot hunters you will never struggle for food again. It is far more likely that you will end up with a bloated inventory that forces you to throw food out so you can take a machine piece with you! There are junk items and dubious items in the game that risk lowering your condition when you eat them, but this is not randomised, so you will quickly learn which items are useless. 


Final verdict; a really great time on the short term, kind of a drag at long term. The best aspect of it is fighting the robots, and the tension from sneaking really close to them, but there isn't much more that makes this game fun. I still really recommend it, I had a blast, and I still occasionally pick it up. For a game that needs some work around gameplay, the world feels alive and mysterious!

author: {'steamid': '76561197966511621', 'num_games_owned': 1215, 'num_reviews': 609, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1570489495}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a charming concept. You (m/f) are a fop and you get dropped on an island full of robots hunting you. You have to gather 'the things' and bring them to 'the place' to escape. There's a couple of different starting options, e.g. the cook, the trapper, the officer. You scour the four (five?) islands looking for 'the things' while trying to avoid the robots and gathering items. There's weapons, food, distraction items, usable items (e.g. matches) and junk. You find them on enemies and in houses - which have no interiors, you just 'use' the doors.

The concept is fun, being hunted is quite tense and it's different from most games. Unfortunately, it's not without its problems:

The game takes several minutes to randomly generate the world. When it's done an introductory video starts playing. I missed half of it because i was in the kitchen. If you have long loading times, don't automatically start anything at the end but bring up a "click to continue" prompt.

The controls are clunky, you can't simply drag items from your (non-auto-sorting) inventory to drop them, you have to right-click on them to bring up a menu that includes the "drop" option. This gets old real quick. 

After finding the second 'thing' i looked everywhere but just couldn't find the third one. You have to look for smoke but i only found fireplaces i couldn't use, because both of the "easy" starting options lack matches and i didn't find any in the 35 minutes i played. Which is kinda confusing.

The buildings are really really low resolution. Seriously, it's sometimes hard to tell what part is the door.

At some point i tried to get to a part of the island i hadn't been to. There was a poorly generated gap in between. I fell in the water. There was no way to get out. I couldn't even swim out to sea. 

Asking ‚Ç¨20 for a semi-finished game is just an insult.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998455758', 'num_games_owned': 1566, 'num_reviews': 1960, 'playtime_forever': 1459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1671283807}
review: A wonderful terrible and very scary game. You find yourself in a world where robots prey on humans and must escape. They are very difficult to kill, they comb the forest with teams, set traps - everything is like in a classic hunt. There are almost no supplies, they will need to be looked for and try not to catch the eye. You will find weapons only a couple of hours after the start. As you explore the world, more and more intelligent and powerful opponents will appear. And finally, no minimap, orientation on the ground - only on landmarks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119611220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1568271078}
review: This game ended up surprising me in quite a few ways, I had it as a gift for a while now by my best friend(who I wanna say discovered this game when Jack Septic Eye was playing it on YouTube for like.. 2 episodes), and I won't lie when I say that I wasn't too enthusiastic about this game at first. This is a randomly generated world kind of game, meaning that each time you play the game, it will have a different map to traverse, along with different item spawns. When it comes to these games, the usual deciding factors revolve around RNG(random number generation), meaning you have a chance of starting with some of the best stuff in the game near where you spawn in, yet you have just as much of a random chance for nothing of use to be around you from every corner. Now while I have only one full playthrough on singleplayer to go by, I think there is enough to circumvent that frustration here. For starters: classes that gives you items to start with, allowing you to start off with a crutch or with little to nothing, for those that wants a more "raw" survival experience. It was definitely a bit difficult at first, as it was best to be as smart as humanly possibly when dealing with the robotic enemies that search around the map for you, but it mostly depends on how many and what type they are, along with what methods you have of dealing with them. Basic robots tends to just have a simple shotgun, but if you had lets say, an axe, you can just land two hits on them, especially if you get them while reloading, so they go from a pretty big early game threat, to a small challenge to defeat when you can for the extras they drop. Dogs are alot harder if you're not ready to shoot them before they lunge at you, landowners are giants that can take all too much punishment so I try to stay clear of them so far, the blunderbust wielding midgets that are found in the groups of trees are just devastating if they hit you with a shot, the fat guys that roam the towns can take alot of bullets but drop revolvers with a fair amount of ammo on them to make them worth taking down, then you also have jousting robots on robot horses that are a pain in the ass if you're not ready to hit the main robot as many times as you can in his face, you have robots up in hot air balloons that have searchlights for your ass, and finally f  u  c  k  i  n  g scarecrows that follow you and make you a paranoid human as they do everything they can to make you dread hearing them teasing being behind you! That aside? The game is actually quite quirky with its parody of British culture, while having alot of personality from its enemies to the general tone this game gives. It may not be a looker, but god damn will it make you have chills with the kind of atmosphere it strives for and succeeds in, its a shame it seems this game isn't talked about or even updated too regularly, because its definitely worth a look!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041248461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1444227174}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted √® un survival game con elementi stealth. Il gioco inizia con noi che ci risvegliamo su questa isola e il nostro scopo √® quello di trovare dei pezzi di un marchingegno che ci permetter√† di fuggire, peccato che l'isola √® disseminata di robot "inglesi" che ci danno la caccia. Il gioco non √® ambientato su una sola isola ma su un arcipelago formato da cinque isole, una centrale e le altre nei quattro punti cardinali. All'inizio di una partita si pu√≤ scegliere il "tema" delle singole isole poi vengono generate in modo procedurale, per√≤ la cosa funziona solo a met√†, alla fine le isole sembrano comunque tutte uguali cambiano giusto qualche edificio, si pu√≤ scegliere il proprio equipaggiamento iniziale e si inizia la ricerca di questi pezzi sparsi tra le isole, nelle isole troviamo questi robot "inglesi" che ci danno la caccia, noi dobbiamo sfuggire a questi robot e sopravvivere, l'idea di fondo del gioco √® intrigante ma √® sviluppata un p√≤ male. 

La parte survival del gioco √® basilare, l'unica cosa che ci viene chiesta √® quella di cercare del cibo per mantenerci in salute, non c'√® crafting, basta girare per le case per trovare del cibo, case che non possono essere esplorate all'interno ma sono in fin dei conti delle grosse casse. Oltre al cibo possiamo trovare qualche arma, qualche oggetto per distrarre i robot e tante tantissime cianfrusaglie, √® incredibile come gli sviluppatori sono riusciti a creare tanti oggetti inutili (inutili veramente non hanno nessun utilizzo in gioco) e pochi oggetti utili. Per evitare i robot basta non farsi vedere, si avanza accucciati nell'erba alta, si posso distrarre e anche affrontare ma √® sconsigliato perch√© i proiettili sono pochi e loro con un paio di colpi ti mandano all'altro mondo oltre che il rumore di spari attira tutti i robot dell'isola. Ad inizio gioco il numero e i tipi di robot sono pochi, man mano che accumuliamo i pezzi aumenta sia il numero che i tipi di robot, i tipi di robot sono sufficienti e alcuni sono veramente inquietanti.

A livello grafico e sonoro il gioco √® sufficiente, niente di che ma fa il suo lavoro. Il gioco √® in prima persona ed ha un ciclo giorno notte, alla fine il gioco diverte ma un p√≤ ripetitivo, bastava veramente poco per renderlo un buon gioco, in primis un sistema di crafting anche basilare, molti pi√π oggetti utili e gli interni nelle strutture, io l'ho preso a 1$ con altri giochi e secondo me √® da prendere solo cosi perch√© in giro ci sono survival migliori. Il gioco ha anche una componente multyplayer tipica di questo genere di giochi.

[b][u]Pro[/u][/b]
+ Alcune buone idee
+ Buona longevit√†
[b][u]Contro[/u][/b]
- Ripetitivo
- Survival poco profondo

author: {'steamid': '76561198121534415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1231, 'last_played': 1567076371}
review:
An impressive little game. 
Best parts: developing strategies for dealing with different types of enemies, the different terrain design on each island, the inventory system, creating different combinations of items to sneak past enemies. 
Least favorite parts: It isn't clear what to do with the dubious items, I wish there was a mini crafting system that made use of these, hunting for the stones gets a little tedious without the scanner, hunting for the stones ends up being a little repetitive as well, I wish there were more scenarios for them to be stored in i.e. not just on the ground but, at the end of a cave or inside of a robot that must be killed.

review: I was surprised by Sir, You Are Being Hunted, and pleasantly so. Stealth survival horror with a strong (and very British) personality. Much of the gameplay is focused on distraction and redirection rather than combat or camouflage. If your looking for a game with some whit, some terror, and some crumpets, look no further. As a side note, you can play online with friends as well. The shenanigans only multiply.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999756575', 'num_games_owned': 942, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1565189119}
review:
I got this on sale for 4 dollars not realizing it was made in 2014 and I'm a big fan. Been on my wishlist for a while because I like stealth games.

Is the game tedious? Sometimes. Is it visually underwhelming? Sure. Is it a bit barebones? Absolutely.

But my god did I have fun.

The premise of Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a simple one. You're tasked with collecting 16 artifacts of varying sizes across 5 areas, each cardinal direction and the center. You have an inventory which is grid-based (think Resident Evil 4) and you have a fairly limited amount of inventory to carry weapons, ammo, healing items, traps, and the aforementioned artifacts, which can either take up 1, 3, or 16 squares. You often won't know how big the artifact is until you attempt to pick it up, which is really stressful when you have a full inventory and you realize it's the largest artifact size while you're trying to clean out space as the enemies you lured away are gradually returning to their post.

As the name would imply, you are indeed being hunted by a variety of British robots that have very solid AI and can see relatively far. Your stealth meter depends on whether it's daytime/nighttime, whether you're sprinting, running, standing or crouching, as well as being contingent on if you're standing in the open or crouched in tall grass- your basic fare stealth mechanics.

The enemy design is pretty good. There are a variety of enemies to evade, the most common ones being the Hunter, a mustachio'd robot armed with a shotgun that either guards an artifact or patrols around villages and fields. They're easy to take down with 2 well-placed revolver shots, but if you're faced with more than 2 of them your best option is stealth instead of direct confrontation. There's also the squire who protects villages and will make quick work of you with his rapid-fire revolver that will kill you easily unless you're hiding behind cover, as well as the Hounds which patrol alongside hunters and run around quickly to sniff you out.

Probably the creepiest enemy is the Landowner, a giant hulking robot that can't be destroyed and slowly patrols around the area making these terrifying moose-esque shrieks and stomping ominously so you can hear him from a distance.

The scarecrow is without a doubt the most deadly enemy. Despite standing there and not doing any damage to you, once he spots you he'll teleport behind you indefinitely, emitting a loud shrieking sound that brings every enemy for miles. As soon as you realize he's seen you, you need to kill him FAST (like within 5 seconds) so you can have a chance of escaping undetected. If you don't, he'll simply lure all the nearby enemies towards him, at which point they'll stay, leaving you stuck and sure to die.

The gameplay consists of looting buildings for ammo and other helpful items and sneaking around trying to kill or avoid enemy robots. Once you beat the game, it basically just says "good job, you beat the game" and that's the end of it. Not much replayability unless you really like the game and want to try again on a harder difficulty (I played on Aristocrat mode per the game's recommendation). You'd think after such a long time of being out the creator would create achievements for the game, but he's understandably probably focusing on his newer games, which are more-or-less variations on SYABH's formula of resource management and stealth, but with a bigger emphasis on science fiction.

Overall, not a perfect game, but a damn enjoyable one, especially on sale. Shame it doesn't have more to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026218489', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 11861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 107, 'playtime_at_review': 1982, 'last_played': 1710686746}
review:
I've been playing this game since it first came out on the Humble Bundle (2013, if I'm not mistaken!), switching it over to Steam after a year or two. Ever since I bought it, I've been playing and recording it for my Youtube channel. As of the posting of this review, I'm currently up to episode 256: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vMIB5RQA8bE

And yet I've realised that, in all that time, I've never actually written a review for Sir, You Are Being Hunted. This has to be rectified immediately.

For me, Sir is the gift that keeps on giving, and it's definitely up there in my list of favourite games. I never anticipated, back in 2013, that I would still be playing this game today. Yet here I am, devising challenges to put a new slant on the gameplay with the help of my audience. With a bit of imagination, you can really get your money's worth out of a game like this!

So what is it about it that I like?

Whilst Sir is by no means an amazingly ground-breaking experience, it is nevertheless a fairly solid survival-stealth game. You're pitched into a sinister world that looks like the British countryside, except with a twist: it's populated by murderous aristocratic robots who enjoy hunting humans for sport. Did I also mention they have shotguns? Or revolvers, in some cases? Or blunderbusses? To avoid being turned into a human-skin rug or having your head mounted on a wall plaque, you need to sneak around a series of islands (which you can customise by tweaking their biomes and features, I will add) acquiring pieces of a device that will enable you to teleport out of there.

You can stealth it, using the environment for cover and drawing upon a variety of items to distract the robots. Or you can get your hands on some guns of your own and fight back! If you choose the latter though, take my advice:

1) Don't get too close to the Poacher. Or he'll blast your face off.
2) Don't get caught out in the open by the Rider. Or he'll rip your face off.
3) Don't get yourself in close proximity to the Landowner. Or he'll nuke your face off.
4) Don't get the Squire in a grumpy mood by raiding his village. Or he'll put six shots into you in quick succession... then tear your face off.

All in all, as someone who grew up in a rural area in the UK, the British rural theme for the setting is what really hooked me. That, plus the premise of being chased by upper class automatons.

Granted, there are elements of the game which could be improved or developed further. Sometimes the open countryside might benefit from having some more interactivity. There are also a lot of items you can find in the game that don't actually have a use. And, sadly, there doesn't seem to be as much activity on the multiplayer side of things as there used to be. But then again, I tend to stick to single player anyway.

Part of me wishes Big Robot, the developers, would come back to this game one day and add some new stuff. Seriously, this game could be really, really fleshed out even further with some new content. New biomes (the UK's full of diverse places that could easily inspire some new environments!); new types of enemy; new game mechanics (for example, one of the game's many food items is blackberries; but what about having the ability to forage them from bramble bushes rather than just finding them in buildings?); new uses for junk items; new animals to hunt (besides the usual rabbits and pheasants already in the game); these are all just some of the many ideas that could be added to a game of this kind. There used to be a small modding community around this game adding similar things to what I've mentioned, back in the day. If only they were still around!

Nostalgia aside, to sum up, Sir is a definite recommendation from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099102768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1558208236}
review:
I'd give this game a neutral rating if I could.  It isn't BAD, it's just not for me.  Be aware that I couldn't even make it an hour in this game, so maybe it changes dramatically at some point.  I don't know.

This game is incredibly boring to me.  That's the first problem.  Everywhere in the starter area looks exactly the same and it's hard to tell what's what and where you're supposed to be going.  I wandered around (very slowly because this is a slow stealth game.) avoiding robots, found a few pieces of what I'm supposed to be collecting, and died several times.

That's problem two for me.  It's one of those games whose tutorial is "Die repeatedly until you figure out how we expect you to play."  Games are not real life.  They rely on mechanics and leeway to mimic real life, which is how games of all kinds get away with pressing a single button to perform what would be a complex series of actions in real life.  That's why we have tutorials, starter levels, etc.  To teach the player what the expectations and limitations are of the systems the devs use to mimic situations and actions.  Without these, you have to figure out the limitations set by the devs yourself.  For some, this is part of the fun.  For me, it feels like a chore.  Every single game is different.  What might help you in one game (like eating dubious looking food to fill your hunger meter) might kill you in another, or be anywhere in the spectrum between life and death.  Do they tell you that the moldy bread will demolish your hunger/vitality meter?  No.  You learn it the hard way, and once your hunger is at zero you start rapidly dying.  If that's your thing then this is your game.  If that's not your thing, be aware of it.  Everything is learned the hard way.  I don't play games to be punished, I play to relax and enjoy myself so it's a negative for me but I'm aware it's a selling point for others.

The hunger system in general is the third problem.  I played an hour.  I ate more in that hour that I have all day today, and I probably walked more in real life than I did in the game.  No one needs to eat this much.  I understand day and night cycles being faster, and to some extent hunger dropping faster, but it's at a ridiculous level.  I fought the hunger meter more than the robots that were hunting me.  I like the mechanic in some games.  It felt ridiculously overdone and tedious in this game.  It's a constant barrage of "DON'T FOCUS ON THE OBJECTIVE OR AVOIDING FIGHTS OR EXPLORING, YOU'RE GOING TO F***ING DIE IN THE NEXT 15 SECONDS IF YOU DON'T CONSUME ANOTHER WHOLE CHICKEN."  Finding unspoiled food was the primary focus of the hour that I played, and I'm not kidding.

The fourth issue is that there is no way to determine if you actually landed a shot on an enemy.  This goes back to "things that are in place in the game to make up for the lack of detail involved in real life."  I totally get not having a HUD.  It's great in many games.  You have to do things to make up for that lack of HUD though.  There is zero reaction from the enemy, zero sound (which a bullet hitting a robot would be loud.  I shoot steel targets, it makes a noise.) and zero HUD indication that you landed a hit.  You can't have nothing.  I would be fine with minor enemy displacement and a noise in place of a hit marker.  There's nothing.  There being nothing means it's hard to tell if there's an actual projectile and a need to lead targets, or if it's hitscan.  Another system limitation in place by the devs that you have no way of determining outside of repeated experimentation, wasted ammo, and dying a lot while reloading saves.  

A lot of people love this game, and that's because it's not bad.  The actual stealth seemed to work fine, I had no issues with the controls and it runs fine even though my PC is a little older these days.  It's not for me though.  The issues above aren't what I'm into.  If you're like me, the game will be frustrating and boring.  If you're shaking your head at my review and wishing I had left comments turned on so you could yell at me, then honestly you'll probably love it.  As I don't like it at all, I can't recommend it, which is why I do wish there was a neutral option.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989895541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1680956614}
review:
Very smooth running "easy to launch" survival game with a really cool concept behind it! 

Its is a real shame the developers abandoned this baby. One of my favorite "easy to launch" games out there and I really hope that the developers would jump back into this gem soon!

Few notices:

+  There are lots of options to set to your playground, like which biomes do you want to play in or which enemies do you want to see and how early, etc...
+ I think the fight for survival feeling really feels in this game.
+ I just love how the game just begins to go harder and harder by every minute or by every recovered "teleport" piece.
+ Effects and atmosphere is really nice.
+ Lots of enemy types and I love how they slowly introduce themselves while playing the game. Its like the robots are getting smarter against you!
+ replayability 



-/+ Multiplayer! I love when developers add multiplayer to their singleplayer games and its awesome ( Looking at you Hinterlands and The Long dark... Please just do it! ), but it doesn't work with me anymore and it was really unbalanced and dull when I used to play it. I just wish it was just the Singleplayer Hardcore survival with friends, but it had more guns and some other differences.


- I wish there would be more in this game and so does everyone else who loved to play this game. I'm not saying the game is bad or anything, but the fans and the game just needs more love into it. Give it some new equipment, guns, NPC's or Fix the multiplayer to be better etc...

Summary:
Had no issues with performance. Totally worth the money if you want that easy to launch quick survival experience! 

Even tho the game is simple its really fun to play and I enjoyed my time in it and I don't see any reason why I would not jump back to it someday again. I'll give it a 60/100.

Fixed the score rate from the old 1 out of 10 to 1 out of 100 to scale and rank it better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990755148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1449437893}
review:
Another case of a game that could be great if the devs bothered to add content. Most of the buildings are impossible to enter and just glorified chests, filled with useless junk. Literally useless, like, there is literally nothing you can do with the items. They just clutter the storage space.

The game is challenging at first, but you quickly understand how to deal with each enemy type. The game adds a few new ones during the course of the game... but you basically just have to evade them, which doesn't make them very intersting. Especially the last one, which is completely unkillable and therefore isn't even an interesting challenge.

To sum up: boring game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105253580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1217, 'last_played': 1573916470}
review:
A simple yet adorable survival game. Has quite a few options for world generation and game difficulty which is a very nice touch to adjust the overall experience for your pleasure and/or pain. Nice variety of enemies, ranging from watchful huntsmen to angry landlords. A decent selection of worlds, from simple cornfields to industrial neighborhoods. A handful of classes with their own set of items to play with, one can go in with a few bandages and go on a scavanger's hunt OR run in with guns blazing.

10/10 Had a lot of fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197988072846', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1062, 'last_played': 1658360632}
review:
An absolutely fantastic game: Part walking simulator, part stealth-action adventure, part survival sim. The randomly generated landscapes are always very captivating and beautiful, and every so often you find a lonely little hill, or an idyllic little village, or a pleasant little meadow that really pleases the eyes.

And at the same time you are constantly on the move, gathering resources and supplies, feeding and watering yourself to keep surviving, all the while surrounded by roving bands of robotic gunmen, each hoping to put a bullet into you.

Even when loaded up with every weapon in the game, unexpected ambushes are rarely ideal. Instead, most of my kills are carefully planned, sniping from a distance or taking my chances and stealthily closing the distance to utilize the pistol, shotgun or hatchet.

Basically, do you enjoy idyllic country-side scenes? How about stealth-action? How about unpredictable AI enemies? If so, you will enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044125756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1552631062}
review:
This game is really good. Basically it's a FPS/Stealth/Survival. There's not much in the way of crafting like in many survival games. It's more of a pubg type survival. You gear makes you better along with your skills as a player. Both improve as you play. It takes a few minutes to get into it if you start with almost no gear, but you have a nice range of starting options. They're thematic but it also connects to difficulty. For example, you can start as a game warden or a scientist, and they have different starting equipment and perhaps skills (not sure about that point yet). The gentleman starts with pretty much nothing. Once you find a couple of items that can help you transition from defensive stealth style to more offensive rambo style, the game really picks up. The hatchet is amazing. I have a blunderbuss, but haven't needed to shoot it yet. There must be a way to get a rifle or shotgun, but the ones I've found so far have all been broken.

If you're a casual player like me, give it an hour or so before you make any decisions about it. It seems a little kooky since you're a bunch of robots running around eating food, but it really seems to work. =)

This is a very well made game. I haven't encountered any bugs, the gameplay is perfect, and there's a mix of easy and difficult goals that you should skip around until you're ready to take them on. Pick the low hanging fruit first, move around, then pick the stuff that's higher up so to speak. Excellent. The save system is good too. You have a few spots that you can pretty easily get back to and save, so you're not spamming save all the time, nor are you risking too much if you decide to try out something that might be slightly out of your league. 

What more can I say? It's worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096569368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1552338140}
review:
This was incredibly disappointing. I spent three hours running around and didn't find anything worthwhile. Just some food and ammo for weapons I didn't have. Not enough food because I died of starvation at one point. I went to three of the different zones and they are all pretty much the same. The first had some houses. One had more hills. One had some factories.

The main objective seems to be to collect 16 things and bring them back to the starting point. Maybe there is more to it. There are no interiors to the buildings so looting them is just clicking on the door.

It was so empty, it made me think I was missing something.

Terrible execution of what could have been a good game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276246943', 'num_games_owned': 24, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 14786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5889, 'last_played': 1689586634}
review: This is a wonderful game! It's a stealth, shooter, collect, survival game with a very interesting story line. It's like the Metal Gear Solid games only with an 1800's fused with subtle hints of a modern era, robot apocalypse, steampunk twist. I have played the game many times because it's so fun. It's also a customize-able game where you can change the difficulty, robots, your visibility of robots (if they have glowing visors and/or arrows over them), along with land customizing. I would love if there was a second game to dig deeper into the story line. I recommend this game to anyone who like stealth games, and it's able to be a two player game. Two thumbs up to this stealth game with a theme twist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170190173', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1271, 'last_played': 1645246188}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is too good!

I absolutely adore Sir, You Are Being Hunted. This game is art. The feeling that you are never, ever safe always keeps you on edge and keeps you moving. You will never be safe standing still for more than a moment!

The environment in this game is dull, but that is a good thing. The environment around you makes this experience even more creepy and provides that eerie feeling that many modern horror games just can't get right. You do not have knowledge on why the surrounding areas are colourless and bleak, or why you are even being hunted, and it should be kept that way to keep you wondering. Not only is the landscape creepy, but the robots that want to kill you are even creepier! There is a large variety to see and (hopefully) avoid, some of which include grounded, aerial and in water robots. I haven't even mentioned the scariest part yet - the voice in your head. He comes out of nowhere, I swear!

Unfortunately with every great Indie game comes a down side. The character you control is a bit clunky and jumping over things in this game is just about Hell, but I don't think that it renders you too helpless. It is frustrating when you have nowhere else to go other than into a field of grass and you can't make it over the hedges so you get shot a few times until you bleed out. Luckily though, on top of the hedge entrances, this is not a common occurrence.

I will not spoil anything to Sir, You Are Being Hunted, but just wait until you hear those cries of pain. You will want to cry because of them!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005004973', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1550179508}
review:
¬´ Sir, you are being hunted par des robots gentlemen √† moustache arm√©s de fusils. ¬ª

Vous venez d'atterrir au milieu d'un archipel de 5 √Æles, toutes g√©n√©r√©es proc√©duralement. La partie commence syst√©matiquement √† c√¥t√© d'un monolithe aupr√®s duquel vous devrez rapporter 17 fragments √©parpill√©s sur l'archipel. Ces fragments sont n√©cessaires pour vous permettre de vous √©chapper et gagner la partie.

Comme expos√© plus haut, l'archipel est occup√© par des robots v√™tus √† la mode victorienne ; et ceux-ci vous chasseront √† vue. Vous allez donc devoir ruser, faire preuve de discr√©tion autant que d'inventivit√© afin d'explorer toutes les √Æles √† la recherche des fragments. Votre inventaire est limit√© et fonctionne par cases. Chaque objet que vous ramassez occupant une ou plusieurs cases, vous serez r√©guli√®rement contraint de vous d√©lester d'un item au profit d'un autre.
Vous devrez √©galement g√©rer une jauge de faim, qui s'√©l√®ve √† 100 points et d√©croit rapidement, √† raison de 1 point toutes les dix secondes. Cela prendra donc un peu plus de 16 minutes avant que vous ne commenciez √† mourir de faim. Si cela laisse une bonne marge, cela signifie tout de m√™me qu'il vaut mieux garder bonne allure. M√™me si la furtivit√© est primordiale, √©tant donn√© la raret√© des munitions, pas question pour autant de passer trop de temps √† rep√©rer les lieux.

Le c√¥t√© survie est assez basique. Les objets ‚Äì nourriture, munitions et babioles ‚Äì ne se craft pas, mais se r√©cup√®rent presque exclusivement en fouillant les maisons de petits hameaux diss√©min√©s sur l'archipel. Vous ne rentrez pas √† l'int√©rieur des b√¢timents, il vous suffit d'interagir avec les portes pour acc√©der √† leur contenu. Un peu d√©concertante, cette astuce technique qui permet de ne pas avoir √† mod√©liser les int√©rieurs s'int√®gre plut√¥t bien dans le gameplay. En effet, tandis que vous farfouillez dans votre inventaire, vous restez vuln√©rable des chasseurs qui r√¥dent.
Heureusement, vous pouvez d√©goter de nombreux outils pour faire diversion. Jeter une bouteille au loin, faire sonner un r√©veil, allumer un petit train ou jouer de la trompette... c'est un r√©gal que de voir une demi-douzaine de chasseurs s'√©lancer vers le bruit en vous laissant le champ libre.

Par d√©faut, les nombreux chasseurs qui √©cument l'archipel ne seront pas la seule menace. D'autres types d'ennemis, bien plus dangereux, apparaissent en fonction du temps qui passe ou du nombre de fragments que vous avez r√©colt√©. Cependant, la difficult√© est enti√®rement param√©trable, puisque vous pouvez librement ajuster le type et la fr√©quence des ennemis. Cela dit, le r√©glage par d√©faut est assez bien dos√©, je vous recommande donc de ne pas y toucher.

Graphiquement, Sir, you are being hunted est assez basique. Vous ne l'ach√®terez certainement pas pour ses performances techniques. Cependant, si l'exposition de son concept laisse pr√©sager d'un jeu avec une ambiance vraiment singuli√®re, force est de constater que le r√©sultat manque de panache. Les couleurs sont assez ternes, le d√©cor ne comporte rien de sp√©cial ; arbres, champs, cl√¥tures et maisons principalement ; et les robots n'ont finalement pas un caract√®re si marqu√© ‚Äì l'aspect gentlemen british n'√©tant que cosm√©tique.

C'est principalement ce point qui risque de f√¢cher. Sir, you are being hunted est un jeu bien con√ßu, disposant d'un gameplay solide et d'un concept plaisant ; mais il manque de sensation et d'atmosph√®re, en plus d'√™tre lin√©aire dans son d√©roulement (passer d'√Æle en √Æle pour collecter les fragment √† ramener au monolithe). De fait, la lassitude peut poindre plus ou moins rapidement ‚Äì √† ne pas confondre avec l'ennui, car les chasseurs, chiens et montgolfi√®res ne vous laisseront pas vous reposer.
