author: {'steamid': '76561197998623861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1489614929}
review: Overall, this game started with an interesting idea. I don't even remember if I paid full price or caught it in a sale, multiple years ago, but even now I still feel like I've been had. This game lacks and depth to the mechanics whatsoever, there's zero polish and it's long since been abandonded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094925909', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1226, 'last_played': 1630626153}
review:
TL;DR: A great stealth game with good atmosphere that deserves better polish.
This is one of my favourite stealth games, without a doubt. It gets all the basics of good stealth gameplay down pretty well, for sure. It also gives you an incentive to choose stealth, as ammo is scarce and fights can easily turn against you even when you have enough ammo through dogs or traps that immobilise you. One of my absolute favourite aspects of this game is the atmosphere, it's moody and just slightly oppressive while still being beautiful despite the game's presumptive lack of graphics budget. The game is also extremely immerssive, as any first-person stealth game worth its salt should be. I find myself checking my "visibility meter" and listening for the chattering of robots sometimes when I zone out at work. Speaking of the robot chatter, this game has a good sense of humour without it becoming TOO present so that the game is still taken very seriously. I adore this game, and my only notably negative note is that the game's updating days are almost certainly over. Big Robot, if you read this, I will buy up to five copies for five friends. One for each major update that comes out for this game. I'd love this game to be a cult classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034420765', 'num_games_owned': 339, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1518132719}
review:
The game died. If that affects you then put your credit card away.

Otherwise play this with an open mind, if you're not an open kind of person then dont bother. 10 percent of you are.

Played it while it was in Alpha 0.7.5095 and was attached to it. There's a charm in this game that I dont find in other more serious games. Which is why I'm obligated to recommend it.

As anything, best played with friends since there is a multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210678744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1505937371}
review:
Location: Back garden.

People: An associate. 

Activity: Sharing a jinther, just concluded some business. 

Discussion :

"That's nice, that is"

"Yep, I know the c**t that grew it, took his time, treated the wee b*****s properly" 

"It shows" 

"For sure"

"So what ye up tae for the rest o the day?"

"No much, day aff so will prob just chill in front o the computer" 

"Oh aye. Playin anything gid the noo?" 

"Just the usual suspects. Whit aboot you?"

"Same, funnily enough. Chillin wi a few bifters and will stick on a new game tae play"

"Whit ye playin the noo?"

"Got a freebie game called Sir You Are Being Hunted" 

"Hmm. Freebies are usually f*****g dogs**t"

"Tae be fair, that's a pretty f*****g good description" 

"Hah. There'll be a reason it's free, usually is"

"I joined a group on Steam an got it through a wee compo, I wis a winner and got the game fir f**k all. Worth fifteen sheet"

"Here, that disnae sound bad. Free games worth that"

"Aye, I dinnae mind if the games horse dung, if I'd of paid for it then aye, but for free, you know?"

" Is it that bad?"

"Och,  no really. Ye play an English gentleman c**t who is getting hunted by robots of all f*****g things" 

"Robots. The f**k?"

"Aye. Just what I thought. Ye hiv tae sneak aboot and collect bits o some kind of stone device that let's you get oot o the place. The game generates a new environment every playthrough and it is the proper English countryside" 

"They'd need a s**t ton mair than that tae make up for the p**s poor premise"

"Aye. The robots can see ye through bushes. Like they've got f*****g x ray vision"

"So wheres the f*****g point o making it a stealth thing"

"That's something ye'd need to pull the devs up aboot"

"F**k, they dinnae even bother tae mak up proper storylines these days, it just a bare arsed attempt tae tak yer candy"

"I cannae disagree. But mind, in my case, I hander over nae cash" 

"Aye, right enough. Yer no as stupid as ye look then"

"I'll try an twist that roond so I can take it as a compliment" 

"Ye'd need tae twist mair than Chubby Checker tae dae that"

"Nae worries aboot that, he was a big fat c**t anyway"

"True dat. Still got plenty o minge though I bet"

"Aye. Bet he wis still twistin wi girls half his age wi one foot in the grave"

"Lucky b*****d"

author: {'steamid': '76561197970901170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1505874109}
review:
It's not enjoyable to write something negative about something that is quite unique in some ways -- above all, I really enjoy the setting of Sir, You Are Being Hunted. Some complain about the lo-fi graphics, but they make the absolute best of what they are -- and I expect my robots to look "clunky".

Sound is more of a mixed bag. The voice effects are entertaining through and through, and distinct enough that you can quickly tell who is in an area and what they might be doing at that moment. At other times though, I hear rustling grass as  proceed over a stone bridge, or no sound at all in the water. It brings you out of "the moment". I quite enjoy the spooky narrator though, and the music always fits.

Gameplay wise... it turned into a slog by the time I had finished my first three (of five) islands. I didn't try more than one character, but there doesn't seem to be much to gameplay besides avoid-avoid-avoid, which basically means to move slowly in crouch position. Attack is naturally limited because, well, you're the one being hunted, but it would have really helped the game to have a few other creative ways of eliminating the danger of the robots. I managed to get every collectible piece of my matter transmogri-whatever by using glass bottles, alarm clocks, and toy trains. None of them felt all that different.

If it's $9.99 or lower and you live these open-world survival games, give it a try. Unless something truly great is $9.99, then buy that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198307606794', 'num_games_owned': 1736, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1667363261}
review:
This game should be called "Sir, you are being hunted.....by robots with thermal-imaging sensors" LOL

This is a cool idea but it's WAAAAAAAAAY too easy to be spotted. 

I was deep in the foliage and NOTHING even close to me when i hear a gunshot and ALL of them converge on me. 

To me, that's not even "videogame/fantasy" realism.

When you hide in the woods, and it doesn't work, there's something wrong with the game. I did this 20 seconds after starting at the stone and they were all over me and i walked in a crouching position after hitting the wooded area.

I'm good at stealth, i use it in every FPS game i play, so i know how to make it work for me. But for them to find me just out of nowhere....this game needs LOTS of work.

Also the game re-assignment controls don't acknowledge MOUSE2, which tells me they haven't perfected the keyboard reassignment either.

9/11/17 

You may have a different experience with the game but when i can go through some survival games without getting killed, once, i can say that i didn't get spotted because of "me".  I say i'm going to shelf it, for 6 months, and come back and see if it plays any better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971939973', 'num_games_owned': 4592, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1504906050}
review: A wonderfully atmospheric mix of stealth and survival. If the idea of hiding in the long grass in the middle of the English countryside while being stalked by robot aristocrats as you get drunk on sherry appeals to you then you'll probably like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981342364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1656183559}
review:
It's good for a little time waster. The premise is nice, the gameplay's alright (if a little repetitive), and the style is well executed. However, it's a small game (5 tiny islands to find 3 pieces each on), it doesn't take long to complete, and it's not particularly deep.

If you can get it for a couple of quid, go ahead. It's "charming". It's just not substantial.

Edit: changed my review to negative. The developers decided to make an "updated" version of the same game and charge us all for it. Clearly, they aren't interested in maintaining their own games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042732366', 'num_games_owned': 476, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1504727595}
review:
Grandiosa idea, p√©sima ejecuci√≥n.

El dise√±o de los enemigos, la idea de tener que huir y tener cuidado para que no te cacen, mientras poco a poco rapi√±as lo que puedes para sobrevivir y defenderte, manteniendote en tension constante, es algo que no he visto en otros muchos "survivals"

Sin embargo, me encuentro con un juego vacio, digno de un Early Acces a recien estrenar. La jugabilidad es repepetitiva y aburrida, simplemente tienes que caminar, recoger piedras y esconderte (Slender, eres t√∫?), solo he visto 2 enemigos (los cazadores y los globos) y la mayoria del tiempo me veo caminando sin muy bien que hacer.

El sistema de objetos, a pesar de tener gesti√≥n de huecos como los de muchos RPG (me record√≥ mucho a Diablo 2), es un poco inutil, ya que la mayoria de las cosas que encontraras seran basuras que no sirven para nada, literalmente

Me gusta como funciona el sigilo (con una combinaci√≥n de visibilidad y ruido muy mostrado en el HUD), que tiene en cuenta la luz que hay; sin embargo, la IA simplemente correr√° detr√°s tuya sin hacer otra cosa m√°s que disparar, lo cual ahoga mucho la sensaci√≥n de estar en una cacer√≠a a gran escala.

Por √∫ltimo, el mapa tambi√©n es terrible, mon√≥tono a m√°s no poder: Casas por aqu√≠ y all√≠ para conseguir objetos, piedras, arboles y algun que otro edificio en ruinas, y las malditas piedras. Preparate para estar viendo la misma gama de colores continuamente.

En f√≠n, cuando descubr√≠ este juego me emocion√© mucho por la idea, pero despu√©s del jarro de agua fria que ha sido, solo queda esperar al improbable caso de que los desarrolladores vuelvan a trabajar en √©l. El lado bueno es que al menos lo compre en un Humble Bundle, y no gast√© los absurdos 20 euros que cuesta.

PD: El audio 5.1 no funciona, empeorando as√≠ uno de los factores clave en este tipo de juegos.

review: This game is just trying to capitalize off the "survival game wave". It isn't even a survival game, and the stealth is sub par at best. Holy fuck i can't believe this is $20. It is NOT worth it this is a BAD game, and it is NOT worth it. played it twice, once when me and 1 other friend picked it up randomly on a sale, thinking it looked it alright. THE FUCKING VIDEO LIES, IM SEEING MORE CONTENT THEN IS IN THE GAME. the one other time i played it was just now. we won. the game is NOT overwhelmingly hard, infact it is pretty easy. I died once , friend died a  few times, wasnt much of a deal. the premise of the game is to bring  however many stones to 1 location,  if you die, you cant seem to loot your body, and the map seems small with limited resourses, so if you collect all the stuff and die you seem to be left with the bandage and  food item given at start until you can finish. lucky by the time things headed south we only had 1 more stone to get , and we finished this terrible game out of principal. it is shit,HASNT BEEN ADDED TO IN THE 8 MONTHS SINCE IVE OWNED IT AND NEEDS TO BE, ID LOVE TO SEE THE CONCEPT GO FURTHER. DEAD DEVS, SHIT GAME, NOT WORTH 1$ ID SAY.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011244448', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1504508839}
review:
Tl;dr: How could you justify having this game for $19.99...much less even allow on the store page?

I bought this game forever ago, only just recently played a round with a friend.
After the initial glow, the game begins to show more like a coders first project than an actual game. 
Any remark suggesting the AI is interesting is a lie, the gameplay is extremely bare bones. 
You walk around an island avoiding enemies, collecting some stones, and then after collecting all the magic stones, you're rewarded with a "cut scene" in which the camera shakes and your character disappears. 

There is very little content to the game, and absolutely no reason to play it for more than 30 minutes. The devs have long since abandoned it, with the last update being some time in 2015. 

Do not support this kind of gaming culture, in which devs release some shoddy half finished game and cash in.

Don't just take my word for it, look at the reviews and count how many players have more than 1 hour of playtime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000112165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1455223588}
review:
[h1]Details[/h1]
[quote]
[h1]Professor Elemental's song drew me in: this is a harsh steampunk survival game.[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=841429003 
A procedurally-generated FPS survival game where you have to collect items to stage an escape from an island full of murderous robots and hunters. Great fun, and decent A.I. Good luck, sir!
[/quote]
[h1]Summary[/h1]
[quote]
[h1]A great game, packed with atomsphere and real tension. The island is not too big so the strategy remains tight and often bloody.[/h1]
Pros:
- atmospheric, challenging world
- grim and unrelenting survival
- some cool RPG options

Cons:
- while a threat, you can often just run away far too often - though ultimately you must fight!
- not sure if still supported
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1748238549 
[/quote]
[h1]See Also...[/h1]
https://store.steampowered.com/app/322190/

author: {'steamid': '76561198083748092', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 706, 'last_played': 1551399104}
review:
This is a survirval game with the same stile as 7 Days To Die and other but with a nice steampunk look, set in (most probably) Scotland were you are a human being hunted by tobots.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[*] You start with items
[*] Life-restoring items are not hard to find
[*] The enemies can be a treat to you (and not easy to avoid once they spotted you)
[*] Brittish steampunk to stile to feel just in the right time (not too in the futore nor in the past
[*] You can choose you class before starting the game (and get different items for ach class).


[h1] CONS[/h1]
[*] Enemies hard to kill with basic weapons
[*] Not crafting included, meaning most items are useless
[*] Cannot build your own fortess, so you will survirve in the grass
[*] Enemies have too much of good aim so in close encounters they will mostly win (and kill you)
[*] Enemies deal a lot of damage and follow you, so it will be hard at the begining to heal you wounds.

[h1] BUY IT OR NOT? [/h1]

First, the score [(5X2) - 5= 5] . For what is it, a survirval game were, as the title says, you are boing constantly haunted by robots, is a nice game, good controllers, "hard" but not as much if you hide and don't jump face-first into the enemies, [spoiler] the cristals are not to hard to find [/spoiler] , and even is if not a minecraft-esque game, is quite pleasing and fun, I recommend it, but don't spect more than what is it, and if you are still unsure add it to you wish list and wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119857556', 'num_games_owned': 1553, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1503469654}
review: I can't remember when I bought this game, but it's been sitting in my library the past couple years. I can't believe I had never tried it before today, it's so tense and fun. It's like no other game I have ever played before, or maybe it is and i can't think of one. The point is this game is great, I haven't had this much fun with a game in a while. Not even Doom was this much fun for me. I only wish that there was more story to it, or maybe at least more backstory. I recommend this to anyone who likes survival games that are more focused on actually surviving and fighting back against forces while trying to complete objectives.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133057695', 'num_games_owned': 683, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1502904346}
review:
"I've been told that the games A.I is quite well made, so despite the fact that the game seems to be neglected, I decided to finally purchase the game while it's on sale in hopes of playing it with a few friends. But, as it turns out, the multiplayer doesn't even work properly. I spent an entire hour trying to make it work, but to no avail. The forums weren't much help either, as this seems to have been a problem for almost 2 years, and the devs won't change a thing. There is somewhat of a solution but as a consumer I shouldn't have to "fix" my product.

So, here's my two cents: Do not get this game unless you plan on never using multiplayer or if you don't mind an unpolished product that you have to manage yourself. Not even worth 4$."

author: {'steamid': '76561198062765113', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1456678840}
review:
I enjoy this game quite a lot, and I really wish I had played more of it, but I personally find it very hard to just pick back up, but when I do, I really enjoy it.
>One of the only downsides I can think of fro this is that it feels very raw and slightly unpolished in a couple of places, well for some, but I'm not sure on it. 
>Besides that this game is pretty damn cool, it's very unique, it's just difficult enough to make it rewarding, it's packed with style, and it's also very immersive, especially with headphones on.
>The lack of lore or backstory, in my opinion is irrealevant to how enjoyable this game is, it says to you, "here's you're objective, go collect all of these things in this huge map, oh and don't get killed by the robots who are actively trying to find and kill you". Fine by me. 
>If you ever feel like you want a stealth experience where you get hunted by whole load of robots in an old timey way, this is game for you.

EDIT: sidenote, one small negative, probably not worth the price that it is, I would recommend waiting for a sale.

review:
Wonderful game, but dull gameplay that does not let you play anyway else than the intended way.
A nice idea badly implemented. Love the voice and humor, but sadly this is not a movie, it's a game.

Wait for a discount and buy for 2 bucks, but don't expect any real enjoyment but inspiration.

With all that's bad with it... It's an okay game. Far from perfect, but aren't we all?

Dev, lower the price, the game is old now, let people play, 20$ is too damn high, stop selling it only on discounts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086336305', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1593551141}
review:
HOW TO PLAY: HONKING SIMULATOR

1. spawn.
2. hear a random honk from behind you.
3. get run over by a floating metal horse.
4. spawn.
5. crawl slowly through the grass.
6. spot a town.
7. approach stealthily through the woods.
8. hear a beeping sound. turn around and see the hunter behind you.
9. get shot.
10. run until you hear honking, then hide in the grass.
11. let all the honkers pass you.
12. get up and look around.
13. HONK HONK! get run over by a floating metal horse.
14. spawn AGAIN.
15. crawl through grass again.
16. you found a smoking meteorite! now go run past all the honkers.
17. HONK HONK.
18. make it to the center of the map. place the stone.
19. only 1,000,000 more to go!
20. get run over by a floating metal horse.

This game had some very good stealth, very pulse-pounding situations(mostly due to the honking floating horses) and very intense gameplay. But I do not recommend it because it has a lack of content, and it soon becomes a repetition of the last round. If it were at least half the price, it might be worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039305744', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1689542075}
review:
Honestly, I can find some enjoyment in this game....but there is a downside. If you are an avid stealth player you may have trouble, but if you fire even one shot from any weapon you must run. If you don't like to run and if you're like me and you enjoy a good firefight then this game is not for you. Many times I have opened fire on the robots trying to pick up a new weapon or A BAG OF MINTS and each time more and more robots would come after me, always from a blindside and always capable of killing you and if you do by some holy miracle of sweet Jesus manage to kill them, then the rewards you find are very disappointing. A broken shotgun, a piece of meat, a skull, or a BAG OF MINTS?! Killed three robots and got a bag of mint!

In summary, I don't like stealth games very much and wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who doesn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005872436', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1692391357}
review:
This is one of my favourite games. To be sure, it's not always a high-octane experience - there is a lot of walking across barren, quasi-British countryside (looks more like Suffolk than anywhere else). You'll spend a fair amount of time alone, poking around deserted villages. However, I happen to enjoy that kind of atmosphere - and there's plenty of atmosphere.

When things do get dicey though, they really do. While you might stand a fair chance vs 1 or even 2 robots if you've found weaponry enough, more than that and you're taking your life in your hands. The robots are not at all easy to escape once they've got a bead on you and if you do manage to escape them by crawling through a wheat field and then sprinting through some woods you'll really feel like you earned it, not that you just outwitted a dull AI.

So it's much like war - long periods of quiet boringness (which actually really sets up the mood) with sudden bursts of frantic activity. Often you'll find yourself gazing through your binoculars at a collectible guarded by robots, trying to fathom out the best way to outwit or destroy them. You certainly won't succeed by just charging in.

To have any hope of success you'll really need to find the device that detects nearby pieces - you can start with this by default if you choose the right character mode. If you don't, it'll be very hard going until you do. I played this game a lot before that particular feature was added in and the dectector improved the game exponentially. Before that it was perfectly possible to walk right by a piece and miss it, despite the tell-tale smoke and you could spend hours scouring the same island trying to find it.

Not one for you if you're seeking constant thrills then, but if you're feeling like playing a slow-burning and rewarding experience this is an excellent choice.

review: What a boring waste of time. You walk around this barely populated, boring, empty, grassy map looking all over the place for a few tiny little fragment things that are impossible to find. No direction, story or any point. Sometimes there are some buildings, none of which you can go inside, but you can press "f" on them to get mostly junk and then like a can of tuna for your vitality. There are a bunch of robots you can kill to get barely anything besides a broken weapon from. Theres 4 different areas or "biomes" which are differently themed and you can change, but finding the boat for them is hard enough, and theyre really just reskins of the main island, with the same stuff. Thats the entire game. There was patched in MP that no longer works, as game was abandoned right after EA finished. No reason to play this game. 4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198018761823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1595307384}
review:
---The Final Encounter in my game I find the final piece on a Peninsula on the center island with no robots in sight and as I enter the field where the standing stones are, two squads of robots appear on my left and right so i crouch and crawl as far as I can between them before one spots me. then I booked it sprinting across the field jumping over bushes hearing bullets missing me and getting hit by several of them. I make it to the stone and place the final part and the game ends the camera panning out showing a dozen enemies surrounding the stones firing a barrage of bullets and I breath a sigh of relief, I've done it.

What a beautiful way to spend the day. Running in the wide open England countryside. Open fields, birds flying, oh and of course the robotic gentlemen set on turning your head into a trophy. Sir you are being hunted, created by Big Robot Ltd. It combines the tense gameplay of survival games with a cartoon like animated look makes quite a fun combination jumping from humor to horror. The premise is given by your butler Mr.Walters telling the player that the experiment has gone wrong  and you're stuck on the archipelago and that you must collect pieces of the device and bring them back to the standing stones which is where the player spawns in order to return home for dinner and that's all the story you get. Before beginning the game there are options to be chosen before starting your play through. The games starts with your selection of playing as Sir, or Madam purely an aesthetic choice affecting nothing but the dialog spoken to you by Mr.Walters. Once you start a new game then the player chooses their "profession" which is their starting loadout and the choice entirely depends on how difficult you want the game to be. Aristocrat is the default choice and begins your game with no equipment except for some rags and is the ideal choice for players looking for a challenge. Other options vary your equipment greatly such as the inventor loadout which has a scanner which can be used to locate device pieces and Officer loadout which gives the player a revolver and rifle right from the start. Once that's done then the player will be allowed to customize their world by choosing the setting of the other 4 islands you will be going through. The center island at the start of the game will also be the same rural setting every time which are large fields, forests, and small groups of houses but the other 4 islands you'll be visiting can have there biomes changed to Castle- fields with castle ruins that can be used for cover, Industrial- large structures and much more housing making it ripe for finding items but can many more robots walking around , Fens- marshlands with canals and plenty of tall grass to hide in., and Mountains- Massive forests and very large hills with plenty of space to keep away from robots but also few homes. From there the difficulty can be left at the default which does increase over time and based on the progress the player makes but can be adjusted at the start to suit your play style whether you want a casual run or a nerve wracking one. Your mission is to collect all 17 pieces of the device and return them to the center island to the standing stones. They'll be spread all over the 5 islands and your inventory menu will allow you to keep track of how many pieces remain on which islands and how many total you've returned. The only thing giving away their position is the smoke rising from their craters. Also now and again you'll see strange floating sprites going across the landscape to the device pieces and they'll serve as a guide you may see only one or as many as 5 at a given time so it's definitely worth keeping an eye out for them. Once you've spawned in you'll receive some basic instruction of how to play but for the most part the player must figure out how this world works on their own. That is a very poor aspect of the game for various reasons one, in regard to the various enemies that'll be faced of which there are plenty you get no information on them so when the player comes across a new foe they'll be unsure of how to face them and the only way to know is to go head to head with them which is not something you should be doing in a survival game. Speaking of the hunters which are the very first enemy encountered is the most basic and will be most often seen thin, looking dapper and carrying shotguns these machines will be your most common foe. They'll be patrolling the islands usually one or two will be guarding a device piece and they can even roam in packs they have an almost random behavior so it can be tough to tell where one can be moving next or when it'll turn around. Beyond just movement they're random with their behavior with each other  interacting with themselves in random ways sometimes they'll have a short conversation about taxes or show each  other some trophies they may also argue and fight other groups until one side is dead. The way the player will approach these machines will entirely depend on what's present in their inventory if the player has rocks and bottles they can toss them to cause a distraction. If they have weapons they can sneak in close and try to take them on with a hatchet or shotgun. If the player has nothing to use then they may employ a slow stealth approach to avoid being spotted or if they're desperate they can sprint past them and hope they don't land any shots. The way your spotted is dependent on your level of visibility shown on the bottom left corner of your screen if you're running through an open field it'll be pretty easy for the robots to see but if you're crouched in some tall grass unmoving then you're practically invisible. Should the player be damaged in anyway your health will recover slowly provided you have a decent amount of vitality which you keep maintained by constantly eating food that you find in the environment such as mints, cured ham, and a jar marmalade. Scavenging is another big part of the game besides the starting equipment which the player may or may not have scouting structures will be the primary source of where you'll get resources from. Any home or building with doors can be scavenged just go to any door and you can interact with it in order to find supplies none of the doors open so buildings are inaccessible. However each door you go to will have a different set of items so be sure to circle around a house and go to every door to try and find valuables which can be difficult since the drop rate on good items is quite low so trash items will be commonly seen in most places. All the items in game fall into four categories Useful, equipable, dubious, and junk the first two will be the category of food items, tools and weapons. Dubious items are items they may have use or may be harmful to you and junk items are just trash and serve no purpose and should never be in your inventory. For the full review please check it out at TeamAggy.com

author: {'steamid': '76561198043669870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1499114290}
review:
More potential than delivery. What really killed it for me was how slow you move when compared to how big the islands are, especially since the only motive to explore is to find supplies you need to stay alive. One saving grace is that the blue wisp things lead you straight to the plot devices scattered around each island. Subsequent playthroughs offer little to no value on its own merit; you'd need to make your own challenge runs for any value.

Decent for a single playthrough but not enough gameplay diversity to warrant a second run, and definitely not worth the asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076052686', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1683747848}
review:
Sir is one of those games you would either love or hate. This game is so unique that I had a hard time pin-pointing what this game does well.

Sir is a survival stealth game. Your task is to gather all teleporter pieces from five island and gather them into one place. The longer the time passes or the more teleporter pieces you collect, the more foes you will encounter.

First off, I ADORE the soundtrack and the visual design. If it was a war game, it would be boring as hell, but because it goes for highly exaggerated world that looks like other people think Britain looks like it's suprisingly solid. It's great, atmospheric and overall good design. However if you don't like depressing grim colors for 2 hours of gameplay on one save, this isn't the game for you, cause it might look dull to some (this comes from a guy who plays cute games with tons of colours.)

The stealth in this game is very solid. If you get out from a predicament somehow, it really feels like it was your doing. The game is punishing, but just enough that you don't want to give up. Each hour of gameplay gives you more to work with.

There are two features that were a real lifesaver for me. Custom world generation and Multiplayer! With the first one, you can create much more interesting worlds with more decorations and stuff than the default generators, however you need to be quite careful with sliders. The second feature is hit or miss. There aren't many servers (but I host one in my free time), so you might not encounter as many players. If you do, you're in for a great ride. Basically you have to escape the island competing with other players in doing the same. There's PvP, loot and trading! Find a friend, have a battle or form an alliance.

What are the flaws? This game feels a bit incomplete, but every now and then I encounter a new item that got me really excited thanks to custom world generation. For some reason the default one isn't so generous with them. When I found a Thingometer and a Mysterious Talisman, they really enchanced the game.

World generation can be really poor too. Unless you're playing on custom generated worlds, they might be really boring. I would like this game to support modding, so I can add more structures to spawn, more items to create and more enemies to fight! I'm a modder type of guy.

Set up a server, be patient and you'll be rewarded for it. However for the standard price it's not worth it. I would wait for a sale below -50% to really make it worth your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994562468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1546974887}
review:
An interesting game and game design. The graphics are not the best you will ever see, but entertaining and enjoyable anyway and while they are quite deadly, the hunters are an amusing lot to watch and listen to.
There is a lot of backwards and forwards in this game as you hunt from island to island, juggling your bulging inventory to allow for all the kit you are going to need.
Despite feeling a little "Safe" when you first start, this soon fades as you realise that you are in serious danger almost all of the time and you will need to develop some strategies to avoid the hunters without being trapped against the coastline of one of the islands.
If you like the idea of a game where you are constantly being hunted and yet must stop for long enough to cook some food to survive (and draw the hunters with the smoke) then you will enjoy this. Well worth the effort of getting into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080331553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1497814231}
review:
When I bought the game in 2013 for 13.99‚Ç¨, I thought I did something really well. But I let it sleep in my library for a long time after I had played it and stopped after getting shot for the first time. I can¬¥t remember why I was so mad but maybe it was the right reaction to the game¬¥s structure. In 'Sir, You Are Being Hunted' you are to choose between these classes at the beginning: 'The Aristocrat' , 'The Gamekeeper', 'The Inventor',' The Officer', 'The Cook' , 'The Artist' and 'The Old Soak'. All these classes differ in terms of equipment but as far as I know don¬¥t change anything else (I only tried The Officer so don¬¥t believe me here).  After that you are introduced to the game you are going to play if you are willing to. You are told to find meteorites to start a Stonehenge-like machine which is located on the central island and the only way to complete the game at the same time. There are 17 of these stones (which is a weird number to me). You are to find them on 5 islands (central, North, South, East and West). While finding them you are hunted by robots. Everything is embellished with great British Humor. At the same time you have to take care of your Vitality but Health and Visibility too. From time to time you will be realizing that there are different categories of items which might be amusing you. Some are just junk, some are useful and others are something between junk and useful (can¬¥t describe them). At the beginning robots might feel like something rare. But the more meteorites you collect the more robots spawn and the more difficult it gets. What problems does that have? Well‚Ä¶at the beginning running away is quite easy but the stealth genre is felt more and more from time to time. The difficulty is how not to be seen or heard: robots seem to be spawning next to you and can detect you even if they are far away and should not. But their detection area is really unstable and is nothing that you can trust.  The movement is really fine and the options are easy to understand. So is the navigation. The next to talk about are the graphics. They are not good‚Ä¶well that is still a polite way of describing them. I took a screenshot that shows a sunset or sunrise (not sure anymore). This is still the best you can find but not what you¬¥d expect as beautiful for a game of 2013.  One thing I almost forgot, the mutliplayer mode is not working at all. However these reasons still would not make deny a recommendation for that game. To sum it up I actually liked playing it. But 20‚Ç¨ as a price for a game that can be completed within 5 hours? [B]Just: no way![/b] 

The promised screenshot (Sunset/Sunrise): http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=948124540

The end: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=948124729

review: This is one of those games that "could" have been great. It started out strong and showed promise but as soon as the developers could stamp 1.0 on it they abandoned it to work on another project. It is currently a buggy mess with some stiched on multiplayer support. If you like the concept and want to sneak around avoiding robots in single player or with friends and dont care about the bugs then give it a try. If you want a game that has developers who fix bugs and improve their game over time, I can't recommended this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128465613', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1677126225}
review: Although I originally got this game for the Singleplayer aspect, I have found the best part to be the Multiplayer. This is a game that can create very memorable exchanges as I have found while playing. It can be great fun teaming up with a friend or so and moving through towns and ambushing robots, or having full-blown shoot outs in towns once you've got some weapons. It also lets you use your creative side to solve problems, like using all the tools you have at your disposal to survive. All in all, I would recommend this game primarily for the Multiplayer aspect, however the Singleplayer is entertaining as well if you are patient enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314193820', 'num_games_owned': 2114, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1496667677}
review:
Really? 20 euros for this?

Crappy gun handling, horrible overall gameplay mechanics, ugly graphics, unimpressive concept, performance issues even on high-end machines (regarding shadows and postprocessing), certain world/save crashes and the list goes on....

They said - "Now With Multiplayer!" Really? Because there are only 4 multiplayer servers that are always locked...

I was looking for a nice survival experience, but haven't found it in this game.

At this price, looking for survival titles, you can either:

- add 3 more euros for "7 Days to Die"

OR

- [b]at the same price[/b] you have games like "Rust", "H1Z1" or "Miscreated"

OR

- 5 euros [b]cheaper[/b], "The Forest", "Miasmata" (which is also horrible, yet it's cheaper at least) and the list goes on...

Come on "Big Robot Ltd"...seriously?

author: {'steamid': '76561197970602587', 'num_games_owned': 6364, 'num_reviews': 3660, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1041, 'last_played': 1496024050}
review:
https://youtu.be/PSQ80QGTU9A

Collecting meteor fragments in the English country side while avoiding killer robots is a solid setting for this stealth survival experience.  Weapons are scare which makes every action carry a lot of weight.

There are some rough spots with the UX that would be improved by having some aim assist on thrown objects or a drop 'junk' command for the inventory.  These additions would ease the experience slightly but the improved quality of life would be worth the exchange.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062505138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1692497843}
review: I really wanted to like this game. The quirky British humor, the (slightly) steampunk feel, and the overall concept seemed great. The randomly generated maps at first seemed cool until you realize it results in low-poly, meaningless landscapes with aimlessly populated AI and rewards. The only way to survive in the game is to move at a snail's pace as once you are spotted you can start the countdown on how long until your dead. That means you're crawling across a vast, pointless, kind of ugly, computer-generated map looking for glowing lego pieces. There are only a handful of tactics all basically variations on the classic 'throw the bottle--distract the bad guys.‚Äù As many people have pointed out it‚Äôs an unfinished game and $20 is too much for a game that feels like a demo. In my attempt to give it a fair go I went over the 2-hour return limit. I wish I‚Äôd stopped sooner. IMO the only way this game would be enjoyable is if you are in a very 'altered-state', or very bored with A LOT of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017392185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1419942615}
review:
Het idee achter dit spel is interessant en het spel ziet er mooi uit. De eerste keer dat je achterna wordt gezeten door de moordlustige robots en je tenauwernood kunt ontkomen, zul je niet gauw vergeten. Jammer genoeg wordt het spel al snel repetitief. Er zijn een aantal problemen die ervoor zorgen dat ik het spel niet kan aanbevelen:
- te weinig mogelijkheden om te sluipen door willekeurige plaatsing van voorwerpen in de spelwereld
- te weinig nuttige voorwerpen in de gebouwen die je onderzoekt 
- managen van je inventaris is erg jaren 90 en niet leuk, biedt geen meerwaarde
- je kunt gebouwen niet in gaan, schuilen of op krachten komen is dus niet mogelijk
- te weinig verhaal, te weinig systemen om de speler te boeien
Het spel bestaat uit het verzamelen van stukken van een obelisk, deze stukken naar de restanten van de obelisk brengen, zodat deze wordt hersteld en een poort opent naar het volgende eiland. Tijdens de zoektocht naar de stukken van de obelisk wordt je gehinderd door zwaar bewapende robots die het eiland bewaken en je aanvallen als ze je zien of horen. Je kunt bij de start van het spel kiezen uit verschillende personages, ieder met een beperkt aantal voorwerpen in zijn of haar inventaris. Er zijn voorwerpen waarmee je de robots tijdelijk kunt afleiden (kookwekker), voorwerpen waarmee je een beetje gezondheid kunt herstellen (voedsel) en wapens waarmee je je kunt verdedigen. Maar de nadruk ligt op sluipen, niet op schieten. Jammer genoeg worden de eilanden waarop het spel zich afspeelt willekeurig gegenereerd (je kunt een aantal variabelen instellen, zoals de hoeveelheid bomen, huizen enz.). Hierdoor ontstaan er grote open vlaktes waar je onherroepelijk wordt gezien en muren en hagen waarachter je je kunt verstoppen op plekken dat je er niets aan hebt. Dat maakt het soms bijna onmogelijk om ongezien langs de robots te komen. Als je eindelijk een paar verlaten huizen hebt ontdekt, komt de volgende teleurstelling. Huizen zijn er slechts voor de show, het zijn in feite grote voorraadkasten. Maar dan wel lege voorraadkasten. Want in de meeste gebouwen vind je niets dan een dode rat en beschimmeld brood. Ik snap best dat de ontwikkelaars het spel niet te eenvoudig wilden maken, maar dit is het andere uiterste. Na anderhalf uur spelen is het heel normaal dat je misschien twee dozijn gebouwen bent tegengekomen en daarbij slechts een handvol (hooguit vijf) nuttige voorwerpen hebt gevonden. Dat maakt je opties om robots af te leiden of aan te vallen nog kleiner dan ze al waren. Na twee uur spelen had ik het dan ook gezien met dit spel. Als er meer mogelijkheden waren geweest om je te verschuilen en je meer nuttige voorwerpen tot je beschikking had om de robots mee af te leiden, was het nog een interessant spel geweest. Maar een sluipspel zonder iets om je achter of in te verstoppen en zonder voldoende voorwerpen waarmee je je tegenstanders om de tuin kunt leiden, is gewoon niet leuk.

author: {'steamid': '76561198178600505', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1520659710}
review:
I don't get why the overall score on Steam for this game are so high. I'm not one to bash a game, but this game is not that great. It has a great concept, but it's pretty boring overall. It took me 7 hours to beat, and for probably 3-4 of those hours there was almost literally nothing happening. I was just wandering around looking for the items needed to progress and not finding them while completely avoiding enemy patrols (there's no reason to go anywhere near them and they are very easy to avoid). When you are forced into a confrontation, such as needing to deal with guards around an object you need, you simply distract them with an alarm clock or a wind up toy, then walk up and grab what you need. Or later, if you find weapons, you can just kill them with no problem at all. You can also escape from enemy patrols by simply running away. Once I figured this out, I would just run constantly; it didn't even matter anymore if I was seen.

The objects you need to find to complete the scenario are really hard to find... until you realize there are a few ways to see where they are, and then you don't have to do any exploring at all, you just walk straight over to them. Several of the islands I explored took me 90 mins. to 2 hours to complete, but once I realized a good way to find the objects you need, I completed the last two islands in like 15 mins. each, which was very anticlimatic. I didn't explore those islands at all...

There are a few good moments here and there, like a chuckle from the writing, encountering new and creepy enemies, and a few tense standoffs with enemies, but the sheer amount of hours where nothing at all is happening really drag things down, as do the anti-climatic encounters with easily killed, tricked, or out ran guards. I heard that the devs worked hard on the sound design, and that does show in the sound effects. Pretty unsatisifying overall, which is a shame, as a game with this exact concept and set-up could be really cool if done right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158379873', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3195, 'last_played': 1651584806}
review:
Sir, you are being hunted, is overall pretty good game. It has the theme of british fox hunt, which makes it quite unique and standing out from nowadays generic trash. The base gameplay mechanics are clear and semi easily to get familiar with, but mastering takes time. While fighting is quite easy, it still offers a challenge to win against several opponents, which is what i prefer, to not make things so easy. However, there is some flaws too. The gameplay gets a bit too familiar in few games. The developers should consider adding more content to the game. Simple item spawnrate adjusters could add a lot to the game. So thats a big - for devs! Other thing is multiplayer. I actually enjoyed it a lot. However, the winning condition is unclear. They should chance winning conditions, so that there is actually point to compete against each other and team with others. Well, i guess its not a problem anymore since we don't have enough players in multiplayer servers. Best bet is to take few friends and playing your own game.

Sincerely,
Still waiting for new updates....

author: {'steamid': '76561198030199097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1492359574}
review:
I¬¥ve spent more than 1,5 hours ingame trying to get multiplayer to work. 
It¬¥s probably a fun game singleplayer and it really looks fun in multiplayer on youtube. But...
Don¬¥t sell games over steam that you can¬¥t play through steamworks. Plug and Play should be standard. 
I¬¥ve tried all the stuff the developers have said is known to cause problems. Port forwarding, firewall issues etc. 
A lot of people have posted similar problems on their discussionforums. And I get that it might be something on my end but it¬¥s weird that I have 50+ multiplayer games on Steam that works flawlessly but this doesn¬¥t. And we were several friends who we¬¥re coming togheter for a Lan-weekend who I talked into buying it and Neither have been able to see any public servers either here nor at home.  
At this point I¬¥m just saying fuck it. I¬¥ll reimburse my friends with some pizza. It¬¥s not like I spent a fortune on the game. The real waste was our time trying to get it to work.

I might still try the game more in singleplayer. But yeah. Dissapointed.

Edit: Hamachi did not solve it. Took another hour to fix. It was fun in multiplayer but I still don¬¥t think that you should need to spend 2h+ on fixing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131329298', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1631398879}
review:
‚ÄúIt's a great game that will take up an afternoon, but for 20 bucks? At its current state, which it will most likely have forever, it is worth 5 dollars, there is just not enough content to justify such a price.‚Äù

I liked this game a lot, It took me just less than 4 hours beat, and I enjoyed every minute. I do think it is telling that nobody who reviewed this game seems to have more than 20 hours. Overall the game reminded me of the excellent game ‚ÄúUndying‚Äù 

The Story

There is not much to the story but it is there. It starts you off with a storyboard, which makes little sense. You can find books, letters and plaques, with a few hints to the story. Nothing is really clear, other than that the stonehenge can weaken the barriers to other worlds -don‚Äôt say it's magic-. I don't think it is very fitting, however. 

The Graphics
People complain about the graphics in this, and they are not very realistic. I think they are nice and stylised and reminded me much of ‚Äúundying‚Äù. There is fog, and it‚Äôs all not very colourful, but I think the graphics well suit the game. There was graphical errors, but these had little effect and I think it is because it is randomly generated. the robots and houses and such look appealing, the ground and the rocks could use some work. There is fog, and I can see some people being bothered by that, however you can still make out things in the distance clearly.

The Gameplay
There are a few weapons(pistol, shotgun, rifle, blunderbuss, axe) which is a good thing, as inventory management is a big thing, and there is little space for many weapons and an effective load of ammo. Each has a defined purpose, and there is nothing else fitting that could be added and not feel unnecessary. It took me awhile to get used to combat, as the sensitivity was strange at all levels. New items don‚Äôt spawn in, which mean you can‚Äôt play around in one place too long. Some enemies are unkillable, and over all it feels like you are meant to avoid all enemies. Despite being open world and randomly generated, it has low replayability. I blame this on the fact it has only one mode, a scavenger hunt .

The game starts you off the center island, with an equal in size island to the north, east, south and west of you which you can go to at anytime by finding a dock in the direction of the island you want to go to. The goal is to find 20 or something gems, which you need to put into the stonehenge to win. These gems are scattered around the islands. There are number of enemy types that randomly patrol the islands, the more gems you return, the more enemies will spawn. There are towns and other building with loot scattered around the islands. Depending on the class you can start with almost nothing, but with luck you can have a ton of good loot fast. You can store found loot in the buildings without fear of them despawning. It took me only a hour or so to realise you can also stash gems in buildings, so the game does not spawn in more enemies. You can find maps, which you can use to mark 3 spots. 3 spots is more than enough, as it allows you to mark 2 towns where you stashed goodies and a final one for the dock. Your position appears on the map, so navigation with one is real easy. The gems produce smoke which can be seen from far away, but even then there was some frustrating times where I could not find the final gem on an island. Once a robot patrol finds a gem, 2 of them, and a robot dog guard it. Only the first and most basic robot hunters guard gems, and so it is not hard to just shoot them and take the gem. Gems are normally far off the beaten path, so robot patrols will to too long to arrive if you move fast. Alternatively you can throw a clock or bottle as a distraction, but this is far harder to pull off and more risky in my mind than violence. The fact only basic robots guard means you only have to encounter these basic robots, as you can just hide from the other, perhaps cooler types. It was easy for me in the final hours of this game, to make a safe point and stash near the dock of an island, and then find and retrieve the gems with ammo to spare.   

Mechanics
 	-Stealth
               Not like most games, there is no sneaking up behind people and stabbing them in the neck or what not (there is no one hit melee). Rather you are more like a powerless convict running from police. Areas are randomly patrolled, and there are a few options of distracting enemies. This is hard to do, and sometimes it feels just easier to kill them. The game does not pause when you loot, so distractions are even worse. There is bunch of guarded items you need to collect, I think only 2 of which I used a distraction. Some other reviewer said this game was more like guerrilla warfare, you hide, shoot a few shots, pick something up then run away. 

	-Combat 
	  Once you get used to it, it feels good. The health system is very forgiving, but once you run out of rags(which do not respawn) to bandage, you are dead. Eating food frequently will allow to regain health. The guns are powerful, but lack range, even for the sniper. Ammo and guns are rare, yet almost necessary. There is an ADS function that greatly improves damage and accuracy. Going in guns blazing never really works even on small groups later in the game, and if you chose a real class, you will only have a gun by then. If there is something you really want, you can try to sneak up to it, distract the guards or pick one off, hide, pick another one off, hide‚Ä¶. It is repetitive, but also fun.

 	-Inventory
You can keep thing in homes without them despawning, so you are encouraged to keep caches of food and ammo in easy to reach spots. Nothing knew spawns in, yet you can discard things, so watch out. There are 3 types of loot: junk, dubious and useable. Junk does nothing, dubious hurts your hunger when used, and useable is what you want. I at first wondered why there was useless items, but I figure it is to keep you looting and exposed longer. People complain about not being able to go in homes, yet being able to enter them would ruin the game. It is never worth it to kill every one guarding lootables, so you need to sneak up on them, and loot what you can quickly before you are seen, to be able to enter the homes would break this. Judging whether it is worth the risk is one of the biggest aspects about this game. 

Horror
The game was unconventionally scary just like its stealth. It is ‚Äúyou hide behind a stone wall as a clunky robot flies past, wondering to yourself if it will see you‚Äù kind of scary, no jump scares or anything. The point of the game is to avoid enemies, you never really encounter these scary enemies up close, limiting the thrill of the game. I think more horror would have improved this game. 

Other Notes
Over all it is a beautiful game, I just love to see a line of hunters march in a line through the long grass. However it is kind of niche, and the novelty of it wears off once you finish your first play thru. There is just not enough game for it to be worth 20$. I encountered no bugs, and it felt finished.  It took me 4 hours to beat it, and I was not rushing. The Devs claim the game has replayability do to its randomness, however when the game is so straightforward do to its one goal and limited supplies, that replayability is questionable. The is no other modes. There is starting classes, and that's all to make each game different, other than the map not being the same. This game is dying for more modes. It's a great game that will take up an afternoon, but for 20 bucks? At its current state, which it will most likely have forever, it is worth 5 dollars, there is just not enough content to justify such a price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094030129', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1487243947}
review:
General Opinion: 
Overall Experience Rating:
6/10
AI Design:
8/10
AI Mechanics:
3.5
Stealth Mechanics:
2/10
Roleplay:
8/10
Creativity:
8.5/10
Graphics:
5/10
Overall Immersiveness:
4/10


Pros: Different Characters with Unique abilities, can generate your own maps, You can change the difficulties (I love a good challenge so my first game was to max spawn everything. Took 2 steps toward the giant rune better the airballoons gunned me down lol!) The concept is extremely innovative. The baddies were unique, tough, frightening, and therefore satisfying to kill!, I approve of the airballoon. The atmosphere was excellent! And the choice between satiating hunger vs. vigor (health) was well done: Eat an uncooked rat: lose 20 health, rather than die from hunger. Life is all about balance.

Cons:
No Interiors.
Very limited amount of items 
not a lot of craftables

My BIGGEST problem was that:
The stealth system sucks: PLEASE READ BELOW before immediately dismissing my argument:

Being clever at hiding is not a viable option:
- I've played dozens of games of man-hunt, hide and go seek, created successful ambushes. I'm an excellent seeker, I think both in and outside the box. As a runner/hider In real life: I've hidden right under people's noses as long as I remembered to:
a) be aware of my surroundings 
b) be deceptive
c) remain quiet, and well-hidden, 
d) think both inside AND outside the both (i.e don't hide under the car, stand still feet hidden behind the tires, be robust and silently maneuver. Also, don't go for the Tall car shrouded in darkness, Go for a small car in a BRIGHTLY lit area. Find a ladder? Climb up and either take up with you, or place it opposite side of the house of your location. Many a times I've been asked: "How the hell did you get up there!?

- In reality: I've won almost every hide and go seek type games using methods mentioned above.
Don't believe me? Fine I bet you're the dumbass that traps yourself in the darkest room with no escape route. Hides "Behind the velvet curtains" and my personal favorite: "under a pile of clothes"/"Buried under leaves." Very obvious. 

Here are a few examples using a,b, c, and d.
1) simply hide behind any door, DO NOT CLOSE IT!!!, instead: squish yourself behind the middle of the door as open and inviting as possible so your pal won't slam you in the face by openng the door): the seeker walks in, checks the closet, the chest, under the bed, piles of clothes, the entire bathroom then leaves.
2) flattened myself as close as possible to the front of the couch., seeker walked straight past me to "check behind the TV set, when he got there, I volted over the couch and touched base.
3) hid behind a small car right across from the seeker, feet tucked in behind the car tires. Fool thought I'd hide behind the TALLER cars because they had more cover. While he was checking under the wrong cars, I won.
4) Hid on the opposite side of a wall like a ninja, sitting comfortably on a slab of concrete. The gaem had no base so I just chilled there for 30 minutes listening to the footsteps off my budies being chased, running back and forth, on the other side. Finally the seeker caled it quits (Ironically right behind me!) and gave him a good scare.

So you see, that is why the stealth system is unimmersive and crap. Another Argument of mine is thus: The AI CLEARLY do not have Heat Sensors, as you can still sneak up on them and whack the shit out of them with a bat. But when detected, it doesn't matter that they last saw you running in a completely different direction, that you ran 100 meters from them and are virtually invisible and far away in giant corn stalks and wheat fields, or hell, hiding in a tree. They magically gain the sixth sense. but ONLY if you trigger them first! 

The only alternative to survive when out gunned in this game is to run, far, far, away. That shows laziness on the creators' part for the AI

And Yes, I know this is just a game, but I play stealth games because I enjoy using wit, deception, and innovation. This game surely was innovative, but the broken stealth, and the bi-polar AI ruined it.

P.S I hope the authors see this and agree with some of my arguments. Sadly, I cannot recommend a game where it's main feature: Stealth is broken.

author: {'steamid': '76561198282643809', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1510417290}
review:
This is one of those games where the concept is quite simple, but it more than makes up the sum of its parts. It's surprisingly tense crouching in a bush waiting for those robots to just narrowly walk by you, and is only better in multiplayer. This makes the excitement 10 times better as you hear your fellow sir or madam call out for help across the map, just for you to realise that there is a whole robot army between you and your friend.

In short, play it in multiplayer.

sir/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198209707959', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1480404091}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028175158', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1632192912}
review:
This game is really fun, really neat concept, but its not done yet. Straight up not finished, needs another few months of polish, make the the gun play smoother, less graphical oddities, flesh out some of the interactions (campfires are super unfinished, theres no cooking UI or anything) They left some of the enemies out of multiplayer, and technically there is only a competetive mode, but larping co-op is still possible. It would be totally worth the 20$ they ask for it if they pushed it as far as they wanted. 

Either the game devs weren't able to continue work on this project, due to engine limitation, lack of funding or lack of want. Or they chose not to work on it, and pursue other projects with games that are very similar in premise and game play. 

They've gone on to make two more "Survival/Action" Games and those are also, more or less, un polished and not living up to their full potential.

This survival game is unique and lures you in with its premise and English theme. The sound design is good and the core game play is fairly simple.

 

Its just a shame, its so close to being something really awesome, but if this is how the devs make a title; unfinished, then im not going to be getting any other titles they've developed.


3/6

author: {'steamid': '76561198088800360', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1643753864}
review:
This game is best game I have ever played [u] that has been made with unity. [/u] I like the style of the graphics, even that it wasnt the best I've seen. Controls are very easy to learn. One thing I would like is crafting. There is only cooking [spoiler] and drinking alcohol obtains you a emty glass to throw... [/spoiler] I think that axe is better than using gun when it comes to destroying robots. If have the trombon (or how its written) you can lure them and them just give them two chop with your axe and robot is dead. Maybe in Multiplayer could be shooting highly effective if all players have enough ammo. At all its is maybe better to just dont kill them if its possible. Speaking about not killing, stealth is prety simple here, you have little circle with eye and it shows you how much are you visible. Sometimes I wished there was quick saving but it would make the game too easy. You can only save at stone monument (your task is to find all mystical fragments that are scattered around 5 island) and boats that are the only way to get to another islands. one negative is that it is short, I completed it in 5 hours, But if it would be longer it would get repetetive. It cost alot but if you buy this game at sale its not so bad.

[h1] When I write down + and - [/h1] 

[b] plus [/b]

controls
stealth
humor
not too easy but not too hard
number of variouse enemies

[b] minus [/b]

its short 
small number of weapons...
price 
not much of crafting

Well I give it 75/100% 

[b] Have a nice day [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198085679005', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1511528377}
review:
First of all, I want to say, that I am fan of Survival games, I really tried to enjoy this game, but it seems like I couldn't. 

I must point out, that idea is interesting, but I think game is poorly executed.

Pros:
+ Interesting take on Survival genre.
+ British stuff.
+ Sounds are fine.
+ Creepy atmosphere

Cons:
- Can't go inside houses.
- I found robots to be boring.
- Too many items that are useless.

In the end, It is just my opinion and depends on a person. If I didn't like it, you might do. Just get it on sale and  if you dislike it, you can always refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097295942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1682820645}
review:
This game is both hillarious and terrifying. 
Hillarious Parts:
-British Hunter Robots
Terrifying Parts:
-Being Hunted By British Hunting Robots

Seriously, if you're used to just ducking into the shadows or under a cardboard box to hide after making a big noise, you're in for a rude awakening. This isn't MGS or Dishonored; these guys are a bit smarter, and you're a lot weaker.

If you love the nervous thrill of a stealth game, this is a great pick.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980145954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482811798}
review: I played this game for a few hours, and it plays smoothly, but there's just not that much to it. After playing it for 30 minutes, I feel like I already understand exactly what to do to beat the game. The robots don't have much character, and they don't seem to be very smart either. You can't really kill them, but it never feels like you need to since even if you get spotted, you can just run away for a minute or 2, and your health will regnerate over time before your next attempt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048101201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1482775422}
review:
This is one of those rare games where you really feel like you're in a world, not unlike what you'd experience in an Elder Scrolls game. A combination of the first-person perspective, the AI-driven enemy behavior, the atmospheric art and soundscape, the stealth mechanics, and the fact that almost everything in the world has some kind of purpose really made me feel like I was on that terrible little set of islands running from robots. It's immersive and tense, and most of the time playing on default settings I felt like there was just enough give for me to scrabble my way through the game to victory.

It's not a perfect game - I'm not sure what the purpose of junk items is (to scare you off the Take All button when looting, I assume?), the highly restrictive savepoints can be frustrating, some of the controls could be explained a bit more clearly (like secondary functions and inventory shortcuts), but overall Sir, You Are Being Hunted really delivers on what it needs to, and the plethora of setup options means that everyone should be able to tailor the experience to their level fairly easily.

review:
I have been playing this game since I had early KickStarter access, have spent a lot of time with it.  Have only played single player. 
 
I really like the game.  It's fun.   Stealth focused, combat is deadly and extremely hazardous to your health, and you need to be very careful of how you approach and initiate combat (it can be the difference between life and death ‚Ä¶ unless you're good at just getting really lucky).  Luckily you are ridiculously good at hiding and sneaking.  But the robots can also be good at searching, and they have robot dogs.  And search balloons.  But, fortunately, the robots all seem to like talking and singing to themselves.  And the ‚Äúlawmen‚Äù aren't out to get you ‚Ä¶ unless they see you stealing ‚Ä¶ 
 
It's fun.  It has a nice theme.  It's a fun stealth/FPS game.  It's intense, and challenging.

Update: Got stuck on the side of a hill with no way out but down. The robo kracken has decided to try and hit me with its tentacle if I go any lower. The only way to stay alive is not to play. If I don't make it out alive I leave my train to my wife and children.

11/10 would get trapped on a hill again.
