author: {'steamid': '76561198003690702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1246, 'last_played': 1585235872}
review:
The game was a good concept in some respects, but never felt finished in the end.  I think the price point is about fair, but the content is still lacking and the islands that you play on are very small compared to what should have been offered.  

The game might be fun for a short while, but it becomes repetitive rather quickly.  If you enjoy a quirky title that offers a few hours of fresh perspective and a few laughs, then this might be a decent pickup.  For me, however, this particular title just didn't do much for me.  It had plenty of potential at one point, but honestly it felt abandoned at some point, just like so many other early access titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128175177', 'num_games_owned': 646, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1705778796}
review:
Good game. good stealth system and nice graphics.
There are a few of problems with this game:
- saving system is terrible, quicksaves would be a really cool update
- please add stealth kill. Approaching a hunter from behind is alrady really difficult and needing two hits to kill it makes no sense
- WTF?!?! Houses are everywhere but you can't go inside them

author: {'steamid': '76561198013556585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 891, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1441743098}
review:
This game is everything you want in a survival style game! The npc's are annoying with their paths and sighting abilities. The erray of enemies is wonderful.

The athmospher the game creates keeps you on your toes and listening for any signs of the ol' chaps that are after you. You get so immersed in the environment that you start to believe that, you sir, are indeed being hunted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024737303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1702878501}
review: FPS set in a gothic Victorian England conuntryside... until you realize its hunting season... and the season is for you. Simplestic game play but challenging. Where stealth and pacifism pays off as much as a successful assult on the loot you are looking for. When you feel confident the Robots up the ante and even when the prey thinks it is safe it comes to realize... No... Sir, You Are Being Hunted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006411483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1435488336}
review:
Sir, you are well designed and fairly entertaining for people who like a little solo stealth-and-adventure game.

However madam, you are lacking in content beyond that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112189890', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1440474319}
review: The game was fun and had quite a few features that weren't in the trailer, but after getting a few of the objectives completed [returning quite a few stones to a discount Stone Hedge is the main objective, every few stones spawn more enemies and enemy types], the game got too hard. Then again, I'm not the best at stealth OR survival. Overall the game was a solid 7/10, but the fact that you can't change the difficulty on the Robot's AI, makes the game hard AF. Plus from what I found, the traps aren't actually lethal, so you end up capturing a robot with a bear trap, and then you have to finish the robot yourself which makes TOO MUCH NOISE, WHICH ALERTS ALL NEARBY ROBOTS TO COME AND KILL YOU. But the game's pretty good overall, but I guess you can say this game just wasn't my *ahem* 'cup of t-[PUN REMOVED]'

author: {'steamid': '76561198088658219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1691, 'last_played': 1617320986}
review:
Sir is an excellent example of how a short game can be very memorable and very good. The game is a survival-stealth title that features British Robots and an overall British theme. Your first playthrough will be full of tense moments and take about 7-10 hours, though anyone accustomed to stealth games may have much more favorable results. As with most survival games you need to consume food and avoid skirmishes with your robotic rivals. If you're interest is lessened by screenshots featuring guns have no fear, you will never become an overpowered thriving individual able to engage 10 robots at once. Using guns will send robots in your vacinity charging towards you. Reload times are long and the clips are very small.  Killing robots is a big component of the game, but you have to use hit and hide tactics. Very often you have to investigate a house's defences before you're able to make a move. You'll need to use distractions, traps and a few choice weapons to outwit the robots. Gameplay is very enjoyable, allbeit very short.
There are a few issues that can detract from your experiance however: death, poorly placed device parts and an invincible enemy. The game uses a save point system and there are five spots to save your progress. Upon death you return to your last save with everything you did undone. This causes some serious balance issues: suicide runs to find things can have no risk, and 3 hours of inventory management and storing items in houses become totally irrelivent if you forgot to save. I'd honestly prefer some kind of perma-death system to being flat out ignored by the game. The device parts also tend to get clustered togeth on the coast. You can basically beat the game by walking around each island and you'll find 80-90% of the needed parts in most instances. There are two invincible enemies in the game one is a hot air baloon that shines a light on you and makes a ton of noise, but can be temporarily disarmed by shooting the light or easily avoided. The other can one shot you, track you to the ends of the earth, and is difficult to evade. I don't like that one. Usually if I get caught I just save and quit and then reload.
The game has been finished and the final product is similar to it's beta. I still recommend the game, though I am disappointed in how little content there is. Wait for a sale. Less than $15 is worth a buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062611617', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1437383756}
review:
tl;dr-Yes good, much planning, many strategic, so sneaky, low replay value, such time consuming 

It's a short game, but fulfilling. Time consuming completing it, but worthy of the effort put into it. There's a lof of thinking and planning ahead going on with the simple things the game gives you, each area is a little different, each chunk of progress gets tougher, until you either become desperate and sprint, or continue to wait. 
I'd say it's good for the one play through that took me 5 hours, eat some shrooms, run from doges, distract smoking, mustache weilding robots, and get let down with the end of the game. Good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983022700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1434145625}
review:
I was honestly looking forward to this game. I got it on sale during the steam summer sale. I wasn't over-hyped about it, but I was looking forward to it. I love a good survival game. This isn't it though.

It has a good concept though. A survival game with smart ai that are trying to hunt you. The bad part is the environment for me. For starters, you can't go in buildings. That wouldn't be so bad if the actual terrain was interesting. Looting pretty much amounts to running up to the doors of houses and hiting the action button. 

There's only like 10 items in the game that are actually useful, which is sad. That makes the game feel even shallower than it already does with the lack of interiors. I was bored with the game about an  hour in. There just wasn't a whole lot that made me want to keep playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060133892', 'num_games_owned': 357, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 4340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1956, 'last_played': 1689290557}
review:
I feel like now that I [spoiler] after many damn tries [/spoiler] tried to beat the game I can finally give this game a review it deserves.

Pros: 

+I really love the concept of hiding from robotic english huntsmen in remote islands in the UK
+Well-executed foliage-based stealth
+4 weapons that are destructive when used correctly (I don't recommend combat that much)
+Lotsa enemies each deadly in their own way [spoiler] (except the Squire, he can be beaten with an axe provided you keep running in circles around him. I dont like the squire) [/spoiler]
+The Landowner's sounds keep me up at night
+Lots of interesting gadgets provide various ways of ridding yourself of pesky robots.
+I really like some of the island types, especially the Mountains.
+I like the way the stealth is also based on how noisy you are.
+Random-generated terrain and the ability to edit the robots that spawn allows for massive replayability.

Cons:
-Multiplayer is VERY VERY VERY BUGGY. I've noclipped through the world so many freakin times and I really hope they fix this soon because I love the multiplayer so far. Wish you could have a Co-op option in the single player "story" (there is no real, complex story), like in Borderlands or something similar.
-Please make the landowner less spooky.

What I hope to see in the future:
-Glitches being fixed in the multiplayer/Co-op in singleplayer would be nice.

[b] Final Score: [/b]

[h1] 8.2/10. A pretty fun game if you like stealth/survival games. [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198019816374', 'num_games_owned': 1351, 'num_reviews': 1677, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1656063761}
review:
Let's Play
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kg6H2do6L48&list=PLBonlAW_WHtxNcg43Hd9zv7j-FnGClIlj&index=10

Ok, so, what to say about this game.

[b]Good[/b]
Robots are extremely Posh. So you won't be dissapointed by a lack of tophats or monocles.
Found letters are so British you will forget you are fleeing from teams of Polite Murder bots who hunt with shotguns to give you a sporting chance (I think).
I got spotted by a baloon and felt like I was fleeing a POW camp.
Tutorial is minimalistic but gets the job done. Don't get killed, use things, eat, find artifacts.
Music is on point and really adds to the atmosphere when you ae being chased.
Drunk effects are decent and can cost you your life if you drink at the wrong moment.

[b]Bad[/b]
Robots often patrol around artifacts in the open, making fighting a requirement (yes even though you can distract them)
Difficulty ramps very quickly. I found 4 artifacts and was suddenly unable to scavenge as each town had a group of Robots in it.
All of the junk. There appears to be [i]alot[/i] of junk stuff everywhere. Why?
Rats, and other dubious items, can they be cooked to remove their dubiousness?
Hunting. I have read that there is hunting and I have seen some rabbits in the game. Do you have to shoot them? Run them down and hit the with an axe? Use a trap on them? The game offers no insight into this and I feel as if it is quite important. There is a finite supply of food that is scavengeable.

[b]Overall[/b]
I do not usually play survival games. I do however, reccomend this game on the basis that it made me actually [i]feel[/i] hunted. I found myself ducking my head (Control Racing style) when I was trying to get asway and hide from a group of hunters. So bravo!

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198106524939', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1438294785}

The game is complicated and very dark so it is difficult to see at times, if you cannot withstand being put under pressure constantly I do not recommend it. I personally didnt like it and would not recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121980277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1705802738}
review:
Pros
1) immersive envioment
2) simple yet elegant story telling
3) The best stealth system I have ever used.  When you get seen you know why!  
4) Customizable difficulty. (honestly I often turn all enemies off just to explore, and loot the immersive world)
5) excellent modding potential

Cons
1) the story while told well is lacking (honestly this is not that big of a deal given the sandbox nature)
2) lacks replayablity (I play for the enviroment of the game, but other than that there is not much reason to come back)

Summery
This is overall a very good game; however, the normal price tag of $20 is a little too high. This feels more like a game that I would pay $10 for.  That being said it is way better than most games that are asking $30.  I value games by the number of hours of enjoyment they give me.  This game gave me one great play though.  I will, and have come back to it from time to time, but after the first play through you have all the game offers.

The modding potential of this game is enormous.  The sandbox of this game is perfect.  It is simple yet funcitonal.  Every thing feels balanced.  Weapons can be hard to find.  once you do find them Ammo is always an issue, and killing anything without ammo is quite an engaging trick.  Honestly this is the only stealth game I have ever liked. The reason being when I was seen I knew the reason.  Further I got to chose when to engauge, and when to sneak.  Unlike most stealth game that are fairly linear in their levels;  Sir gives you a wide open sandbox with a reason to sneak.

I cannot stess enough for one play through this game is great.  Mind you it will take a few tries to learn the game, and that is fine.  I will be excited to see the mods that come out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125534085', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1488714149}
review: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 12 years old when my mother said to him, ''if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediatly.'' Tears welled in his eyes and he realized exatly what was at stake. He gave it up immediatly. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- ''dont ever smoke, please dont put your family through what your grandfather put us through.'' I agreed. at 17, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say that I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it. Because this game gave me cancer anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081274240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 656, 'last_played': 1566167596}
review: Loses its tricks after the first playthrough, but that first playthrough is one heck of a ride. Should have more replay value with more updates. Its a must buy if only for the end credits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034421672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1437943802}
review:
Pure nightmare fuel.

Oh, yes, this game lures you in with it's dark humo(u)r and british charms, but then you realize this game is terrifying. Now, I don't play very many horror games, but this game...It's scary. But there are no jumpscares. The robots aren't scary in a "ooohbooo" kinda way. They don't look gross, they aren't that de-humanized or anything. I guess it must be what they represent.

I was making my way through an abandoned town, crouched down, peeking around every corners. A hill, nearby. Suddenly, 12 pairs of glowing red-eyes appear over the knoll. Bearing muskets. I turn around, going in the opposite direction. Then, I realize there's four more enemies on the other side of town, and a hot-air balloon just to top it all off. There's only one street in this town, and if I'm going to not be spotted, I'm going to have carefully stealth and adjust my position as the enemies sweep through town. The enemy will have to have one house between me at all times. I must wait for them to pass...



Or, better yet, just quit the fucking game because i am not fucking gonna shit my fucking fuck to fucking shit my god damn house. Fuck that shit. Seriously. Motherfucking asshole british fucks, shitting dick piss fuck.

2spooky4me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058220338', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1439234712}
review:
"Sir, you are being hunted" est un jeu de survie √† la premi√®re personne. Apr√®s un accident lors d'une exp√©rience (en gros), vous voila propuls√© au milieu d'une archipel britannique du 19√®me si√®cle, o√π de petits aristocrates robotique font une partie de chasse. La proie, c'est vous, √©videmment. Comme tout jeu de survie, vous allez devoir chercher des armes et de la nourriture principalement.

N√©anmoins, la difficult√© repose sur des principes assez simple. En effet, l'objectif est de rassembler des objets qui ont √©t√© dispers√©s, des sortes d'artefacts, qui doivent √™tre ramen√© au cercle de pierre du centre de la map, l√† o√π vous d√©marrez.

-Qu'est ce que √ßa donne?

C'est un bon jeu, √† n'en pas douter. M√™me si les graphismes ne sont pas exceptionnels,"Sir, you are being hunted" promet de bons moments de survie, m√©langeant la discr√©tion, les diversions, et un peu de combat. Le point fort repose notamment sur la g√©n√©ration al√©atoire de la map, qui est ma foi de tr√®s bonne facture, m√™me si certains espace sont parfois un peu vide. Vide? Pas tant que √ßa en y regardant √† deux fois une pr√© avec des hautes herbes ou une for√™t d'arbuste n'est pas un vide, puisque cela vous maintient cach√©. Qui plus est, lors de g√©n√©ration de map, vous aurez aussi la possibilit√© d'avoir diff√©rents "biomes" (chateau, industries, campagne... 1 biome par √Æle). Le jeu est plut√¥t bien √©quilibr√©, tant au niveau des loots que de la difficult√©.


- Parlons en, de la difficult√©.

Il est int√©ressant de se pencher sur la difficult√© du jeu, apr√®s tout c'est le fondement d'un jeu de survie. Car celle-ci r√©side dans les objectifs. En devant aller chercher ces artefacts, vous devez pas mal voyager, √† pied. Puisque vous devez les ramener au centre, √ßa vous promet pas mal d'aller-retour, et donc, corse la difficult√©. En effet, la sauvegarde est possible, mais pas souvent, quand vous √™tes au cercle de pierre, ou bien quand vous √™tes au bateau, qui est donc votre point d'arriv√©e sur une carte. Autrement dit, si vous mourrez alors que vous √™tes au beau milieu d'une nouvelle √Æle, vous perdez votre progression et retournez au bateau qui vous a emmen√© l√†. Autre d√©tail concernant la difficult√©, un artefact prends de la place dans votre inventaire, parfois beaucoup, vous obligeant √† le g√©rer en r√©alisant parfois quelques sacrifices.
Sachant qu'il y a une grosse dizaine d'artefacts √† r√©cup√©rer, il ne faut pas se le cacher: certains trouveront donc le principe r√©barbatif, bien que la situation peut √™tre √† chaque fois diff√©rente. C'est le risque lorsque des moyens simples (bien que plut√¥t efficaces), sont employ√©s pour cr√©er la difficult√© du jeu. N√©anmoins la difficult√© est relativement personnalisable lors de la g√©n√©ration du monde et dans les options.

- Et les robots l√† dedans?

H√© bien, les robots ne sont pas si mal. Je trouve l'IA assez √©quilibr√©, facile √† √©viter. Le surnombre vous posera souvent soucis, vous obligeant √† contourner, √©viter, faire des diversions. Si on a la bonne approche, on peut s'en sortir. Ca reste assez ardu, mais je n'ai pas eu le sentiment, personnellement, d'√™tre compl√©tement bloqu√© parce qu'ils √©taient trop forts. Les combats sont n√©anmoins √† √©viter la majeure partie du temps.


- Bref, il y a des d√©fauts quand m√™me, non?

Evidemment. On pourrait appr√©cier davantage de contenu. Des armes suppl√©mentaires, un moyen de locomotion discret et ne donnant pas trop d'avantage comme un bicyclette. Un mode multijoueur serait amusant. On peut aussi songer √† devoir fuir des battues. Bref, ces "d√©fauts" n'en sont pas vraiment, puisqu'au fond, on ne critique pas ce qui est pr√©sent, mais on regrette des choses qu'on aimerait √©ventuellement voir apparaitre.



En conclusion, c'est un tr√®s bon jeu de survie, qui p√¢tit d'un graphisme plut√¥t vieillot, mais d'un bon √©quilibre quand √† la difficult√©. Il promet pas mal d'amusement pour un jeu solo. Il m√©rite qu'on s'y attarde, m√™me si on certains tourneront vite en rond. "Sir, you are being hunted" sort vraiment du lot dans le monde du jeu de survie solo, c'est une belle r√©alisation sur laquelle on aurait aim√© voir beaucoup plus de moyens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084098073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1138, 'last_played': 1671013212}
review:
It was a chilly, spring evening in O'Lution Manor when this first came to my attention and I must say, that my interest in gaming had been waning a bit, snatching short plays of casual titles rather than putting in any significant time playing anything of depth. Indeed, with my eldest son having largely commandeered the console, leaving me with the laptop and mobile devices, it seemed I was wandering into the realms of the casual gamer.

And then I came across Sir, You Are Being Hunted. The visual style and sense of humour lulled me in in and when I saw, yes, my word, it will run on my laptop, I decided to take the plunge.

Buy, install, test. Yes, it seems to be working fine. I'll give it a proper go tomorrow.

Well, maybe tomorrow.

Tomorrow.

After a month of tomorrows I finally sat down to play it properly and... yes.

This game has it all for me, a veteran of stealth since Tenchu and Metal Gear Solid, here was a game that allowed greater flexibility than even they allowed. Sure, it allows you to make more mistakes and it can be very unforgiving when it wants to be, but what we have here is a very solid game. 

You, a gentleman or lady of apparently some standing have been transported to a strange alternate Britain, populated by a variety of robots who seem focussed on making your days end. Gentleman hunters, with synthesized Upper-Class British accents are you initial foils, but soon a whole range of robotic country-pursuits types are also on your trail, from poachers to foxhunters and of course, the robotic force-of-nature which is the Landowner.

To escape, you need to collect several parts of a machine scattered across the five islands, returning them to a set of standing stones at the heart of the map. 

You have weapons and traps available to find, as well as a number of items to help distract your opponents and, of course, food to keep yourself alive.

Vastly outnumbered, stealth is the key to victory here. Sure, you can try to slog your way through the robotic hordes but that is unlikely to end well for anybody. Rather you are encouraged to explore and retrieve what you need by subterfuge, or perhaps through use of a rusty trombone.

So, the gae itself. Lets look at the negatives first. The world is precedurally generated, which is great for variety but it sometimes seems that this makes the landscape you biggest enemy from time to time. I've never had a problem with beyond some locations being fiendishly difficult to get to, but it seems others have been completely stymied by this.

The graphics are great for such a small team and have an excellent visual identity of their own, but especially at night there are a couple of glitches that sometimes give you cause to pause, was that the flash of something significant, or just a glitch in the landscape.

And of course, thr focus, this isn't a big narrative game, this is a game that gives you a world and a mission and lets you get on with it. Don't expect AAA production values here...

...but...

that's a good thing. You see, the designers have come up with a good idea. This is a clever open-world stealth game that rewards ingenuity, careful planning and the occasional bout of gung-ho bravado. This is a game that is not afraid of stacking the odds against you and leaving you to your own devices. If there are insurmountable odds between you and your target do you wait it out, try and sneak through anyway, or just back off and live to fight another day? The game is certainly challenging in this way and with this in mind, the ones who will be most disappointed with it are those who like to be led through a game by their noses, or rely on quick reflexes to blast their way through a horde of opponents.

As a stealth game, its a welcome return to form from a genre that had lost impetus in recent years and as the kind of person who would once upon a time sit patiently watching guards waiting for that perfect moment, this game has rekindled my enthusiasm.

As mentioned, Graphically you are not looking at detailed character models, but beautifully stylised creations that can bring a smile to yoru faces with their occasional nuances and the scenery fantastically evokes the British countryside. Sound is equally well thought out, with a balance of excellent natural cues and some brilliant audio for the hunters themselves (The gentleman hunters somehow manage to come across as upper-class Cylons). The sound design will be as much of an ally in this game as anything else and playing with headphones is warranted.

The Keyboard/Mouse controls are responsive and clean and the HUD and inventory interfaces are straightforward and intuitive.

Frankly, Sir or Madam, this game has brought be a lot more joy than the last few TripleA games I bought and that is an achievement in itself. Now, if you don't mind, I'm going to set my hat at a jaunty angle and go and explore the North Island again. Toodle Pip!

review: This game was....fun i guess. I mean, there isn't actually that much to do but roam around shooting robots, and running faster than an olympic sprinter on steroids when you see a landowner. i mean, the game was fun until i realised that i don't want to collect 24 or so randomly spawned pieces of magical rock or whatever. author: {'steamid': '76561198053957831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1437414850}
review:
Nice little game, got this on sale and don't regret it. A quirky stealth survival game with very suspensful and slight horror elements included (if you're scared of british robots with guns). It's a slow paced game and one that definately gets easier the further you get into game and collect more loot. The game has a great atmosphere despite it's mediocre graphics.

Negatives include the fact after a while it can get a tad repetitive, and the game has a rough finish. There feels like there should be something more to this game, but I can't put my finger on what that'd be. Also, the robot AI is pretty poor, if you crouch you become pretty much invisible, even if you're stood directly in front of a robot. 

Still would highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072253557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1681441165}
review:
Welcome, Sir/Madam, to the most haunting and horrifying hunting game; where YOU are the ultimate prey.

Your helpful butler will explain things more fully, but suffice to say that this game is not your standard survival fare. I'm sure you'll be informed about the striking resemblance of the Archipaelago to some nightmare post-apocalypse Britain, and you'll likewise be educated about the wonderfully dreary atmosphere whihc makes this game stand out from the crowd of survival-horror titles. You'll be instructed how to avoid detection by the cold, calculating automatons that will relentlessly pursue you. You'll endure the elements, and learn to prepare impromptu meals from dubious ingredients. You'll learn to outwit those hunting you, and to fight back against them. You may even discover the hope of a safe trip home.

I'm sure you'll learn of all these things in good time. However, I'd like to draw your attention to another matter. 

You see, you are no longer alone with the robots. Others have made their way to the accursed place, and while that may be an opportunity to band together; it could equally be the sign of a new and far more dangerous threat. Not all your fellow prey are interested in working together, and it seems there may not be a way to bring everyone home...

Ignore the cut-throat ruffians who spread rumours of "abandonment", for the hunt is very much on. 

... ok, breaking character now for the sake of a more complete opion. Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a phenomenal game where you must combine stealth, guile and brutal combat tactics in order to escape a relentless horde of very British robots on a group of very British islands, while a very British butler guides you in a quest to recover the fragments of a mysterious machine. The stealth action is extremely tense and clever; and you'll be rewarded for keeping a cool head. The survival aspects are basic, but they get the job done -- and when you're running from crazed robots with shotguns, feeling a little nip of breeze is your last concern. Keep calm and carry on, and all that.

The controls and menus are intuitive and functional, and the world of Sir is far from hideous. If you get a chance to stop and admire the sunset, it's quite nice really. However, most of the game is spent crawling, creeping, sprinting and dodging; so the view doesn't always need to be the most spectacular... soon enough, the sight of hard cover and safe shelter will be more attractive than the most breathtaking vista. As such I'd suggest you ignore anyone complaining about low production values or a supposed lack of polish -- there's a definitive rustic and gritty tone, but that's kind of the whole point.

The real sense of excitement and enjoyment comes from that moment you turn the tables and begin laying your own traps, making your own plans, and visibly progressing towards your escape. Everything in the game points towards that end -- from the not-so-subtle reminders that most of the "loot" you find will be utterly irrellevant to your quest, to the way that the robots force you to keep moving, and even the barren-ness of the landscape.

That said, there are plenty of moments of levity mixed in; and the addition of multiplayer adds a whole new dimension to that. Items which were previously useless (or as good as useless) can now be used inventively; both for pure shenanigans or for a tactical purpose. 

Furthermore, multiplayer adds a new element of competition -- the robots can be outsmarted and outmanouvred, but fellow players are a whole different matter.

Sir, You Are Being Hunted combines the best elements of horror, stealth and survival; and wraps them all up in a quirky British package. It's not everybody's cup of tea, but if you're into that kind of thing then it will do very well indeed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977835630', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1437359130}
review:
This is a stealth action title, with emphasis more on the former than the latter.

The game meets its concept well and even /plays/ well, but the only people I can recommend this to are serious fans of the stealth genre. Inventory is limited, as are your opportunities to save the game - a simple misstep in a crowded area can bring half a dozen hunters to your location and may cost you 20 minutes progress in the blink of an eye. Think NES levels of frustration at times.

The procedural generation sometimes leaves a bit to be desired; I attempted to visit the northern island only to find the island had generated with sheer cliff walls. A piece of the machine is in there for me to find. Can't wade in the water, because water robots will get me. Can't climb a sheer wall because the game isn't set up that way. Hard to progress, under such circumstances. 

Controller support felt loose and lackluster. Keyboard WASD was fine, and felt more natural. Remember, inventory doesn't pause the world, so good luck using those rags while you're bleeding out!

In all, things I'd have liked to have seen:
* A few more save opportunities for those of us who aren't particularly great at Stealth
* tighter controls on a gamepad 
* some basic fairness would be pleasant, though certainly not required 

For: Stealth fans
Not for: People that like tight control, people who feel a game should stop destroying your hopes and dreams, or people who want a more cinematic/triple-a experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978587031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 463, 'last_played': 1437001836}
review:
So this is a first person shooter / stealth game set in a robocalpytic British islands scenario. You have to find mysterious parts that are strewn about the landscape while avoiding different types of robots that will try to kill you on sight.

The islands are procedurally generated, and the parts you have to find are dropped in random locations on the map. They are made easier to find by emitting a pillar of smoke, and are usually guarded by a couple of robot huntsmen. You can either rush in and try to demolish them or you can sneak in and steal it from under their nose. Or maybe it's safer to create a distraction, in the form of an alarm clock going off that you previously dropped some place else, or maybe a little choo choo train that you let go somewhere in the hope that the robots will go and investigate the disturbance.

The game has a day and night cycle, so it's obviously better to wait until it's dark for your pick up attempts. The problem is, you will get hungry while waiting. So you have to find food, maybe in the form of a glass of pickled eggs that you found in an abandoned house, or you might stumble over a pheasant in the fields, which just tastes splendid when cooked over a campfire. Too bad you haven't found any matches yet to get the fire going.

The default settings generate 5 islands that are connected by boat (which serve as the loading transition), and measure about a square kilometer in size. The British landscape is well represented, with rocky coasts and small, but thick forests, rolling countryside with some agriculture, some castle ruins, and so on. The weather is also well represented, rainy, with a chance of clouds. There are small abandoned hamlets, hunting cottages and other buildings strewn about the maps, which can unfortunately not be entered, but if you activate the doors, you can find useful items within. They range from junk like bones or souvenirs over dubious food items like dead rats or strange mushrooms to useful stuff like guns, ammunition, bandages or cans of tea.

The robots are pretty deadly, they only take a short moment for aiming, then you are blasted with shotguns, blunderbusses or other weapons, which leads to a quick demise. If you start bleeding, you better have some bandages on you, or your health slowly runs out until it's game over. The AI is pretty good, the robots investigate all kinds of noise and movement; for instance if you startle a rabbit while your sneaking towards a guarded piece, a robot might see it run away and start looking for trespassers in the area. Sometimes a robot can get stuck in an obstacle, but I only saw it one or two times. The different robot types require different approaches to deal with them or to avoid them, which creates a bit of variety in an otherwise pretty repetitive game (you walk around looking for the smoke pillar of a piece in the distance, sneak there, deal with the robots who might guard it, get the piece, rinse and repeat 15 times).

Technically, the game is solid, the controls work well, the AI behaves like it should, and video and audio is well implemented. It obviously doesn't have triple A graphics, but it gets the job done, and art assets are stylish and support the British setting beautifully. The soundscape supports the feeling of being alone and hunted by a superior foe and sometimes even creates a mildly creepy feeling, when you are sitting in the high grass and listening to the distorted electronic voices of your hunters all around you.

There is no free save system. You can only save at the place where you have to return the pieces to (a spot in the middle of the central island), or at the boats. This obviously creates some tension, because if you get detected while going for a piece and die in the aftermath, you will start again at the boat and have to travel the whole way to the piece again (which doesn't take very long, fortunately).

I finished the default 5 islands scenario in about 7 hours, but it's probably doable in less time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009398866', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1674780246}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976798627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1575408386}
review:
"Avec ou sans nuage de lait votre th√© ?"

Vous √™tes un noble aristocrate qui a atteri sur un archipel inconnue √† cause d'une exp√©rience qui a mal tourn√©. Sans aucun √©quipement, vous voil√† seul avec comme unique aide un tutoriel de 26 secondes sur la situation : Pour revenir √† la maison, vous devez retrouver les diff√©rents artefacts qui vous ont fait venir ici, √©parpill√©s sur les 5 √Æles du jeu.

Mais voil√†, vous vous rendez compte que l'archipel est peupl√© de robots qui ont pour amusement de tirer sur tout ce qui n'est pas m√©canique... et qui se tirent entre eux s'ils s'ennuient un peu trop d'ailleurs. 

Entre deux pauses "tea and biscuits", vous allez devoir survivre, vous cacher (souvent) et distraire les robots pour r√©cup√©rer ces artefacts. La nuit sera votre pire ennemi et vous crierez au miracle quand vous trouverez une arme (avec que quelques munitions). A chaque instant, vous stresserez sachant que vous pouvez mourir ou avoir une crise cardiaque de peur √† chaque coin de l'archipel... et que les sauvegardes sont que entre les diff√©rentes (grandes) √Æles. 

Sir, You are Being Hunted est finalement un jeu unique, agr√©able, jouant avec votre stress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044905628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2307, 'last_played': 1618104670}
review:
In Sir, You are Being Hunted, you are trying to collect mysterious machine parts on an archipelago, filled with victorian robots trying to hunt you down. Basically imagine Hot Fuzz if they were all robots.

Pros:
+Epic Atmosphere. You feel like you are in the British countryside (which i have experience of).
+Brilliantly designed robots. They look cool and are well animated.
+Good music and sound effects. Music is reminiscent of Half Life 2 in its quality and the sound effects are perfect.
+Actually scary. Hearing the little bleep the robot makes and not daring to move, then jumping up and running off at the shotgun blast is terrifying and awesome.
+Has an interesting story that you can track down with in-game letters.
+Now with multiplayer!

Cons:
-Bad UI. The mouse is a bit laggy on menu/inventory screens and it feels quite slow.
-Occasionally laggy. Could do with some optimisation.

Overall the game is a unique, wonderful horror semi-survival game with ample replayability and a macabre, gleefully sinister atmosphere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044616029', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1445215282}
review:
Sir, your being hunted (or simply Sir,) is a survival Stealth game through and through. and i wolud like to put extra emphasis on the 'Sealth' this game likes to follow more in the vein of metal gear solid then ARC or the long dark, then enemy is not the opressive enviroment or steady tick down of your hunger and thirst bar but the more immedate threat of your murderious hunters! you generally start off with no weapions and limited equiptment but this is fine as in Sir, your own gun can just as easily get you killed as save your life oprituntys to save are generiously given so death well punishing is not unreasonably so light survival game eliments are in play and you must scavange for food items to recover your vitality though this is mostly in place to push you into closer proximity to unfavorable ground and your hunters, the AI is reasonably intelligent and reacts in a farily authentic way, hunters will guard the artifacts your searching for if they happen across them, and can be deceived into gunfights with eachother by skilled players in the right ground. there s also a constant and oppressive atmosphere with steadily mounting odds as more and more robot types join the hunt. 

all and all an incredibly good game though the reacent multyplayer beta is a bit difficult to acess if your not shure how.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031750809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1663074764}
review:
I thought it was all over when I accidentily shot a Squire in the face.
I thought it was all over when I hid under a structure from the Balloon only to find out the spotlight is made of magic.
I thought it was all over when I stepped in my own bear trap after I put down an alarm clock.
I thought it was all over when I got shot in the face by a robot talking about concealing secrets from his wife.
I thought it was all over when I lost my fake British accent.

But then, when all hope was lost, I got all the pieces to the Stone Circle and went home.

8/6 broken shotguns, would get hunted again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086388293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 236146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 384, 'playtime_at_review': 53137, 'last_played': 1710625798}
review: I really like this game.   It is a 100%  stealth and strategy game.  I have played using all the different character types  available which does not change the gameplay just the items in your inventory at the start of the game.   You can change the landscape and the buildings and throw in the amount of robots that you want.   I really like the ability to be able to modify and change landscapes and structures because you have a different game each time.  I will strongly advise not to start the game with the max amount of robots  if you are a beginner as it will be almost impossible to play.  Between the dogs and the horsemen you will  running  for your life and may not enjoy the game.  Horsemen  sometimes  do not appear if the fields (hayable, stonewall,  hedge, woodfence) are not checked or turned on.  They will appear outside of fields obviuosly but many times I have constructed landscapes with no fields with horsemen added in  the mix of robots and none were ever seen during the game.   If  you  really want a challange give it a go because almost every single field will have a horseman.    Horsemen are not limited to the fields and they will roam the woods and villages as well but prefer the fields it seems.   It does not matter where you are  if the horsemen see you run.  In the landscape menu you have a variety of landscape types to pick from and to modify.  Only one landscape pattern per island.    Be careful when choosing dramitic with mountains and valleys as it can make extreme pits and  canyons to fall into and mountains that are very tall and hard to climb.     Also, if you choose large islands for all your islands sometimes the game will have trouble loading and then other times there may be  one of the docks that is off in the corner of the screen (map) or way out in the water where you will always be killed by the mechanical arms (bog monster) before you can reach the dock.     However, not all of the arms will bite you causing damage.    I have found that they tend to rotate damage vs non-damage.   The first one you encounter will make noise and that is all but when it goes away the very next one will bite and cause severe damage and death if  you do not run away.   Sometimes you will have a piece of the artifact (teleporter) on an island that is only a few yards away from your main island and you will have to walk through the water.   There are no boats to use for these situations you must wade through chest high water and sometimes go underwater.  You do not swim or drown just walk or run through the water.   I have spent alot of time in and under water and never drowned in this game but anything is possible I suppose .   Jump in the water and wait for one of the bog monsters to  pop up.  If it does not bite then keep going but if it does, retreat back to shore and wait for it to go away.  Do not stand at the waters edge cause they can hit you on land.   Once it goes away try again and the next one should be harmless.   There is so much to this game that I love and appreciate.   My hats off to the makers of this game at Big Robot.  Great job and well done.   I  know some people do not like this game because they cannot save game progress anywhere anytime in the game or they say there are not enough weapons or they want massive damage weapons.   This IS NOT a "shoot'em up" type of game.   It is a stealth and strategy game.   I love the fact that you can only save at the standing stone or at one of the boat docks.    Also,  if you are bleeding or starving you cannot save either so make sure you have rags and food.    I like the challenge this puts on the player.   Its 100% all about STEALTH and strategy.   If you use your noise makers wisely ( clocks, trains, bottles, rocks and trombone)  you can distract the hunter bots to accomplish your goals.  I  know its just a game and that the robots can be predictable sometimes, but you still have to plan  and think ahead about how you manuver.   Happy hunting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962933804', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1436612419}
review: Absolutely terrifying

author: {'steamid': '76561198009870555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1461452784}
review: A bit clunky and a bif stiff, but the feeling of wonder as you explore the countryside always on alert of possible hunters is really unique and will make you want to come back and give it another try. I'd definitely be in line for a sequel, if it ever came out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080230536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1581987709}
review: A very dynamic open world stealth/survival that actually makes you feel like you're being hunted. If you suck at killing things and you fire off a few too many shots to take an enmy down, it might just attract a few more baddies from off in the distance. If the robots know about where you are but can't quite get a fix on you they won't hesitate to release the hounds. All in all a pretty good title for the price. My only complaint is the shooting/combat in general needs to be a bit meatier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049631929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1487626919}
review: Spooky

author: {'steamid': '76561197987514123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1436282862}
review:
A first-person, procedurally generated stealth'em up with a satirical steampunk twist.  Basically a stripped-down version of DayZ with the bandits replaced by literal bots.

Honestly, I don't consider the low audiovisual quality a huge downer:  It's still functional and you're supposed to remain focused on the gameplay, which the game delivers on by and large.  There's a nice attempt at world building with little tidbits of information to be discovered, which are fairly well written.

AI is quite predictable (isn't it always the way in stealth games, though?) but the scarcity of defense measures and variety of enemy behaviours allow the game to remain challenging (run on default bot population:  I have no intention of playing on the hardest settings, thank you very much)

Overall, probably not worth the full $20 but it filled four hours and I don't consider that time wasted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058342657', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1386598054}
review: My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him "if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- " dont ever smoke.Please dont put your family through  what your grandfather put us through." i agreed. at 28, i have never touched a cigarette. i must say, i feel a verry slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050488270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1436099719}
review: l histoire se passe sur l ile d island , tu doit rechercher les  fragments de la pierre sacrer afin d en acquaparer son pouvoir pour pouvoir detruire ce monde de monstres .tu te deplace sur une barque instantanement sur les quatres  point quardinaux de l ile .tu recherche les fragment en evitant les gardes, les chiens ,les boss, les cavalier , et les mongolfieres. comme un jeu de survie tu doit te nourrir , trouver des armes et des munitions.et autres objets utiles comme de la dinamites, un detecteur de fragments , des boissons , des annimaux a chasser , des soins .ect... amusant a jouer , jeux asser court , je le recommande. ( voir page du magasin)

author: {'steamid': '76561198053560912', 'num_games_owned': 585, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1436081663}
review:
I thought I could trick them into my brilliant trap. All I had to do is set off a few rounds and they will come running to me, I thought. So bang! A revolver round shot off and they came running. Into my trap I thought assured- come into my trap! They stopped right in front of my bear trap and walked away. Inside of my mind was screaming, NOO!!!!! So I shot 5 rounds at the robot, missing them. Not a single shot hit them. Dang it. However, They all came running towards me now. Yes, 3 more bullets and right into my trap. FOR SURE NOW! Don't waste your last 3 bullets! Wait, where is the 2nd robot? I swore there were 2- one going into my trap and.... 1 of them. Wait, what happened to them? I swore there was 2 of them. Now there is only- wait, where the guy who walking?.... NOOOOOOOO! Where did they go?! Bang Bang! A sting hit from behind, another shot from the side. But HOW?! That's when I realized, the first bullet attracted the guy in front. The 5 wasteful bullets attracted the ones from behind me 1 minute later when patrolling. I'll just go foward, since they don't seem to be there? How dead wrong I was. The 2 that were suppose to fall into my trap came around from the rock and bullets went flying into my body. I was surrounded. I panicked.
Scrambling- shooting 3 bullets at one of the robots, and one bullet hit but didn't kill it. 
I scrambled into my inventory to see if I had any other weapon.
I panic and ate a mushroom.
I can't see what going on...
that when I realized that I have 5 seconds to bandage myself or I'll die.
I panic and I clicked on my smoking pipe that was next to my bandage.
GOSH DARN IT.
...... did these robot just outsmart me? Impossible. 
They were just cheaters. Yep. That is it. They cheated!
*quit game*
Writing a legit review about the game, that contains no helpful information.
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198039692704', 'num_games_owned': 453, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1435875358}
review:
Review for Controller Users

Awkward movement
-Slow charecter movement (very!)
-Clunky (Let's try to walk straight.. not as easy as I thought..)
-Cannot walk diagonally, only foure directions (is this 2015?)
-Pushing to the right/left makes your Character tilt to the right/left which feels weird and imprecise

Menus & Inventory
-Need Mouse for Menu
-Need Mouse for Inventory (you will use your inventory frequently for loot)
-Not all buttons are used


Overall I cannot recommend this game for those of you who want to use the Controller to play this game. Luckily I only spent 2‚Ç¨ to get this game so no regrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066647427', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1652462557}
review:
I'm recommending this, but it's not a strong recommend. Picked it up during a monster Steam sale -- I think for like 90% off or something -- and it was definitely worth the ~$3CAD but probably not the full price of >$20. 

Sir (or Madam), You Are Being Hunted is a sandbox first-person stealth game set in a vaguely Edwardian time period where you, the protagonist, get stranded on a series of islands and are hunted by murderous robots. Your goal -- to travel to each island (five in all) and acquire pieces of a machine to transport you to safety. All the while, you have to mind your hunger and scavenge for items like food, bullets, weapons, and alarm clocks. The islands are procedurally generated with each game with a choice of one of five biome types. I really like the procedural islands; each biome is different and they feel natural and well thought out. On the default setting, the game starts with a few robot  hunters and, as you collect more pieces, ramps up the difficulty until finding those last pieces becomes seriously difficult.

The good and the bad (caveat: I haven't finished the game yet because of the serious difficulty mentioned above):

Good:
Procedural generation: I'm a sucker for it, my favourite game genre of all time is roguelikes, and this is roguelike-y in random generation of the islands, the buildings and the enemies.

Stealth: this game is at heart very stealth oriented, inasmuch as even if you do find weapons going in with guns blazing, even on the lower levels, is not a winning strategy. Bullets are scarce, weapons are scarce, and there are way more of the enemy than there is of you. It's entirely possible to play the game without shooting any weapon at all, which I find refreshing.

Graphics: I game on Linux, which okay, I'm already at a disadvantage, and I game with a low-endish business model Thinkpad, which again, problematic, but the game is smooth as anything on my machine and still is graphically nice to look at. Well, "nice" in that the game is simulating a depressing English countryside, so colours are muted and browns, grays, dull greens abound, but that's ok. 

Sound: Surprisingly this game is *very* sound oriented. Don't try to play without having your sound on; you'll get clobbered. You'll need to hear the robots approaching -- each type has a distinctive sound -- in order to avoid them. There's an option in the game to turn on an indicator, which puts a little Metal Gear Solid-ish "!", "?" above the robots' heads to gauge how aware they are of you, and this is *invaluable* - at least if you're playing the game without headphones -- but even so you'll have to listen hard to survive.

Repeatability: There are *lots* of options to tune the robots appearances and numbers. I haven't messed with this yet as I want to finish the game on the default, but it's great to have something beyond "Easy, Medium, Hard" for difficulty.

Gender: It's a small thing, but the fact that you can pick your gender is a good one. More games should do this.

Bad:
Stealth: hey wait, didn't I just put stealth in the "good"? Yeah. But in this game you spend a *lot* of time crouched in reeds or ducking behind buildings while all the while your vitality trickles to zero. This does present a nice amount of tension to the game, but the islands are *big* muthas and finding the pieces without the piece detector is hard enough; trying to find them blind is *really* hard. And when you've spent hours combing an island to find that last piece, while all the while the *hordes* of robots that populate the endgame are shooting you, trapping you in bear traps, running you over with rocket horses, and biting your foot it gets real frustrating real fast.

Sound: I have a mild hearing disability and I don't particularly like games that are super dependent on sound, so I sort of resent the fact that I *have* to have sound turned on in this one. Not sure how it would work without it though.

Items: The primary way one gets ahold of things is by searching buildings for them, and there are a *lot* of junk items you can't actually do anything with. I would love an option to turn off junk items because it's annoying to go to a door and just find bones. You can't do anything with junk -- not even throw it as a distraction -- so I'm not sure why the designers included the junk items in the game at all. As far as I can see, they serve no purpose beyond annoying window dressing.

Buildings: The buildings look great, but you can't go inside them. They exist solely as a cache for (mostly) junk items. The game would be improved greatly if you could enter a building and peek out a window, or have, say, fixed items to heal damage, like beds or something. Instead they're basically giant crates.

I'd say, eh, three and half stars out of five to four stars out of five depending on your tolerance for frustration in the difficult endgame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123699433', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1434234575}
review: This game did not feel balanced to me. There were many parts that were very difficult, and many other parts that were too easy. This inconsistancy in difficulty has driven me away from this game all-together. A free demo would have been apreciated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056250645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1492395531}
review:
This game is very unique and fun, perfect for a stealth game fan like me. In this game, you are spawned on a randomly generated island where you have to collect all of the pieces of a machine scattered across the land. However, the world is filled with robots who wish to hunt you dead. As you progress, more robots of different kinds spawn such as a dog that will pin you to the ground, a horse riding robot that rams into you and a giant robot that will not stop chasing you unless you die or enter another area. If the game is too easy, you can modify the world before you start so that more robots spawn or that the different varieties spawn earlier. This game is easy to get into and waste some time on and has a ton of replay value.

Also, multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044797961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1435575819}
review: A beta version or a bad one first person shooter. The graphics, textures, landscapes and scenaries are dull and poor, specially in rural areas. The stealth system is not well implemented by the treatment of sounds in distance: run is the best way to move because walking crouched is too slow and there are few places to hide sure in countryside, overall if you are in trouble. Pretends to be a survival game but not has a true craft system, have little variety of items and many are useless, irrelevant or negatives. There are structures, but are inaccessibles and only serve as containers; all appear to be a cardboard decorate. The foes have great perception and make high damage, but give miserable loots; when a shooting begins many times appear one or more from the nowhere. Always its better avoid them, distract them or flee, and this ends up to not being fun. Maybe a wonderfull game at the 90s end, but nowdays only worth with a huge discount and for hang out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064445036', 'num_games_owned': 1447, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1435141002}
review:
Was ist Sir, You Are Being Hunted? Eine Mischung aus DayZ, Slender und Minecraft. Eure Aufgabe ist es bestimmte Artefakte zu finden um das Spiel Erfolgreich abzuschlie√üen. Schwierigkeit daran ist aber das Ihr gejagt werdet von Roboterwesen, welche anders wie in vielen anderen Spielen euch mit 3 Schuss ins Game Over schicken. Manchmal reicht jedoch auch schon ein Schuss, da Ihr wie z.b. in DayZ blutet nachdem Ihr getroffen werden und euch erst verarzten m√ºsst eher Ihr damit aufh√∂rt und somit keine Lebensenergie mehr verliert. Desweiteren m√ºsst Ihr Nahrung finden, Dinge reparieren, Essen kochen, Orte erkunden und viele andere Dinge tun um nicht von den J√§gern erlegt zu werden. Was bleibt zum Absch(l)uss zu sagen, Sir, You Are Being Hunted? ist ein besonderes Spiel da Ihr in einer Position seid in der Ihr in 98% der Spiele die Ihr sonst spielt nicht seid. Deshalb ganz klaren Daumen hoch.

F√ºr einen wahren Sir:http://www.twitch.tv/thebenjaminkendrick

author: {'steamid': '76561198091531843', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1175, 'last_played': 1514016919}
review:
[i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i] is a stealth survival FPS with random map generation. You step into the role of a high-classed gentleman/ lady scientist/ inventor of some sort who's latest experiment has gone horribly wrong, and has this Sir or Madam stranded on a group of islands in an alternate reality. If things didn't look bleak enough, your butler informs you that you are being hunted by denizens of this strange new land; they are Victorian England robot hunters looking to fill in a space on their den wall. Keep a pistol in your hand and an ear to the ground as you venture forth in this funny yet freaky adventure.

The goal of the game is to repair the Standing Stones, the relic that went haywire during your tests, in order to use them to warp you back home. To repair the Stones, you need to locate the missing pieces which where dislodged during your failed experiment, and gather them back to the Standing Stones. The catch, however, is the presence of the manhunting automatons that are more than happy to riddle you with buckshot, catch your ass up in a bear trap, and otherwise just ruin your unexpected journey. Their forces grow larger and more dangerous with the more progress you make.

As a survival game implies, you have to manage needs like hunger. It is called Vitality in [i]Sir[/i] and it is basically a calorie meter combined with your potency to regain lost health over time. You use various food and drink items you gather from looting and hunting wild game to restore Vitality.

Even though the game supports a decent variety of weaponry, from a simple axe to a high-powered rifle, the best weapon is stealth. Ammo can be difficult to find as the game goes on and can be very cumbersome on your inventory, so sticking to the shadows pay be the most safe and economic way to play. If you're one who isn't worried about saving every bullet and shell, then you can employ guerilla tactics and Rambo your way to victory. There are also other means to gain advantages against your predators, such as bear traps and noise makers.

This game stands out fairly in the survival game scene nowadays, with its somewhat simple yet surreal/steampunk art direction, witty humor and Easter eggs, the haunting feeling of being watched and hounded down, moments of "what the hell..." and robotic gentlemen with shotguns instead of zombies. I give this lovely game a 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077634365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 3184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1670, 'last_played': 1568458783}
review:
I've recently purchased this fine piece of work during the summer sale. When I first saw the title, I liked the concept although I forgot to follow it.
I'm through now a couple playthrough and I have to say it is quite a great, violent hide-and-seek game.
I like the idea of randomly generated worlds which we see quite rarely in games although with todays tech it is more than convenient to build certain games to have this feature.
I liked the AI - it payed attention to check out places where they saw some distraction multiple times.
And I liked the touch of horror in some robots - personal favorites are the Landowner and the Scarecrow. It's great when you don't notice it, you hear something from behind and when you turn around suddenly a glowing pumkinhead smiles back at you, you unload your rounds (it would be fun if you could shoot yourself in the leg in such frightening moments if you don't aim right), then it minces you in a couple of blows... Or when you sneak through the forest and then for the first time you hear the landkeeper's scream and you open up your inventory and rather drink up all the brew pretending it will make it go away...
Another funny factor was when robots started to fight each other. In some playthroughs I've got my first weapon+ammo this way.
Love the game! Good work! ;)

review:
Keine Ahnung warum irgend jemand dieses Spiel gut findet?
Es gibt keine R√§tsel oder Herrausforderungen au√üer der am Leben zu bleiben. Dies erreicht man durch st√§ndiges Laden des Spielstandes. Austricksen der Roboter ??? Keine Ahnung wie das gehen soll.
Schmei√üt man eine Flasche kommen ca. 30 Roboter und killen einen egal ob man versteckt ist oder nicht. Selbiges passiert bei allen anderen Dingen die L√§rm machen.
Benutzt man eine Schusswaffe passiert dasselbe. Also einziger weg ... Axt nehmen und die von 5-6 Robotern bewachten Steine frei k√§mpfen. Echt ganz gro√ües Tennis.
Absolutes Drecksspiel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041756379', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1507724137}
review:
Playing "Sir, You Are Being Hunted!" has been one of the most engrossing and endearing experiences I've had for a while. It makes you feel powerless, but hopeful. It's a game where an empty bottle is more useful than a revolver, where running is usually the best option. 

You have to weigh up risk and reward, since you can only save at key locations. It's nailbiting when you're driven to sneak through an occupied village because you're desparate for something to eat, hoping you don't get caught. Although, when you do get caught, it's a rush. You're faster than the standard, common hunters, so you'll be able to shake them if you put enough forest between the two of you.

Overall, I had a lot of fun with "Sir, You Are Being Hunted", a really fun experience, and a great sense of achievement when I made it out of the hunt alive. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for something different.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970516292', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1435641359}
review:
Do you remember those early moments playing games like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. where the game had just started, and you were travelling along in a desolate ruin of a place feeling tremendously under-armed and vulnerable?

If you loved that feeling of tension and vulnerability, this is the game for you. 

In Sir, You Are Being Hunted, well, you get what it says on the tin. You are being hunted. Constantly. At first, if you're cautious, avoiding the patrols of dapper british robots trundling around looking for you in the wake of some robo-pocalypse feels pretty easy. 

But the more of the key pieces you gather to get to safety, and the longer you survive, the more dogged and determined the robots get.

Weapons are few in this game. Ammunition scarce. Weapons (on both sides!) are devastatingly powerful. Nothing feels like a peashooter in this game, especially on your meatbag fleshy body. Running and hiding is ALWAYS preferable to combat, not least of all because the sound of gunfire and violence will bring in robots from the surrounding countryside.

This game isn't very fast-paced, but it is tense, and great at punishing you for being too careless. (It will also punish you for being too cowardly, as you've got to keep scrounging and wandering to find/hunt food.)

This isn't a game you'd call a power-fantasy. It's more like a vulnerability-fantasy. 

It's a very particular flavor of a game, but if it's a flavor you like, you'll find it intense and satisfying here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022295012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1434158062}
review:
this game is meh
simple and quick little stealth games for those looking for a simple little tromp through the genre.  you can beat it under 2 hours if you dont die much and there is very little on offer.  The basic of the game has you running around 5 diffrent islands collecting shards while avoiding the robots hunting you, sounds fun on paper but the only time i had trouble was when the robots were puppy guarding the shards themselves other then that they are painfully easy to avoid.  might be diffrent on harder difficulties but the game gave me no reason to try as it gets repetative and boring very quickly.  there is enough enemy variety but none really give you trouble unless attacking in numbers (which is usally the case except with the wierd scarecrow ones). all in all not worth the $20 asking price but i got it for $5 on sale and that to me seemed fair.

review: I've been watching and wanting this game for a long time now. It's very unique and the british/old english theme just appeals to me. I finally bought this game on the Steam Summer sale and I am not disappointed. It's a bit of a slow paced game and I personally like that. If you have severe ADD you might do better to skip this game. I've only played it for about an hour so far but I really like it. The graphics engine is very nice. It may not be the most technologically advanced in terms of all the latest bells and whistles but it does distance drawing very well. I look forward to playing this game for many hours as time permits. For what I paid for this on a Steam sale I feel like I've gotten my moneys worth already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084475452', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1434305829}
review:
Runs slowly even with all the graphics settings set to low, but that's due to my elderly computer rather than any obvious flaw in the game itself.

In less than half an hour of gameplay I collected several skulls and a pair of unusable boots, was startled by my butler making comments at seemingly random moments, suffered food poisoning thanks to questionable food choices, and was shot in the face by a dapper robot. I look forward to repeating the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126259287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1434246712}
review:
Pros - You are indeed being hunted, so we know they tell the truth
 Robot heads glow so they are easy to find/avoid.
 really cheap on sale.
 works with onboard graphics, so in reality, my main con can be dealt with.

Cons - everything else.
 Some issues with the graphics makes my rig draw 260 watts - far beyond the justifiable draw for the graphics and scope of the game
 due the power consumption issue, this game is unusable for me, it makes my room too hot. SInce I didn't give it a fair chance, I'm not giving a thumbs down, but in reality, it is the game makers fault I'm out the cost of this game and have an unusable product. My computer works with over 30 games and not one issue on any of them - I5 4690K R9 290 16GB 1866- high end Case, PSU, fans, Motherboard- just in case anyone wants to blame my rig.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965624987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 815, 'last_played': 1624685416}
review:
"Sir, You Are Being Hunted" is a blast. If creeping across English moors with little but your wits, evading an entertaining array of robots, who are naturally, hunting you, sounds like your cup of tea, nick some biscuits from an abandoned house and dunk away.

It is immersive and spooky, the lighting in particular adds to the tension as the tell tale sound of one of the excellently animated robots tests your stealth and nouse.

A flaw perhaps is that it is repetetive to a degree (few games aren't) - find the 15 scattered items to get off the island, but the random generation of the map and item placement adds enough replayability for me. For now.

The limitation of only being able to save progress at various points, for me, adds to the game. A few well set traps and a loot filled rucksack can all be undone by not taking the safe option occassionally. It's your decision if you want to risk past progress. 

Multi-player is being added soon - will be interesting to see how that develops.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076561670', 'num_games_owned': 882, 'num_reviews': 264, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1449349920}

author: {'steamid': '76561198054539340', 'num_games_owned': 1817, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1445958399}
review:
I'm not sure how to explain just how good this game is.

For a start, it's incredibly difficult - and I mean difficult. Finding out how to get past that robot patrol guarding that telebit piece is a challenge in and of itself, and whilst I've never been caught by the Landowner I have indeed seen his creepy-as-bollocks appearance. 

Scarecrows are another matter. Let's not talk about them.

The aim of the game is to fix your teleporter whilst also not dying. That is literally it. This sounds fairly simple - but then you discover that your butler is ethereal, seems to refer to you as a madam (disclaimer: this is indeed an option), and there are robots with guns trying desperately to find you and the telebits whilst also generally being a nuisance. Couple this with the fact that not only is your Vitality is constantly draining, but food is basically non-existant, there's a giant Bog Monster in the sea, and an invincible hot air balloon can see you from miles off, and it makes for an atmosphere to kill for.

Oh, and also everyone in the game (bar yourself, the silent protagonist of old) is English. 

You're welcome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042546601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1658959390}
review:
Go to new fresh island
Set bear traps near the boat so I can collect some juicy rabbits when I come back
Search the island
Collect all magical rocks
Decide to just sprint back to the boat
Big spooky landowner robot sees me
The chase is on
Getting close to boat
Step in one of my own bear traps
Landowner is getting close
Open inventory, use plyers to get out of bear trap
Landowner is pretty close
Running for boat
So close to boat
Step in another bear trap
Try to use plyers
It's too late
Landowner kills me with his magic stick of stun

Good game, do recommend.


Edit: editing the review for badge

author: {'steamid': '76561198071730806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1434174111}
review:
First I'd like to address the fact that this game has some of the worst graphics I've seen in a while. Second, I'd like to also say that this game is horribly optimized. I have an i5 4690k, and a GTX 970, and I'm only getting roughly 50fps on medium.

PROS:
This game has a great atmosphere, and pretty satisfying combat. 
Inventory is quick and easy to organize.
Enemy AI is surprisingly good.
Gun play is well balanced, and ammo is relatively hard to come by
This game also offers quite a decent challenge. 
CONS:
Bad graphics (doesn‚Äôt really matter)
Poor optimization, even on high-end pcs
The save mechanic is rather annoying (you always have to run back to spawn to save)
You can‚Äôt explore any of the interiors of the buildings.

Other than these few things, this game is pretty fun. However, I'd highly recommend getting this game on sale, as it's something you'd be disappointed with if you spent $20 on it.

review:
Don't take the fact that this is a a positive review at face value. You might hate this game.

In a way it's like a lot of roguelikes where your experience might be RNG dependant. This game is frustrating and annoying until you get you get a weapon. This game is hard until you learn how to -use- that weapon (quick tip: ambush enemies around corners). Once you get a start going, it's pretty fun. THough I don't have too much experience with games of its genre, but I'm under the assumption that this is a decent entry game. I got it for 2 bucks, I'd say it's worth it.
