author: {'steamid': '76561198049420272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1511140761}
review:
This is quite a strange game. In my opinion, it's pretty genre-bending experience. I'll just sum up what the plot is: You are an English gentlemen who has mysteriously teleported and anbandoned on an archipelago of 5 islands, which are inhabited by several different types of robots, who, like you, are English gentlemen. These robots range from Hot Air Ballon pilots to just normal humanoid robots with rifles and hounds. Their mission is to hunt you down and kill you, before you are able to acquire a certain amount of crystals, which in return transport you back to your home, where your butler awaits. 

I'll tell you first hand, that this game is TERRIFYING when you start playing it. When you see a Hot Air Balloon, you'll run for the forests to hide. When you see a group of hunters moving towards you from a distance, you WILL panic. Not only is this game scary in some ways, but it is also very depressing. Somehow the abandoned and destroyed setting and constant rain somehow brings it all down to a quite sad and almost nerve-wrecking experience. 

But nevertheless, all of that depression is replenished with the spirit of scavenging and hunting your hunters! Although this seemingly a stealth game, you have all the wits and will to fight back. Eventually, you may find an axe. Or a rifle. Or even a grenade, Which all can be found through this game's scavenging system. Food, gadgets, and gizmos can be found all across the 5 islands in houses, destroyed robots, and more. 

I would strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes a nice amount of stealth and a strong sence of fear. 
WARNING! You need a pretty beefy computer, as mine cannot handle some of the detailed textures, and often lags when looking at, say, a forest. But even if you don't have a good computer, still try getting it! It's really worth it!

I rate this game 4/5!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013780205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1399084149}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035004965', 'num_games_owned': 1792, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1409106790}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted, (SYABH), is a proceedurally generated game that is a little unlike most games I have seen.  It is a rather plesent blending of alot of little game ideas that seem to pay off.  

You play as a inferorior human, and some strange monolyth like marchine has exploded.  It is up to you to put it back together.   However while playing across some Britich Archapellago, you are being hunted by a colorful veriaty of robots who seem to find you fitting spot.

So while hunting down these chunks of machine you have to dodge, hide, scavange and possiably fight your way through the world, small strange towns hold places to scavange for supplys but also seem to be the favriote hangouts of robots aswell.  
You need to eat to stay strong, you need rags to bandage yourself up, you need all kinda noise makers to distract robots, and if you lay your hands on a weapon you really need to wonder, is it safe to shot the robot, or is there another way.  Guns are very loud and raise alot of atteniton and are pretty much a last resort, for any situation.

The worlds are pleasent and procedurally generated from game to game, you do have some control over it.  There are methods of finding the chunks of the machine, however they take up an aweful lot of bag space, and the diffrent kind of robots range from not very dangerious, annoying, to making you paranoid as you lay face down in a puddle of your own terrified wee praying that they didn't see you.

An awesome game that so many have overlooked, if you like stealth and hide and seek this game is most certianly for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021519256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1474924650}
review:
This is everything I want from a stealth game. Frequently I find stealth games are somewhat elementary. You can sneak but you're just as good fighting it out with all the guards. The only real penalty for not being stealthy is usually a rank at the end of the mission or game. This is little better than a wagging finger.

Sir, You are Being Hunted turns this on its head. You are vulnerable. You drop in unarmed. The clock is ticking. You have to scavenge supplies. Being spotted starts a mad dash for cover. You have little way to fight until you get lucky enough to find a weapon. Even then, killing a robot is difficult and you often stand to expend more ammunition taking one down than you will gain from having killed it. Stealth and patience are key.

My only complaint is that I wish the robots had posh British accents.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047975427', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1455486879}
review: It's a fun game with challenging stealth mechanics. If you just play to beat the game it might get repetitive fast, however if you take it at leisure it's a pretty nice survival game. My only issue is that it feels as if it is still in Early Access; it feels unfinished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003802360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1408702556}
review:
L'idea che sta alla base del gioco √® sicuramente molto interessante, purtroppo per√≤ √® gestita male. A inizio partita quando i robot sono ancora pochi e deboli lo stealth "classico" funziona anche, ma andando avanti nel gioco diventano sempre pi√π forti (e grossi) e al contrario il nostro personaggio non migliora. Non esistono "punti stat" da assegnare o nuovi gadget da utilizzare, si deve sempre e per forza ricorrere al "nascondino" per non farsi trovare dai sempre pi√π numerosi nemici. 
Stanca molto presto, ancora prima di finire.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046588843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1440963435}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005518845', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1399467190}
review:
Although this game is obviously not fully developed yet it shows a lot of promise.

It is an open world roaming stealth game, at least that's the way you'll be playing most of the time.

The game mechanics are sound, moving around, sneaking, shooting, it all works perfectly.

The randomly generated worlds offer variety and although the textures at the time were a tad bit bland I'm quite sure these will be souped up in future releases.

Do buy it, it is well worth the price!

edit: 

Five years later and nothing much has changed, sadly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040836436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1409160469}
review: Sir, This game puts you in beautiful setting consisting of 5 islands with a clear objective to achieve. Try to survive and even arm yourself to fight off the different kinds of robots hunting you down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070453934', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1444632710}
review: I love the ambiguity and wonder this game produces. I haven't quite looked into much on the robots themselves, but I find that the immersion comes from wondering just what the robots are and observing their behaviors. Trying to stay hidden can be somewhat of a chore, but I find that it takes some amount of practice to be able to successfully sneak or confront robots and remain alive. Building your inventory is less "what if" and more "this is what I need right now". Some weapons and items are outright useless (I've had no luck using bear traps at all. I was able to set one off, but it just sat floating in the air). The weapon mechanics take getting used to, especially with the hatchet, but they are entirely usable, such as the shotgun and revolver. I enjoy the pseudo-sandbox aspect, wherein you can change your class to increase or decrease the difficulty and change what and when different robots appear throughout the game. Bottom line, Sir requires a bit of immersion on the player's end, which can be tough for some people who are used to better stealth games, but this game gives me chills and a racing heart. I have no idea what most of the robots are there for, but I really don't want to find out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055441759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1385544352}
review: I bought this game on a whim during early access.  Unfortunately, "Sir, You Are Being Hunted" is a poor game.  The game is nice and atmospheric.  You really do feel like you're being hunted.  The game's mechanics are a good start, but they lack depth.  The only really good way to survive is to completely avoid the robots.  If you try to attack the bots, you'll most likely get killed and will definitely run out of ammo.  If you try to ambush a bot with an axe, you'll get shot and bleed to death before even landing a hit.  The robots have nearly unlimited ammo, but if you kill them, you'll rarely be able to scavenge any.  Trying to avoid the bots takes forever, so you starve to death.  Getting an objective without alerting the guard bots is pretty much impossible.  The guard bots get alerted, and even if you survive them, bots for half a mile will come running to kill you.  This game had potential, but wasted it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040961114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 672, 'last_played': 1390581138}
review:
Very unique setting and characterizations of NPC's are well done. The game only excels and is carried purely from the strength  of the originality it inspires to achieve, sadly, the actual gameplay detracts so much out of it that the originality is all that remains. 

A simple premise of collecting fragments of a crystal from different islands filled with pompus, steam-punk policemen wraps this game up in a nut shell. The gameplay mechanics are extremely primitive and under-developed, and in most cases- broken. 

It doesn't take long for the novelty to wear thin with this one. Not worth buying in it's current state. 


42/100

author: {'steamid': '76561197992202855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1401456328}
review:
Contrary to popular belief, and unlike the title suggests, no, you are not being hunted. Instead its a treasure hunt as you sift through un-enterable buildings, collecting 7/10 useless things, and 3/10 that might actually be of use. 

Bots, while their dialogue amused me, and their aggression towards you is something to consider, aren't as amazing as the blurb suggests either. I scrapped one with an axe and it bunny-hopped backwards away from me, continuously, until I finally managed to end him with another swing. I don't get why they try to escape you like that when they could very easily put you down. 

The terrain is vast and mostly uninteresting. At one point I roamed so much of an island undisturbed I actually thought a glitch had ejected all bots from the map. This game would be cool if you were actually being constantly hounded by hunting parties that are out looking for you, so the stakes would be that much higher. But instead it's just a matter of working through (or around) the various patrols to get at the supposed plot devices while fending off periodic starvation. 

I find that the game description is... slightly misleading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037558977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1388, 'last_played': 1462810886}
review:
Holy Crap on a Cracker, this game is awesome! Where can I begin?

Firstly, the entire setting is wonderful. An archipelago of islands filled with deserted towns and houses, being watched over by Tweed-Donning robots with a taste for tea and murder. Exploring the islands is great fun, as you must always be on the lookout for roaming hunters and their dogs, hot air balloons lighting up your position or the Landowner, a fearsome robot with a cane that is well accustomed to crushing various bones and organs. Some variation in setting between islands whilst keeping the same British-Grey colour palette allows each area to be individual but memorable. The Castle biome has many ruined walls and turrets of old fortifications, while the Industrial Biome has larger towns with great chimneys and drilling platforms. Finding landmarks in the terrain that are often guarded by the posh automatons makes exploring no walk in the park, and adds to the tension and sense of adventure this game can create.

The enemies are very well designed, with types varying from the standard Winchester-wielding Hunters to the turbo-charged  robo-horses that are ridden by jockeys determined to run you over. The big cheese of all the robots is the Landowner who, as mentioned before, is a formidable opponent that must be avoided or outwitted in order to survive his metallic glare. Enemy variation doesn't stop there, and the combinations these types of robots can be found in can make taking certain Pieces a challenge.

The Main Object of the game is to retrieve each Piece of the "Device" that was destroyed in the "Experiment" (some backstory here wouldn't go amiss) and return them to the standing stones on the centre island. Each piece is guarded by at least two or more robots and can vary in size from tiny pieces that barely take up any room to giant parts of the device that need prior planning and inventory space to take back to the standing stones. Once all of the pieces have been collected the game ends. As time passes and pieces are returned, more robots appear, in greater numbers and variety, making each piece harder and harder to collect.

The Inventory system is tile based, so that certain items take up more room than others. A Flask of Luke Warm Tea only takes up 2 tiles but the Largest Piece of the Device takes up 16 tiles all together. Looting houses, fallen enemies and occasionally bins and phoneboxes mean that your inventory will stack up with all kinds of good loot, making you consider whether you want those extra shotgun shells or that canned pie that might be needed later.

All in All, I enjoy this game immensely and hope that Big Robot continue to add fresh content to this already wonderful concoction of a game.

EDIT: Props to the Devs for allowing you to play as a Madam!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969592572', 'num_games_owned': 1954, 'num_reviews': 477, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1408304571}
review:
[h1]SIR, YOU ARE BEING HUNTED[/h1]

So, "Sir, You Are Being Hunted" is a relatively neat concept of a game that you a in fact being hunted, with a twist of some British humour. I like the concept of being hunted, but the execution is rather disappointed. 

I expected the rush of being the target of a manhunt, but got a scavenger hunt with a heavy emphasis on inventory management. Like, the main goal of the game is to find some "mysterious objects" which tend to differ in size like some can be relatively small and other, very big. So how can this be a problem? Well, you gotta manage your inventory all the time since it is not intuitive. You have to scavenge for food all the time since your vitality keeps going down and well, you gotta keep some space for guns and ammo. However, from the guns I tried, they were weak and the robots took a few shots before being brought down... and more than half the times, their scavangeable goods are trashed. So, guns are weak and ammo are more than scarce. So you're better of just avoid the robots huh? NOPE! They'll find you anyways since in each strategic places you have to go, there's not only one but a few robots patrolling. And talking about places, you keep trying to figure out WHERE THE FRAK YOU HAVE TO GO, since the map isn't working... or maybe I haven't found it on the character I've picked? Bah whatever!

The game do look nice and the procedural generated world is well made, but are often repetitive and mostly empty. Playing around with your grid-based inventory can be time consuming enough to break immersion. Having limited inventory for a game like this is great, but having to reorganize a grid-based inventory to pick up an item when enough space is available is annoying (so you're hunted and you gotta play Tetris at same time!). Also, you can't enter buildings since they act like chests.

So overall, sneak around robots, scavenge for goods and ammo, manage your inventory "Tetris style" while being Hunted, look around and find the plot items "mysterious objects" FIFTEEN TIMES without knowing where they are. Fun? NOPE! 


[h1]POSITIVES:[/h1]
[b]+Procedural world setting is decent.
+Atmosphere and setting of being hunted get's creepy.
+Audio atmosphere is gloomy.[/b]


[h1]NEGATIVES:[/h1]
[b]-Poor inventory management.
-Game world looks pretty much the same everywhere.
-No maps to help your navigation around (maybe you do get one from another character build?).
-Way too scarce ammo.
-Fetch quest is the main goal of this game... finding those mysterious objects FIFTEEN times gets tedious for nothing.
-Story is simply not interesting.[/b]


[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME. Unfortunately, Sir, You Are Being Hunted fails to either impress me and make me feel like I am being hunted and breaks immersion too often to maintain my interest.  Basically, "Sir, You Are Being Hunted" is not good enough to justify spending X amount of hours just to finish the game. I haven't finished this game nor I am willing to spend more time on this below-average game when I got lots of better titles around.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198009852020', 'num_games_owned': 125, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1396842675}
review:
I bought this game expecting something cool and suspenseful and replayable, but what I got was a half-baked product that was so low-quality that I couldn't believe that the developers would release something so unfinished under the tag of 'Early-development'. 

The first thing you'll notice in this game is the complete lack of challenge. The bots are completely easy to avoid, and hunger isn't really ever a struggle or challenge for the player because you can find food everywhere in the towns. The only part of the game that comes close to difficult is when the air-balloons fly around and spot you with their spotlight.

Second, there's absolutely nothing to do in this game. Every game has some sort of direction it wants players to go in. Even DayZ has the loosely defined goal of 'getting tons of cool stuff, making a helicopter, and killing other players'. But in [i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i], there is nothing that the player needs to accomplish. The developers /knew/ this would be a problem in an open-world, single-player game like this, but do you know how they tried to fix it? They added a goal where players need to follow these little shiny 'wisp' looking things to crystal shards so that they can go to another island. 

As a player, I'm left thinking, 'why do I want to even do that'? What's my motivation to collect the shards? The next island is gonna look pretty much the same, and it isn't going to be any harder to clear than the last. The game itself is a chore. A chore I paid like $15 for, and not even a fun one like pulling lint out of an AC filter. 

Don't buy this game. I bought it a year ago expecting the money to help the developers work even faster on the game and make a great final product, but now the game is pretty much the same as it was when I bought it.

Oh, and one final note. The voice-work in this game is pathetic. It's some guy with a painfully-fake British accent talking into a headphone microphone. You can even hear it 'pop' when he says 'p' syllables because they didn't even have a professional microphone with a pop guard. It makes me angry to think where the 'early-development' money PLUS the kickstarter money went.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003052612', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1408565556}
review:
Hail fellow and well met, what ho and good day to you Sir!

Well, I say 'good day', and indeed it would be, only for the fact that it seems that you've been involved in a bit of an accident, you see? Now you're stuck on these rather bleak looking islands, and I'd say you need to find all the bits of your spiffing machine if you want to stand any chance of getting home.

Only catch is that there doesn't seem to be anyone around. Couldn't imgaine where everyone's gone off to in such a hurry. Maybe they're all away on hols, eh? What a wheeze that would be, sir!

But wait, sir, there do appear to be some figures wandering these lands. Good, tea-drinking, game shooting, tweed-wearing chaps like yourself, sir! Ah, but it appears they're of the mechanical variety, so it's most unlikely that they'll help a fellow in need. Not the friendliest of toffs those robots, as a matter of fact. 

Actually, on closer inspection it rather appears that they favour hunting humans over more conventional game. A rather unfortunate turn of events, sir. You know what that means, of course? Yes, sir, you are being hunted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112966560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1464633832}
review: This is one of the best stealth survival games I have ever played! It has a randomly generated landscape, along with tense and suspenseful gameplay. There were so many moments in the game where i was scared shitless and hopeing that the patrol wouldn't see me, or feeling like a complete badass because I got my hands on a gun. The game also has island biomes rangeing form rural areas to industrial biomes with even a custom island generator to make your very own island! Not only can you customize the islands but you can customize the difficulty by adjusting how many of each type of robot spawn in at different times in the game, hell you can make it to where there are no robots at all.There are tedious things about this game such as the inventory management, i mean sure i get it, its used to add strategy and planning. but you cant even rotate items and your inventory space is way too small! The game also gets repetative and boring after a while with not alot of replayability. I'd give this game a 6.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198045453823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1613364543}
review:
Hide in the grass, thinking I'm safe. Nope, footsoldiers.

Hide in the rocks, thinking I'm safe. Nope, Air Balloons.

Hide behind a building, thinking I'm safe. Nope, Landowner's pissed.

Hide in the ocean, thinking I'm safe. Nope, robot alien fish.

Shoot a robot walking with his robot-buddy, and stand in plain sight. "I guess it was nothing".

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198075536602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1530658316}
review: This game is amazing. What's better than hiding from stereotypical English robots? This won't be everyone's cup of tea (get it?) but if you do like it,you won't get bored with it. However,you may want to wait until it's on offer as I do not believe it is quite worth the full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098387639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1655830903}
review:
This game to me is average. It has some fun moments in the fact that there is a lot of stealth and chases. That said, it feels really empty. The visuals are ok, but not as good as i had expected and the only real places to hide are fields, thats it. These areas that say they are industrial really arent as most of the landscape is, well... grass. The variation of enemies are cool and they each have the weak points and strong points. The inventory is a clever idea, but frustrating at times as you play a puzzle game to try and put everything in. This game can bring a few hours of enjoyment overall, but can become a little boring after a while. I would still recommend this as for a stealth game it works very well, it just needs a bit more work as it still does not feel like a full game. Only get it when its on sale in my opinion as its not worth the price. If it was cheaper then this would be a great game to get and a really fun way of spending time when your bored. The randomly generated maps are ok as well and they do vary loads, but there still needs to be work done to make it more of a dense world and have more to do.
6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197992892379', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1407807358}
review:
Generally disappointing. I think It lacks depth and variety.

Your first and only objective is to find pieces of the mysterious machine that can take you home if fixed. That‚Äôs what you‚Äôll be doing for the rest of the game. 

[i]Stealth[/i]
So, you approach a piece and see that it‚Äôs guarded by a couple of robots with guns. You can throw an empty bottle or a rock to the side, the robots will leave to investigate the noise, you safely grab the piece and leg it. It doesn‚Äôt matter if they see you: they can‚Äôt run nearly as fast as you or shoot straight. Even if they hit you, it still doesn‚Äôt matter‚Äîyour health regenerates over time and their guns don‚Äôt do much damage from a distance. The old bottle trick will help you get the first fragments, but, the thing is, it‚Äôll work just as perfectly for the very last fragment on the last island. There are other tools you can use to distract or fight the enemy, but why bother if bottle throwing works every time? At later stages of the game some tougher enemies will appear. They never seem to approach the fragment sites. You have no reason to disturb or confront them, so I‚Äôm not sure how tough most of them really are.

[i]Survival[/i]
You need food to regenerate health, but it is abundant. I only ran out once, and that was at the very end of the game when I already had all the fragments. Sure, it‚Äôs neat that you can hunt and cook the game you‚Äôve just shot, but you can easily get by with whatever you find laying around.

[i]Story[/i]
The intro is intriguing. How did you get there? Who built the device and what does it really do? What was the experiment all about? How did it go wrong? Who‚Äôs the man helping you? Why do the robots hunt you, and why do they seem to control the area? Where did all the humans go? What‚Äôs with the will-o‚Äô-the-wisp things and what do they have to do with the device? Sadly, I didn‚Äôt get closer to finding answers to any of these questions when I got to the end. Even the ending cutscene just shows the machine starting and then cuts to credits.

All in all, I guess it was interesting enough for one playthrough (took me roughly 4.5 hours), but I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll be getting back to it unless there‚Äôs a patch that makes survival harder or expands the story greatly.

Many thanks to AvantGuard for gifting me this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043074776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1417923424}
review:
An adrenaline-fueling yet funny game, where you are being hunted by an army of Gentlebots. You have to get machine pieces and bring them back to where you start to repair a teleporter as your butler, Mr Walters, talks to you. As you get more pieces, more and new, tougher robots come. You have a hunger meter, so you have to scavenge for food in the houses that lay around. At first, your only tools of dealing with the robots are bottles that you can throw to distract them (they don't hurt them) and alarm clocks that you can set to go off - up to 60 seconds of delay. Although, you might find some weapons that will be of use - the hatchet, the pistol, the shotgun, the rifle and even a blunderbuss! All the time, you will have to deal with a Tetris-like inventory. 
It runs on the Unity Engine, so it is not that intensive: but don't expect great graphics.The game is still in development, so new robots, biomes and items are being added.
A definite recommendation.
Oh, and may I add: Sir, You are being Hunted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035855295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1455148087}
review: Do you enjoy using model trains and empty wine bottles to lead upper class English robots into an ambush? Me too. The game has a unique dreamy aspect to the visuals a fair bit of fun game play and roving bands of aristocratic robots looking to mount your head on a wall. All as you search for missing hunks of an obelisk and try to escape.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014681050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1257, 'last_played': 1453967331}
review:
Someday i awoke on this island with these oddly speaking english robots...

they are hunting me.

my clothes were enough for 3 bandages. 

i am wounded. i am starving... and i can hear them laugh.

i saw them from a distance holding human skulls up high and singing robot songs...

i dont¬¥know what they want... but i found a revolver and 6 bullets.

fear leads to anger. anger leads to hate... and now the hunter becomes the hunted!

(Highly recommended Survival Horror full of fear for the skilled and creative Player in a Sandbox Matrix. Noone will Survive. This time It¬¥s a Trap!)

10/10 "They are made for Hunting Humans.... And they will do!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198020982568', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1527522393}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024451265', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1407304528}
review:
+ Game design, particularly enemies, is charming in its own right
+ Dynamic lighting was visually pleasing on high settings
+ Vitality system encourages scavenging, though it's somewhat too easy to manage
+ Strange and enjoyable soundtrack helps set the mood very well
+ Enemy AI is passable

- The amount of walking you do gets boring, fast
- Very, very poor save system which harshly punishes simple mistakes
- Very limited selection of traps and weapons
- Increasing numbers of enemies as you progress seems to be the only way that difficulty is managed, which doesn't really add anything; You'll be dealing with enemies the same way, only there is more risk, which is bad (considering the save system)
- All the different island types feel the same, with few distinguishable features
- Best approach to enemies is to either avoid completely, or shoot to kill quickly, which seems like the opposite of what the devs were hoping for, so I count it as a negative that they ended up not encouraging traps
- Poor replay value

[h1]LockeProposal's Big Day Out[/h1]

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/bigdayout#]Community Group[/url]
[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/7611703/]Curator Page[/url]
[url=https://www.reddit.com/r/SeriousSteamReviews/]Serious Steam Reviews subReddit[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197999123375', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1644419261}
review:
The moment when I pulled off a successful raid on a trio of Victorian Gentleman Robots and their robot-dogs without a shot being fired using a clever combination of alarm clocks, toy trains, an empty whiskey bottle and a trombone, then escaped without being spotted was the moment I realised I liked this game. The fact that it successfully invokes more heart-pounding mouth-drying leg-crossing tension than a job interview with your ex's mother with nothing more than a stretch of open countryside and some robots. The way you can live in the woods surviving solely on fruitcake and sherry.
Sir, You Are Being Hunted. Worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070455550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1609708684}
review: Bloody marvellous game this is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120675325', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1423247980}
review: This is a very fun game. It has been made to a high standard. There are the scary moments which scare the living daylights out of you and there are the funny moments which make you chortle with laughter. I 100% recommend it to anyone who enjoys tweed horror games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966072175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1508961586}
review:
Very enjoyable but quite a short game. Worth buying in the sale.

The game dynamics work very, with the robot hunting parties becoming increasingly challenging as the game progresses. The number of different types of landscapes also keeps the game fresh. Very atmospheric, beautiful landscapes, music and lighting (day, night, mist)

Cons 
- I have to run the graphics / resolution on a very low setting - its seems very resource hungry.
- It has an amateur feel sometimes, such as the lack of intro movies and very simple plot line.
- length of game is way too short. Kinda feels like something is missing when you finish it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052014473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1697420952}
review: Probably one of the most tense games I have ever played. I like that you can switch between being called Sir and Madame. Despite the graphics not being the most amazing I have seen, this game instills a quiet fear inside of me that I can never quite shake. Definitely worth playing through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972378490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1678763914}
review: Good show old chap. Play as the "aristocrat", start with nothing. Run in fear from the robots. Has some of the survival feel of the DayZ mod for Arma II but with a purpose other than "kill all humans". Save points far enough away to make it a challenge. First few intros to the game are terrifying until you get oriented.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065531949', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1409843592}
review:
En achetant ce jeu je m'attendais √† une sorte de jeu de survie dans lequel des robots te chasse sur une petite map et o√π les armes sont difficiles √† avoir (un peu comme un Don't Starve en FPS avec des robots =P), je me trompais.

En fait, le jeu emm√®ne le joueur sur une grande √Æle sur laquelle il y a d'autres √Æles accessibles par les bords du centre, on peut choisir sa classe au d√©but (par exemple le "Policier" qui commence avec un revolver) et ensuite la loi du plus fort prend le dessus : Les robots qui sont en groupe sont difficiles √† battre au d√©but, mais c'est souvent gratifiant car leurs armes les tuent en un coup (le revolver les tuent en 3 balles, ce qui est r√©aliste). Le protagoniste (vous) se r√©veille pr√®s d'une sorte de Stonehenge qu'il faut charger de cristaux pour retourner chez soi, ils sont souvent dans les feux de camp (Un conseil : Cuisez votre viande crue si vous en avez avant de prendre le cristal car apr√®s le feu s'√©teint (ce qui attire les robots)).

Au niveau de la survie, il y en aussi : 
 - Il y a une barre de faim, qui ne peut pas √™tre recharg√©e en mangeant des assiettes ou des cr√¢nes. (on peut)
 - Si vous vous couper vous saignez et il faudras un bandage sans quoi vous mourrez.
Ainsi que de la furtivit√© : Vous pouvez approcher les robots en discr√©tion dans les hautes herbes par exemple et leur tirer dessus (ils sont g√©n√©ralement 3 - 4) ou les couper si vous trouvez une hache. Par contre personne n'est sans savoir qu'un coup de feu fait du bruit, mais vous pouvez prendre les bouteilles et les lancer, ce qui fera aller voir les robots ailleurs.
L'inventaire quand √† lui fonctionne par cases, une assiette prendras 4 cases par exemple et une bouteille 2. Donc si vous avez jou√© √† Dr. Mario ou Fragile Dreams (jeux pas connus, Fragile Dreams est un tr√®s bon jeu d'horreur sur Wii) vous ne devriez pas avoir de probl√®mes avec √ßa.

Ce Early Access a un futur tout trac√©, j'attend surtout un workshop et un multijoueur.

Si vous ne parlez pas Anglais il faut surtout retenir l'histoire des cristaux violets.

En esp√©rant que cette √©valuation vous a √©t√© utile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081924025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1418496726}
review: I do admire the concept of this game and the fact that it is set in old England with typical English landscapes and features. but what let me down is how I feel like I should only be escaping the robotoc enemies and how I end up not focusing on the objective (collecting the glowing stones). The trickery and  stealth in Sir, You Are Being Hunted is quite unique and runs smoothly, though I was dissapointed by the shooting mechanics.  you always get a sufficient amount when looting, and you can find some uselfull things to use. In conclusion, I felt dissapointed after playing this game, but could potentially be more enjoyable if a few of the points I suggested were improved, though for now I did not enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104818185', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1503390031}

author: {'steamid': '76561198140674159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1406513359}
review:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. And it's enjoyable to a point but it's such a let down. 

I've been following this game's development since it's Kickstarter campaign, and I was so excited. Although when it reached it's Beta phase I forgot about it because of personal reasons. During the recent Summer sale, a friend of mine bought it for me and I couldn't wait to play it. 

For the first hour, it was fun. But then I really saw the lack of gameplay, enemy, and equipment variety. With only a handful of weapons, enemies, and items...it's hard to not get bored with this game. Not to mention there's only a single objective that requires you to have a huge gap in your inventory at all times. The game feels like it's in Alpha still, and is another reasons I have very low expectations for Kickstarter funded games now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061501120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1410048780}
review:
This game is simply a masterpiece. I would beat the game again, again, again for the song at the end even though I have the internet. But seriously, a wonderful game. Can't wait for more updates and multiplayer. I just hope that they continue updating this game. I bought the game when it was on sale for $5.00. Anyway if you feel buying and playing this game good luck and remember...


Sir, You Are Being Hunted...

author: {'steamid': '76561198042372383', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 3491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2969, 'last_played': 1620883559}
review:
Everybody missed the point of this game, confound it! It's not about stealth and survival, it's about the tea, biscuits, hats, and good mannerisms. Stealth, survival, violence, and a good read are bonus bits thrown in.
Totally recommended. I would have my children play this.
Relentless Britishness and the revenge of Humanity on robots. 
Slaughter them. Bonus points for having the option to disable the freaking invincible landowner. Cheap shots. MORE bonus points for map editor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038738372', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1141, 'last_played': 1667693839}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a great stealth based game where you are being hunted by British robots who roam the country-side and small towns which dot the landscape. 

The point of the game is to survive and escape the robotic realm which you are in. You need to collect pieces of a device and gather them at a point on the central island in order for you to return to your home. 

I have to say that 'Sir' is a brilliant game, it does force you to be stealthy at almost every turn since weapons to defend yourself are rare and many times only draw more patrols to your position. 

Basically; if you like sneaking around, trying to avoid detection, get this game and don't get caught.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963107509', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1405226521}
review: To keep it short. With the plethora of survival games out there right now, you should not even bother considering this over games like dayz and the forest.  There is just plain nothing to do but eat food and run from robots.  You can't even go inside a single building, you click on the door to take any goods that might be in it.  Oh yeah I almost forgot, you run around and collect stupid rocks that have no purpose other than a means to end the game, hopefully sooner than later.  I payed 5 bucks for this and you would be overpaying if you payed 99 cents for this. There is about 5 cents worth of meaningful content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144435439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1622598638}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a great game! Seriously! Although still implying that it is a horror game with lots of surprises, it can be loads of fun. I recoomend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002994478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1405983466}
review:
Not a bad stealth game all things considered. 

Suffers from a lack of replayability because it's rather simplistic. Took about 4hrs to finish on my first attempt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056400982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1681262037}
review:
Gathered a bunch of robots together with a toy train and then blew them to smithereens with dynamite.

Drank 4 bottles of whiskey in a row and shot a robot on a mechanical floating horse as it tried to trample me while I couldn't see straight.

Feared for my life while fleeing from (and being shot at by) a horde of gentlemanly robots and their dogs.

Almost shit myself when I got snuck up on by a Scarecrow, and actually got spooked by an explosion while I was hiding in some tall grass.

10/10, would definitely recommend. This is an amazing example of a survival game, and proves both the ability of the Unity engine and that you can still be scared for your life with graphics that aren't bloody-darkness-realism.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015769385', 'num_games_owned': 677, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1405111306}
review:
Another Early Acces fraud

This game is a great example of Early Acces developers who failed to finished their game and keep all the promices they gave. 

Few days Big Robot Ltd ago releas version 1.2 patch, but dont be fooled about thath. Sir, You Are Being Hunted is absolutely unfinished game which, for some reason, considered to be completed and sold for full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111269584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1134, 'last_played': 1405899269}
review: Gorgeous aesthetic concept. Lacking intuitive controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040092795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1508906890}
review: A clever setting, killer gameplay, and a great juxtaposition of cute graphics set against a very harsh and foreboding landscape. Sir, You Are Being Hunted keeps a very very very tense atmosphere while retaining a large amount of ridiculous British charm. The gameplay has never let me down, and every time I die, I know why I died. The pacing is brilliant and it holds everything together. There's a couple of glitches here and there, but nothing game breaking. In fact, it's so polished it could be a full game, but they're STILL adding things. I'd say the only thing lacking is in the sound design, but even that is almost perfect. Solid game, and definitely worth the price tag. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994706812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1422311207}
review: Basically other negative reviews sum up my feelings, I feel no reason to go back and play more of it, I only found maybe one McGuffun but I've probably exhausted 90% of the actual content of the game. Price is insultingly high for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007514801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1503663026}
review: This game is fantastic fun and I would definitely reccomend it to anyone looking for a game with a unique take on stealth and exploration. I was worried that the game was too easy after having played for around 20 - 30 minutes, as i had no trouble retrieving the metorite shards. However the increasing variety, number, and deadliness of the robots rapidly makes the game into a real challenge for even the most well-versed veterans of the stealth game genre. This game is fantastically well fleshed out and well rounded for still being in development, and is absolutely worth every penny!

author: {'steamid': '76561198054474397', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1545913752}
review:
Other reeviews have gone into great detail on this game but im not going to, all im going to say is i think this game is brilliant, it just feels right as you are scurrying about the long grass, you have 5 robots in your path and the balloon search light is overhead. Then you spot this massive thing with a walking stick, its stops and spots you... you have 6 bullets in your gun (now what do i do feeling comes over you) think man.. think..) Argggg.. Brain lagg.. 
Now thats what you want from a game experience.. It might not have the polish of an AAA title but its got enough thrills and heart thumping moments to keep you happy, and the best thing about it for me is its re playabilty as ive not spotted any patterns to the robots where you know they will be there the next time. 
Really nice Game experience this.

review: If you like stealth survival games then you will love this game. It reminds me of fallout 3 but i lot less ammo and way more simple. You do not go around killing everything you see you have to decide if its better to run or to fight back. Ammo is kind of rare witch is nice and also you have to eat but there is alot of food witch makes it very hard to starve to death. This game has Low polygon graphics but they make them work really good. But this game is not for everyone if you don't like to sneak around plan ahead and take your time then do not get this game because it is not for you. Also ever time you play it is a deffernt map so it is always fresh and you can't go online and look up where everything is but that forces you to expolre and makes it more realstic. At first i was on the fence about buying this game then it was on sale for $5 so i got but it is well worth the $20 for it. Also watch some reveiws before you buy it like with every game to see if you will enjoy it. Thank you for reading.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994159228', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1405958725}
review:
For a game which is essentially "capture the flag" the inventory is horribad.
some games have a kind of magnet effect when shuffling things through the grid, not this one. get it perfect or try again. you cant swap items around by dragging over them, you have to one by one (and you have to pick the up by the right place), perfect your pack so you can fit the unreasonably large rocks in your pack.

This, and endlessly hunting for food (which has to be shuffled around the pack) takes up so much of the game space that it sucks the joy out of the quirky aggressors and their hyper-paranoid guard activity.
There also seems to be (maybe its just me) a kind or ramping scale of difficulty for each failed attempt.
Try 1 - 2 guards
Try 2 - 2 guards and dodging a large patrol
Try 3 - two guards, two guard dogs and a patrolling giant .. thing..
what is wrong with you people.

This could be an ok game, forgettable but fun.
Instead, its a waste of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014774219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1627068401}
review:
This is certainly a unique and quirky little game. Aside from the slight British humor that saturates the game, I found the robots themselves to be a bit comical (In a murderous, creepy, sort of way). It's an easy game to get into, but I must admit it had me checking the Wiki every so often, especially when a little creepy voice kept whispering "Behind you!". 

As a fleet of enemies, these robots can be both heart-stopping and childish. One loan hunter is no problem at all if you have a rifle or a man trap, but 5 hunters in a party with dogs becomes a force to avoid. Thankfully I never had the misfortune of alerting the landowner, but his thunderous steps were intimidating from the distance I kept between us. Each class of robot has their own strengths and weaknesses, but virtually all of them can be lost by just running in a straight line and ducking behind some cover. So long as your visibility is low they will almost never find you. I found it very interesting that the robots will eventually attack each other. I noticed that groups of hunters will often attack each other, riders, squires, and scarecrows. Although a little confusing, it sometiems works to your advantage when a group of 5 hunters shoot themselves down to 1 and have taken out 2 riders and a trapper.

The narrator is a gem, but a little more could be done with him. His ability to talk to you is never explained nor his in-depth knowledge of the alternate universe you've been accidentally flung into. Nonetheless, more of him would have only added to the charm of the game. I was a little dissapointed by the backstory and ending; they could have been a lot more indepth and provide an atmosphere that better explains and better allows for this alternate universe. There are books spread across the islands with little tidbits of story, but I found those few and far inbetween.

Starting from the easy setting, it took me about 7 hours to make it through the game. After finding all the parts on the center island I would collect all 3 items on each adjacent island and run them back to the center. Each island was a different landscape with a different theme, but as I collected more pieces there were more robots. 

All in all this was a cute game that I enjoyed playing, well worth the $5 I paid for it when it went on sale. It has some decent replayability to test out harder settings, but i look forward to any future updattes the game might see. Since the story and ending will be the same every time, it may be a while before I choose to play again.

Exploitables (Possible Cons):
-Saving the game does not save the robots. Saving at either the center rock or a boat and then immediately loading the last save point will erase all the robots and reset their spawn allowing the player to make a mad dash to find the next piece. 
-If a machine piece is surrounded by enemies, just find a cozy spot with 0 visibility and wait for another group of hunter to come through and shoot up the place. Normally they do a good job defeating the other classes (squires and riders hardly fight back at all) and leaves the player to take out the 1 or 2 survivors who are at lowered health.
-Hiding is too easy. A patch of grass can hide you completely and have a squad of hunters walk directly in front of you without ever being alerted. The only exception is the rider who will see you from his vantage point attop his robot horse and run you over repeatedly until you sprint away. You think the fastest robot in the game would be able to chase you, but they don't. At least not very far.
-Robots need an invitation to shoot you. When a robot spots you it will make a little beep and take aim. Hide or croutch, lowering your visibility, and it forgets it ever saw you. You can juggle a hunter by doing this, letting him see you, hide, let him see you, hide, and so on. This works especially well to pick off the last person in a line of hunters by having the others continue on while your target can't decide what to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044915388', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1597607975}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069587184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 775, 'last_played': 1401858462}
review:
I've read a bit of the other reviews for Sir, You are Being Hunted and as far as I can see, they are pretty spot on. The good reviews show the good sides of the game while the bad reviews show the bad sides of the game. Most importantly, many of them are incredibly truthful, althought this game gave me a fun challenge for a few hours, I'm going to have to give it a negative rating.

Lets start off with the good things about this game!
First of all, the game runs and looks as it was advertised, with all the features the store says it features, but do not expect anything more from this game.

First-person stealth and survival.     Check.
Procedurally-generated British landscape.        Check.
Five biomes to explore: castle, industrial, rural, mountainous, and fenland.            Check.
Powerful, brutal AI that becomes tougher as you play.          Check.
Tea and biscuits.             Check.
Foliage-based stealth system.            Check.
Scavenge to survive.          Check.
Play as Sir or Madam.          Check.
Relentless Britishness.         Check.

HOWEVER.....

Infinite replayability in a sandbox world. 

Now this is where my review gets a little bit on the negative side. The game is infinitely replayable, IF you like playing the exact same game, but a slightly different generated world. Sure the landscape will not be the same, but everything seems the get more and more repetative the more you play the game. Villages become bland and overdone and you see them quite often without much variation besides the occasional big village or small village. Of course the AI acting differently must add some kind of extra replayability right!!??? No. Yes, they have different hunting patterns, but if you play long enough, they dont just become easier to predict the more you watch them, but they become easier to avoid. As said, "The AI becomes harder as you play," is a pretty acurate statement by the devs, except the the fact they don't really get harder, there are just more of the tweed jacket wearing hunters. Max I give the game a few hours of playability before it gets bland and overdone, maximum would be maybe 48 hours of gameplay.

THE NUMBER ONE THING THAT MAKES ME HORRIBLY DISSATISFIED WITH THIS GAME was that it was released with low resolution textures. I mean the textures were REALLY low resolution. They look like alpha placeholder textures that devs put in before-hand to make sure everything runs and looks as it should. The textures have not gotten any updates to clean them up or make them neater and prettier, the game looks nice and all, but everything looks as though it was painted by a four year old with water color paints. ALSO, with all these horrible textures, the game runs like absolute shit! Although it does not run as bad as another MAJORLY disappointing game, Starforge, it runs worse than Skyrim, which is saying something because Skyrim is a pretty intensive game to run even with it's high resolution textures. Sure they might try to pass it off as the games artstyle, but at least try to make that excuse convincing and make some good artistic textures.

All in all, Sir, You are Being Hunted is a fantastic game, besides its extremely limited playability and horrible textures. If I had the choice to either by this game or not, having played it, I would choose not to pay $20 for a game that looks and runs badly, that can only be played once or twice. I hope my review helped anyone on edge about buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969605977', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1708, 'last_played': 1445357768}
review:
This game certainly seems to polarise opinion (what game doesn't?(Civ maybe?)), so I write my review based on the fact that you may have similar tastes to mine.  This game has a bucket load of atmosphere, the sound and music particularly are superb and the recent addition of 5.1 surround is tactically important.  Combat is short and brutal.  I still jump when the bots fire their first volley at me.  It's a superb sound.  Not booming hollywood gunshots, more the snap of a 18th century musket.  And being shot in SYABH is a genuinely unpleasent thing to happen.  It absolutly cains your health and unless you find cover quick you will not last long; the screen shakes and rocks, things start to go grey when health is low and your heart becomes audible.  All standard gaming tropes but effective nonetheless.
I found that the stealth is satisfying.  It isn't hardcore stealth.  It's easy to figure out and get right, but it feels fair and believable and it requires a fair amount of patience and observation.  I think the most important thing about this game is that, like Mario, the game never feels broken.  You never get spotted, or killed and think "screw this, that shouldn't have happened, this games broken".  It's ALWAYS your fault.  Or you got unlucky.  Either way it feels fair, and in this kind of game (indeed any game but particularly this kind), that is important.  The hunger/health mechanic works well, and I like the plethora of objects to loot.  There is a loose backstory, however I have yet to find all the letters and books scattered about.
For me, the most important thing about this game is the setting, theming and atmosphere.  In this regards, this game is an absolute winner.  The gameplay might not be for everyone, but I thoroughly enjoy being hunted by those loveable, ruthless robots.  It's only going to get better once mod support and co-op is introduced (if this happens, and I have heard that it might).  So put the kettle on, grab a packet of Hob Nobs, slip into your smoking jacket and get ready for the most British sneaking experience you are likely to enjoy this year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017619541', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1514192780}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted plays out as a great game. AT FIRST. However, things will go downhill after sometime. Buy this game on a low price and ONLY if you want some short fun.

This game is a survival stealth game, where you have been thrown into a world (This world can be edited somehow before the game) where you need to collect different parts of a machine to get back. There are enemies though and you are given the choice to either avoid them or take them down: Silently or loudly. In the mean time, you have to take care of yourself and scavange for food and shelter.

This game looks interesting at first as the enemies range from infantry to riders. Some are rather fearful so much so that you would rather avoid it than fight them.

However, that is just about it.

Because everything is repetitive afterwards, making the game very boring towards the end as you continue to scavange, hunt, kill and collect pieces. That is what is going to happen after that. Even with the other classes, you will not want to go back and play this game after once. 

I give this game 3/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197979765713', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1675861652}
review:
Despite the mixed reviews I saw for this game, I still went ahead and bought it because of its promise of a free-form, British survival experience.  It turned out to be better than I expected!  The atmosphere is fantastic and it really does feel like Britain especially on a dark drizzly night, crouching in the woods with the moon shining down above you.

While it's definitely not Amnesia (and doesn't try to be), the robots can be genuinely scary, especially when you hear the slow thud of the Landowner bearing down on you.  Which brings me to maybe the best bit about this game - the sound.  It really evokes a dark, 'tweedpunk' future filled with menace.  The first you'll know of the robots is when you suddenly hear their whirring and clanking from behind a hill.  They also come out with some humorous phrases ("I blame the foreigners").

The AI seems pretty good, and the robots will sometimes erupt into firefights amongst themselves, giving you even more ways to outwit them.

This is a game you need to use your mind for as the sandbox environment (and 'British Countryside Generator') provide a pretty much infinite number of situations you can find yourself in.  If you like sandbox games and sneaking games, this is definitely for you.

While this game is very nicely designed from an artistic point of view, the textures can look very plain close up.  I was surprised to learn that the engine used in this game is the same as the one used in The Forest.  However, this really does not detract from gameplay at all, and I especially love the effect of the sun's rays shining through woodland at sunrise and sunset.  It also means that the game is well optimised for slower systems.

Downsides?  If you want a comprehensive survival experience this isn't it.  You can hunt for food and cook it and so forth, but it's not worth it.  You can keep your 'Vitality' topped up by munching on blackberries and drinking tea every now and then and that's really all there is to it.  There's no system of shelter, sleeping or crafting so it's nothing like as deep as other 'survival' games out there such as Rust and The Forest.  It's a 'shallow' survival game, which to be honest is all it professes to be.

Approach this game with an open mind as there is really nothing else like it out there.  It is still being patched currently and I think multiplayer support is still to be added.  It's certainly well worth the asking price and I look forward to seeing what Big Robot can make next. 

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197971297522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1609175683}
review:
OK. Reading some of the comments on this game, I did not expect too much of it. I picked it up on sale for $5 and glad I did.

Pros:

-Large environment to explore.
-Great use of night and day lighting (easier to hide at night than at day)
-Real sense of fear to get caught or seen by one of the robot, making you play stealthy as much as possible and the fact shooting guns makes a ruckus that will always attract more of them to your location encourages you to play that way most of the time. Still, dispatching robots with guns is so satisfying...remember to run away after as other robots in the vicinity will survey the noise you caused.

Cons:

-Buildings can be looted, but you can't enter them. Would've been nice to actually enter a house and loot or hide from the robots.
-Sometimes, the sheer number of robots patrolling an area is makes hiding almost impossible...and the tendency for them to sometimes move towards you even though they should not know your location is kind of suspicious to say the least.
-There is no implementation of stealthy dispatching of the robots (like moving behind them and pressing a quick-action key).
-You have to go back to the stone to unload the repair parts, and limited inventory makes travelling back from Islands to the main one a chore. Also, there should be a few scattered save spots on each island.

I give this game 6/10. With some adjustments, they can make it better I'm sure. Pick it up if it's on sale, not at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962257838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 638, 'last_played': 1405615797}
review: True stealth game. Be warned: if you lack patience, you will hate this game. If you play stealth mode in rpgfps games like deus ex, thief, etc you will love this. Really gives that feeling of a struggle to stay alive and accomplish your mission without being seen. Very basic mechanics and goal, but very enjoyable and immersive atmosphere thus far. Love the fact you can fully customize each stage of progress to make it more or less challenging or unique for different style playthroughs. I can see myself playing this repeatedly once I finish the default playthrough. Have not experimented with the custom terrain tool, but it states it is still very buggy, so I guess I'll wait on that for later. Anyhow, great game so far, the different biomes all have a very unique feel so make sure you have one of each in your playthrough! *rural is pretty boring compared to the others and the starting island is always rural.*

author: {'steamid': '76561197967778193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1476318987}
review:
I picked this game up for $5. 

It's not worth it.

But not for the reasons one may think! The game is a very simple game, with procedurally generated maps and loot 'chests' (the doors of buildings are basically all loot stashes, and you just loot them instead of going into the building), and some good AI for the robots that are always trying to kill you.

On the one hand, I often found myself bored as I trudged through empty fields, seeing nothing and becoming lost all the time.

On the other hand, when I was finally able to defend myself, figuring out ways to combat the often overwhelming bot force became very fun and action packed. So much so that when I was inevitably killed, I felt like playing again (after a bit of a cool down, thanks to my temper lol).

Normally, I'd say this easily merits the $5 tag I picked it up for... but for one word: Glitches.

Did these developers test their damn game before releasing it?! I have CONSTANTLY been running into three specific glitches that make the game unplayable.

Glitch 1: My inventory mysteriously vanishes- yet I cannot place items into it, or remove items from it (or try to use any of the few items that do show up).

Glitch 2: The boats in between islands mysteriously dissapear, thus stranding me on the island I am currently on.

Glitch 3: My most hated of all glitches- randomly (though it likes to do it more when I get shot), the entire game will vanish, leaving behind nothing but a colored blur that you can tell is the layer behind the clouds above. I still have access to my hud, and can even open my inventory (but not use items), but everything else is gone. no buildings, no weapon in hand, no clouds, and no ground. It's just blank. I can hear when i use my weapon, and even still take bleed damage (but cannot be shot or hurt otherwise), but anything else (including enemies) just dissapear, and never come back.

After the 5th or 6th time of this occurence, I have decided to give up on this game. Please try harder next time, devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979795898', 'num_games_owned': 656, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1405212025}
review:
I'll give this game another try when it's further in development. Currently it offers a giant empty world that you move through EXCRUCIATINGLY slowly, even at a run, punctuated by robots that kill you in a couple of shots, won't stop chasing you if they see you, and summon more robots on death. Also the controller options are broken, so although it says "full controller support", it can really only be played with KBM.

I think the premise is great and has a lot of potential, and this game's on its way to realizing it, but it's not there yet. Hopefully it will be someday.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116208480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1639188162}
review:
Alright, so.  Having already acquired half of the Stones, (of which are 18 BTW,) I think I should be able to write a decent review on this title.  Let me start by saying this:

Unique.  Yup.  I've played a lot of games, and nothing is quite like this one.  YOU are being the one hunted, and boy are you ever; those robots are EVERYWHERE.

The robots, being CPUs, have really good AI.  They aren't just idiots who, when seeing you run behind a corner, completely forget about you and walk off.  No.  They will search wherever you were last, and then some.  An interesting mechanic is that you can use trains, rocks, clocks, and glasses to distract said robots.  Using this technique, you can even trap them.

At first, getting a gun can be hard work.  Then you have bullets... Sometimes, there will be a small village with around six mags of bullets, each of which includes 6 bullets.  And then other times, you won't be able to find any bullets for an hour or more.  So don't expect this to be a war zone with guns blazing... well, not YOUR guns blazing, anyway.  

After that, you have to remember to watch your "Vitality" bar, or hunger bar.  This does not deplete fast, but the more it's filled, the faster you regain health.


So, overall, what do I think of this game?
Very unique, with a pleasant art style and decent game mechanics.  Robot AI is quite smart, and there is a wide array of different kinds of robots.  Being a survival game, there are lots of survival mechanics and good stealth mechanics as well.  I HIGHLY recammend this, though for the $20 price, It's steep, but with a replay value, worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064408197', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1644264148}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a brutally underappreciated stealth game, with procedural generated terrains and bursting with charm out of every seam. 

Although it took me a fair few goes to actually get the gameplay, the dynamics of each enemy type, and utilising the mechanics, it did become easier to navigate and play through this world. One thing I would say as well is that you should go into this game blind, because the atmosphere and the unknown really do elevate this game into one of the best stealth games out there.

It also has multiplayer and a potential remaster on the way!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025093178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1664196101}
review:
Do you like stealth games? Do you like robots? Do you like -punk universes? If at least 2/3 of your answers are yes, you should get this game! I've been playing it since it was early access and feel like the devs have managed to balance every item and robot type very well, and you can tweak stuff in the options to suit your tastes.

Some initial reviews say that you don't really feel as hunted as the name suggests, and at the time that was true. The robots spent much of their time with the teleporter fragments you're gathering, largely allowing you to set the terms of the confrontation. In the full release, however, the devs have upped the number of robot patrols and depending on how your island generated, you really can't get too far without having to duck in the grass, the bushes, the woods or behind a structure. There's gentleman robots looking for you all around. There's trappers in the woods / bushes. There's bots ready to stalk you on the fields. Every environment (but not every island type) has its own special hunters, and some hunters look for you all around. Lucky for you, some of the bots don't get along and will fight when they encounter each other, allowing you a chance to escape or get some loot when things die down. There will usually be some at the fragments too, since the bots know you will be coming to get them sooner or later.

With the variety of enemy types and starting equipment, beautiful environments that are randomly regenerated each time you start a new game, different options to customize your game (even removing all the enemies if you just like to walk around) Sir is an excellent choice for the stealth enthusiast. The graphics aren't to everyone's tastes, and the open world environment with its own stealth mechanics might rub some of the fans of the genre the wrong way. Personally, I adore the look and the mechanics, but these are the gripes others have repeatedly expressed and which seem to be dragging the metascore down.

TL;DR: Stealth is cool, robots are cool, tweedpunk is cool - Sir, You Are Being Hunted is cool. Buy and enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029403101', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1549779576}
review:
A quite enjoyable game... Survival at its best... Only without the zombies (which is quite refreshing).

I'm not sure if there's some form of backpack item to expand the inventory, because the gems one needs to recover in order to win, take up nearly half of the available carry-space... Which is my only complaint should there NOT be a backpack to be found somewhere in the procedurally generated islands.

I seriously felt hunted by the robots, so much in fact, that the feeling persisted even when I closed the game.
Paranoid me? nah! The game is simply very immersive.

I love the graphics also, cartoony, yet very well rendered... and I should know, I'm a 3d artist. ;)
