author: {'steamid': '76561197966792440', 'num_games_owned': 907, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1405136975}
review: Honestly, just boring. Run around island looking for smoke that indicates scavenger hunt pieces. Either chuck a bottle to distract or just kill the couple guards at the piece. Collect it. Repat until island is clear. Run back to start, deposit pieces. Repeat with the other islands. The various enemies really aren't that interesting and are easily avoided. If you do get spotted, you can just outrun things until they fall far enough behind. There's no real sense of fear at any point. The classes are pointless because it's so easy to find plenty of items that what you start with hardly matters. The only items that are really useful to have as early as possible are any kind of gun and the map. I did one playthrough, beat it in ~2h with one death 5 mins in while I didn't have a gun yet. I saw no reason to drag myself through another game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004211063', 'num_games_owned': 1751, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1636082360}
review: I really loved my first experience with this game. It just oozes personality and the dark tone is right up my alley, across from the dumpster, and next to the comatose homeless person. The minimal voiceovers from the robots are great; they made me wish the protagonist had some dialogue as well. "Bother, I do believe they are shooting at me!" I have one negative comment, but it is not necessarily a complaint: this game is butt-ugly. Even if the game had been released a decade ago, it would still be tough to look at. The interface and the menus have some charm, but overall the environments and animations are just crude at best. Yet, the drab visuals somehow contribute to the Victorian-era setting and historical overtones. (I'd like to see the Atari 2600 version.) Just goes to show that looks aren't everything. Overall I was immediately hooked by this game and I look forward to playing some more!

author: {'steamid': '76561197964787349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1405355603}
review:
Took around 2 minutes to generate the world.  Survived for roughly 5 minutes once the game started.
The two minutes of watching the loading screen was way more enjoyable than what happened after.  

Some sort of tutorial, or explanation of what the hell is going on, would be nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141195856', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1486530466}
review: So I went into this game hoping for a little indie art some probably mediocre gameplay, I've played this for a couple hours now and I LOVE the game! The gameplay is fun and exciting, the audio is fantastic, and there's a ton of little things that make this game a winner- such as the wildlife acting as a warning mechanism for careful players. The day and night system is fantastic and I love the semi-serious, semi-comedic routine of the narrator and the action in general. Well done devs and absolutely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056323131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1642629667}
review:
Fresh breath of air. When people think of "Survival games" first thing that comes to mind is those zombies. In SYAB, they said fuck the zombies, we go with british robots. The game's stealth is pretty basic but works fine. Scavenging is cool, the robots are really neat looking and a bit silly. The atmosphere is just perfect and fits the game amazingly.

Only thing I have against this game, it's that it can get a bit repetitive if you get too much ammo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046773892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1405113519}
review:
This game isn't terrible but it could use a lot more work, like most Early Access games.  Good base plan: survive in open world where your only real goal is to escape.  I've always wanted to resident evil game like that, where you randomly find lickers and tyrants in the city and can run or fight.  Back to topic...  Good plan, lazy execution.

First, you can't go inside of buildings.  Just one question... Why?  In an area full of evil robots (or any enemies searching for you) crouching in the 2nd story window of a house and shooting down or throwing a bomb would feel great!  I understand this game is about being sneaky and hiding if you can, but that's even more reason to be able to go in building.  The general world doesn't have too great of hiding spots.  You need buildings to hide in and jump to and from just to get around anywhere that has more than one robot.

Second, any robot with a gun deals so much you are lucky to survive and patch yourself from the first shot.  Then, even if you do survive, you can't (to my knowledge) put bandages on your hotkey bar.  So, you can't instant patch yourself, meaning you have to pause and do it while they are still chasing you or else you will bleed out in about 10 seconds.  God forbid you get hit in a field or an area with nowhere great to hide, because you will get shot and killed while trying to bandage yourself.

Next, minor complaint: I do wish it was true open world.  I mean that the islands were all loaded with a render distance enabled.  Having to teleport from boat dock to boat dock is a little lame feeling.  I want the moment of running from robots, hopping on a boat and sailing out while ducking in to the boat and barely escaping in to the sea.  Then having the excitement of finding a new island and trying to find a safe place to dock.

I'm pretty good about going on for a really long time when reviewing games, so I'll cut it here, but I just have to say: Good start.  Great idea with the possible escape to try and give the open world genre some feeling of meaning, unlike games like minecraft which, while very fun with friends, can get dull fast when you realize all you are looking forward to is fighting a very laggy dragon that clips through blocks, to get an egg that does nothing.  But if this game wants to be remembered it needs to open it's doors (literally) and brouden it's scopes.  Also, not sure if this is a thing, but it would be cool if you could use hotair balloons you shoot down.  Patch them, etc.  Then be able to fly anywhere with them (again requiring a true open world).

author: {'steamid': '76561197994477634', 'num_games_owned': 1009, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1466054573}
review: If you want to use an old, rusty trombone to lure a trio of robots into a courtyard full of landmines, then this game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061764403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1437143673}
review:
You do nothing more than find loot, kill robots and recieve some stones. It is extremly easy to survive because you find food in every house and you will know whats coming. It is eighter a forest or a house. The game is also no online and extremly limited of weapons. You can't swim because a stupid robot moster try to kill you, so you can't swim to another island or something. You can choose to start with a gun. It is sad when a game with so much potential, fails so hard that i have stopped playing it. The atmosphere btw is good and the robots is actually a little smart, but that means shit when all other things fail so bad. So the score i give it are:

3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025511855', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1407225121}
review: Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a must buy for fans of the survival genre. It has a completely different feel to any other game i have played and each problem you will come across in the randomly generated landscape has various ways that you can go about solving it. It is an incredibly humorous game that will still keep you pleasantly terrified. Go buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053155440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1467988541}
review:
A lovely little incredibly British survival game. It has engrosing atmosphere, simple(ish) gameplay, an appealing art-style and unique setting, which is underexplored in my opinion - The British countryside.

It's simple and complex at the same time... I love it.


Yes, this review makes no sense, I know.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050726492', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1438130508}
review: Very LOOOOOOOONNNNNNGGGGG game to play which mostly involves you trying to find fragments that are being babyguarded by 2 or more robots, making it extremely hard to actually get the fragment. The stealth aspect is GREAT in this game, and when you first play it, it is quite terrifying. But this effect wears out quickly and soon hiding from robots becomes quite boring and the game starts to feel impossible with the huge army of robots hunting you 24/7. Although difficult, I really have to say that the idea was great, but it lacks in horror.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964267969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1447803435}
review:
Tweedpunk for people who want S.T.A.L.K.E.R.y scary sneaky stealth survival scavenging s...gameplay. It's funny when you find alarm clocks and trombones more useful than firearms.  It plays kind of like a hybrid of Don't Starve and FPS sneakers. The procedural landscape generator is neat for exploration fans and the lonely hostile atmosphere is excellent. The difficulty of the world ramps up as you progress and more twisted robot surprises join the hunt. 

It's not an AAA-budget title, so some people might be disappointed by compromises like you can't enter buildings, only loot them from outside. At full price it might not appeal to everyone but discounted it's a very nice grab. Apparently it's going to get multiplayer modes in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111401720', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1449871444}
review: I would like to preface this by saying that I had been looking forward to playing this game for a long time before I had purchased it. Gameplay looked smooth in the trailer, but I could not get it to run smoothly even on the lowest graphical settings, which were very poor. The game is very poorly optimized, and is a long way from being playable. The only voice in the game is very badly recorded, and gave me a headache. This game has the makings to be fun, but it still needs a ton of work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090519816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1514441622}
review:
This game is awesome, a little pricey and slow loading, but amazing nonetheless. Sir runs well, even on poor computers, has an extensive landscape, and wicked difficult gameplay. Don't work fast enough and you will be meeting swarms of robots when you don't even have a gun. It's the type of game where you can control almost every facet and detail within and still have an amazing playthrough. I cannot say enough about this game.

As mentioned, the game has some loading issues, and that is only because it generates the worlds as you tell it to. When creating a new game it takes roughly five to ten minutes till the intro and gameplay begin. And as for the price, just wait until discount day and it will be more than worth it. 

Cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974139955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1404678029}

review: At first glance, it's not much - but underneath it's tweed-punk exterior lies an awesome trial of wits and cauculation. Throw all your afternoons into it and see how much you can learn as a robot hunter and explorer... Or die trying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000378204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1404673935}
review:
I woudn't recommand this game if you're hoping for a long game. There's not much replayability here, even with the worlds randomly generated. You've played once, you've seen nearly everything.
But nonetheless, the short time you play is quite nice. The feeling of survival and of being hunted is incredible. The graphics seem poor but set up a brilliant atmosphere, reinforced by extraordinary sound effets.
So clearly it won't please every player, but if you'd like a short trip to a beautiful british countryside, hunted by robots, hiding in the tall grass and exploring to find these bloody last three pieces of the machine that will let you escape this hell, you're in for a nice time.
Oh, and beware the scarecrows.

Je ne recommande pas ce jeu √† ceux qui chechent un jeu qui les occupera longtemps. Sir, you are being hunted manque singuli√®rement de rejouabilit√©, m√™me avec le territoire g√©n√©r√© al√©atoirement. Une partie (√† peu pr√®s trois heures) suffit √† tout voir ou presque.
N√©anmoins, le peu de temps pass√© √† jouer est vraiment agr√©able. On a bien l'impression d'√™tre traqu√© et l'aspect survival est tr√®s pr√©sent. Les graphismes ont l'air foireux quand on voit les screenshots, mais ils sont parfaits pour instiller une ambiance oppressante et terriblement british. Les effets sonores sont extraordinaires aussi et contribuent pour beaucoup √† l'ambiance.
Alors clairement, √ßa ne plaira pas √† tous les joueurs, mais si vous √™tes tent√©s par un petit voyage dans la campagne anglaise, chass√© par des robots ridicules mais impitoyables, cach√© dans des hautes herbes et explorant des iles pour d√©couvrir les trois derni√®res pi√®ces qui vous aideront √† r√©parer la machine qui vous permettra de vous √©chapper, alors pr√©parez-vous √† un d√©licieux moment.

review: Very promising game coming along quite nicely if I say so myself. It has quite a feeling of lonelyness and dare I say the feeling of being hunted. Every decision you make is like a risk and it feels like the more you play the more danger arrives.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005966913', 'num_games_owned': 544, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1404505242}
review:
This days so many survival games. Half of them with cubes, half of them with zombies or mutants. 

This game give us original world, where you should survive versus hordes of robots with different skills and abilities. You have also various traps, weapons and alarms, to distract enemy and take what you need without problems.

As a bonus to image of England with typical English items like teapots or whiskey, there are plenty interesting stuff, like books and letters that dive you deep into this world and this story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983206748', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 225, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1444689979}
review:
This game is about being dropped on an island to find some randomly placed stuff whilst not being killed by starvation or patrols. It's not about being hunted, the AI is simply patrol based, they chase you for a while when you trigger them. I love stealth and so forth, but the gameplay is poorly executed and irritative at best. The robots sound terribly annoying. 

The only positive remarks I have about this is that it's indie, it's RPS-related, it's creative and it's cheap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024565484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1599416347}
review:
So I figured I would come back to this game and re-do my review, now that it's not being updated any more and I hadn't properly played it since shortly after coming out of early access. I've now done two full playthroughs on Aristocrat difficulty. 

At first I was surprised by how divided some people were about "Sir...", and in retrospect I can sort-of see why. The lack of building interiors, simplistic stealth mechanics, small weapon roster and lack of world building outside of the basic premise could all be seen as negatives.  

That said, I think the last of these points is the only one I found actually a bit disappointing. The scattered letters and books found in the houses/giant-loot-crates were amusing and interesting to find, but it felt like it needed a bit more. Also, although I like the procedural generation for replay value, there was some noticeable jank in the form of buildings spawning in the sea, the Land Owner "boss" getting stuck in trees etc. Though these were mostly just a bit funny rather than actually impeding progress. 

Anyway, I maintain that the gameplay loop is still a fun mixture of stealth and a bit of guerilla warfare. Fighting back is often dangerous and cumbersome, but makes it more satisfying when you pick the right moment and come out on top, telebit in hand. I also liked the fact that not all the robots are out to get you, and that they can sometimes turn on each other; made it all feel more "alive". The multi-tonal beep-booping of your pursuers sometimes plays tricks on you, I found myself imagining I could hear them when there were none nearby and even started hearing them in the real world! 

If there was one big thing I wish they'd added it would probably be more opportunities to save the game than just the standing stones and boats. Perhaps at the bonfires used to cook things (a la Dark Souls)? Sometimes you'll expend a lot of time, energy and items trying to get just one or two telebits (especially late in the game - one time I had the Land Owner, a rider, scarecrow and about four hunters all around one telebit!), and running all the way from one side of the island to the other to make sure you don't lose all that progress can be taxing. Since updates are finished, I'll leave that as a warning for new players! 

The atmosphere generated by the Tim Burton-esque scenery and spooky lighting give its mechanical "tweedpunk" inhabitants an extra dose of menace, and their quips about the weather, how obscenely wealthy they are, how great Britain is etc. add humour and even a dash of political commentary (indeed, you could say the whole thing is an analogy of something like fox hunting - we don't see any foxes running about, but the player fits the role!). Overall I think the game looks great, and the music is non-intrusive and oddly soothing at times.  

I do think the very specific cultural referencing makes "Sir..." rather niche, and may have had an impact on its reception as those who didn't relate to that side of it were less won over by the gameplay mechanics. This is a game where its strong presentation is what sets it apart from the deluge of stealth-survival titles we've seen in recent years. So I would still recommend it on those grounds, but don't expect anything revolutionary under the hood.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025367310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1402103919}

review: Sir, You Are Being Hunted has quockly become one of my favorite games in my steam library because it is just absoulutly brilliant! With its amazing humor and its ability to make moments very tense this game is deffinatly worth it if you are even a slightest bit intrested! I give it 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198105205197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1415669344}
review:
The game details say "Full Controller Support". This game has anything but. Using a controller the controls are at best awkward, and at worst make the game unplayable. The only controller option is "Enable controller", and if you want to tweak the controls they're all listed as keyboard keys. (So if you want to change the controller settings you're in for a lot of headaches and guesswork.) 
Now I know some PC gaming purist is going to say, "Why don't you use a keyboard? It's the superior input method." Keyboard gaming is horribly uncomfortable and I can play for about fifteen minutes before my arm feels like its about to snap off.  
The game looks like a lot of fun. I honestly wouldn't know whether or not it is because Ive been fumbling around with the controls for the past hour. This is not worth the headache.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994134338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1654081542}
review:
The standard control scheme, when you start the game first, is utterly garbage, and if you don't modify the game, I joke you not, this game is unplayable. The standard controls are some kind of design created for an absolute masochist, with four hands, and three keyboards. You will not have any idea at all of the scope of the game, the usefulness of certain items, their value, the availability of resources, until at least half an hour into a game. If you have the patience of a Saint, this is the game for you. Forget walking Simulator, this is Crouch-walking simulator. Moving at the speed of a particularly slothly snail, hiding in cover as the robots hunting you pass you by, because there is absolutely no reason to kill enemies in this game. You will rarely, if ever, pick up any more ammunition for your weapony, that is if you find any weaponry at all. I got an axe at one point, but in order to use it, you have to sneak up on your foe... who walks faster than you can crawl. Enemies tend to stand still for approximately the amount of time it takes between you dropping a glass in a restaurant and the entire place going quiet, and will kill you in the amount of time it takes for someone to clap or whistle in congradulations for dropping said glass, if you so much as stray an inch out of their exact 180 mark. 

This was one of the biggest let downs I have ever encountered, as I've been following it since this game was even announced, and the delivery thus far has been plain insulting for the price demanded. 

If you really, really, really want to play this game, don't let me stop you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070046768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1444251078}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028873725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1631016051}
review:
I love this game. It‚Äôs one of two games I wanted to play just on the strength of a preview video, the other was TF2. I guess that means I like solid gameplay dressed with quirky character and environment designs.

It‚Äôs a stealth game where the odds will be increasingly stacked against you as the game progresses, and there is no quick save (though there are save points). In other words it doesn‚Äôt spoon feed you or hold your hand. 

The only edge you have is being able to run much faster than [i]most[/i] of your potential pursuers and good cammoflage. Any other edges you may feel you require, you will have to chisel out yourself with your fingernails.

The AI is well coded, plan badly and you will be chased for zig-zagging miles while you try to throw your pursuer and keep your health intact. You can aslo try to induce the AI to fight amongst itself a lot of fun if it works.

So to summarise I'm not even going to qualify with "for an indie game" when I say this is a great game, but rather it's a great game full stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989091266', 'num_games_owned': 733, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1703370276}
review:
[i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i] almost passed under my radar.  It's quirky name and decidedly tongue-in-cheek "maximum Britishness" approach made me think it was going to be too much gimmick and not enough game.  I am happy to say that was not the case.  [i]SYABH[/i] (what an acronym) is a solid game that perfectly captures the appeal of the stealth FPS genre, but with its own unique ambiance and the added boon of high replayability thanks to random map generation.

To be more specific about the gameplay, [i]SYABH[/i] seems to combine a lot of elements from other stealth (or stealth-optional) shooters into one attractive result.  Combat plays out a bit like [i]Deus Ex[/i], of all things: crouching is the key to being unobserved, enemies won't detect you if you're not in line of sight, and sometimes the best choice in combat is to simply leg it.  Inventory management is also a bit like [i]Deus Ex[/i], certainly with the grid-based "you have X slots" system, but the use and variety of items is more reminescent of [i]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.[/i], especially with the game's focus on looting and storage.  [i]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.[/i] also comes to mind with the game's health and vitality (read: food) system, along with the possibility of bleeding from injuries and the necessity to stop said bleeding with bandages.

As for the ambiance, it's very tongue-in-cheek humorous while also retaining that real sense of danger and, dare I say it, horror at times.  Some enemies can and do strike fear into your heart if you see them under the wrong circumstances, which in this game is more often than not.  Above all though this game is very, very British.  The robots look British, say British things, and act British.  I once caught a hunting party stopping mid-field to have tea before continuing on.  It's the little touches that make this game charming, some of which I'm sure I'm missing because I'm not British myself.

Difficulty wise, I've found this game pretty decent.  Early on the game is easy for anyone experienced with stealth combat, particularly for [i]Deus Ex[/i] players.  The basic robot variant is fairly easy to take on in combat if you're sneaky, and will even reliably miss you at close range so long as you're circle-strafing.  Once more variants start showing up though, or even simply start appearing in more numbers, things definitely get more challenging.  Certain combinations and/or numbers of enemies are definite "run away only" situations no matter how much firepower you've managed to scavenge, and just sprinting across the landscape in the hopes that you won't get shot too much simply won't work anymore.  You have to think, observe, and plan in order to make it to the end of the game, picking your battles where you can.  It's a reasonable difficulty ramp, and one you can tackle more or less at your own pace, since it seems to be tied to how much of the game's central fetch quest you've completed.

Overall, [i]Sir, You Are Being Hunted[/i] is an enjoyable game that manages to amuse in one second and induce very real tension and even a touch of fear in the next.  Anyone who likes the sort of stealthy resource-reliant looting-with-optional-combat type gameplay seen in [i]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.[/i], [i]Deus Ex[/i], and countless other titles will find that same part of their game brain satified by this, and the randomized and adjustable nature of the game makes it highly replayable.  If that sounds like your kind of game, then it's well worth the modest asking price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058567129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1409956338}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023785211', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1462061686}
review:
Can't say I was too impressed about this title. Was expecting some cool stealth and survival gameplay on randomly generated maps (which sounded. altogether, quite cool)... What I got was more like a hide in the bushes until the robot get past you and don't even think about silently knocking them down (you just can't!). Survival was more like "go to that house/barrel container and loot the pile of useless junk". You sometime get some food or ammo but pretty much everything else is, as the game itself point out, junks!

Now the random maps... They are more like small random island. Five in total with boats that "load" the closest one when used. Terrain is mostly flat and uninteresting. Some wild animals and cool sunsets add to the otherwise boredom of the landscape. Was expecting more: hills, cave, large town, resource gathering... Textures are quite ugly and low resolution as well, which does not help. GPU was reporting using about 350-400 MB of DRAM. Not very 2014ish.

I do not recommend this title at all. Unless you want a game to play for like 1 hour and then get to something else, which I did.

review:
best thing ever for survival horror comedy fps and hardcore (unless you tone down the spawn settings)

unless you totally disagree with everything i've just said that is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080923778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1418497859}
review:
This game is great!

The game requires you to find different magical stones for The Device, which I assume takes you away from this godforsaken place. Or it explodes and alerts every robot on the island to turn you into swiss cheese. EIther way, I haven't found out yet.

Another great part of the game is the survival aspect. You must always have food to survive. I don't mean a Dead Rat or some gross spuds either. I mean you must always have GOOD food, or in the game's case a lot of whiskey, otherwise you're living on a timer until your Vitality and Health runs out, killing you.

One the the best things is the stealth required in the game. You can't run up to a group of robots later on in the game, otherwise you're asking to get loaded with buckshot. You must sneak up to them, distract them, or my favorite, use a ManTrap on them, which is simply a beartrap reinvented to hunt you. Also, pay attention to your visibility. Robots can spot you from just looking at you so it's best to crouch when they're near and to get a rock or some other cover between you and your hunters.

Overall, this game is great and has a lot of replayabilty considering you can tweak the world generation and the amount of robots. I also think this game would be great if they had more survival features and it was a challenge to survive without the robots.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198013218345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1528419339}
review:
This was my first venture into the procedurally-generated survival games genre. And I've had a blast!  Graphics are not great, but by no means bad at all.  Good enough to enjoy waltzing/sneaking around the fictitious English country side, trying not to be killed my murderous robots.... who smoke pipes.  

Gameplay is where it's at.  Sneaking and stealth is done pretty well.  If you think it's a good hiding spot, then it probably is.  AI is good without being unfair.  The shooting mechanics are well done also.  In short, give this game a try.  Especially if you like indie games (which I do).

author: {'steamid': '76561198011495777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1543, 'last_played': 1430337178}
review: As of version 1.1, the game still doesn't offer EVERYTHING we might like to see in it (i.e. no multiplayer yet), but it does prove to be a really engrossing experience. The graphical demands are steep: my computer can barely handle it, and I can run most things with ease. This only adds to the ambiance, though, the slightly choppy framerate making it truly dangerous to go toe-to-toe with a robot. Hiding from patrols and waiting for the path to clear, as your character gets hungrier and hungrier, is truly compelling, though. With another patch or two, this game will be excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996595222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1403949318}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041368969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1571863238}
review: Sir, You Are Being Hunted, is aa unique and fun game.  I love the game and would recommend it because it's funny, fun, and it also provides moments where things are very tense.  Getting stuck hiding in grass while there are robots, horses, and dogs sweeping the area, can be nervewracking.  The only things that I don't like about it, are how the dogs can instantly put you down, and as far as I can tell, all you can do is just sit there and do nothing.  The giant landowner is the same way, but he's supposed to be powerful.  I would suggest making the moment when a dog downs you a quicktime event where you shake the mouse.  That way, the player will feel like they're actually doing something, instead of just struggling for nothing.  Aside from that, the game is really fun, and that small problem isn't enough to stop me from loving everything else about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004558873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1425015949}
review: A game of exploration, punctuated by intense moments of survival and thievery. You must be able to enjoy a good walk (Proteus), stop and admire the beautiful scenery (Far Cry 2), and take pride in navigating the world efficiently (again, Far Cry 2).  Games are often about repetition and mastery, but unlike Diable where you'll click-click-click and watch numbers get bigger and perfect your execution, your reward in Sir is a new vista and a new set of obstacles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045786636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1402691064}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031366984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1723, 'last_played': 1597857330}
review:
I really like this game.

I've enjoyed playing this game since day 1.  The gameplay is completely free-form--no being told what to do--and can be quite challenging and tense at times.  Some people have complained about the graphics (I actually like the graphics).  This isn't Crysis, but I believe the gameplay and challenge make up for the visuals.

The downsides of this game are that it can get repetitive.  After I beat the game, I rarely start playing another file.  But it's definitely fun and one of the few times within the past couple years where I truly don't regret a Steam purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037586730', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1402498014}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is the vision of the future if we let mad british scientists loose.

The story in this game is left up to the player to figure out, for the most part. Hidden messages in the randomly generated maps will help you to piece it together if you play enough. But the story isn't the most important part of this game.

This game, because levels are randomly generated, can be either extremely hard or very easy. But for the most part the game has a fairly good difficulty, with enemies becoming increasingly difficult to handle as you spend more time playing. This game is advertised as being a stealth game, but you can choose yourself wether to go down that route or just jump in guns a blazing. Both tactics work well. Some players argue that this should not be the case, but it didn't bother me while playing.

This game can be played with a controller, but I would reccomend sticking with a standard keyboard/mouse setup because it makes inventory management much easier.

The graphics in this game are not to most amazing. They're not bad as such, but they could be made more detailed, especially the "ground" textures. However, the world generator does a good job of capturing what you could call the stereotypical "brittish village" look (amongst other types of land), and when seen from afar, it does look very nice.

The sound in this game is good, the ambiance and such sounds do a good job of immersing you, and it can be very jarring (in a good way) to suddenly hear a robot coming up behind you.

Because things are randomly generated, don't worry about just restarting if you happen to come across a world that places you smack in the middle of an impossible area. The chances of that happening are very low. And if you are finding things too hard or too easy, you can use the newly updated "custom world generators" to swizzle the difficulty.

This is a really fun open-world stealth game, and definitely worth a shot if you like survival horror games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961352342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1401463530}
review:
Sir and/or Madam,

You should consider purchasing this fine entertainment product. I have taken the liberty of personally previewing it myself and can reveal to you its delightful secrets. Simulating an unlikely otherworldly situation, you will be hunted by robots through a series of 5 different and randomly-generated islands designed by the developers to resemble the fine British countryside. The verisimilitude of the setting is quite striking and you will surely marvel at the beauty of the thing while shotgun wielding tin cans try to blast your head off!

There are a variety of things to find in aid of escaping the archipelago including weapons, distractions and the necessary nourishment to see you through the ordeal. You can deal with your hunters in different ways, and must consider stealth and deception a primary means of remaining alive.

There are limitations, of course, and there is perhaps a limit to how many times you might wish to revisit this joyful simulation. There is a chance to define how the islands are randomly generated in the latest retrofitting of the code, but overall once you have figured out how to deal with the problems and accomplish your glorious escape (perhaps after a few lethal mishaps), there isn't much left to draw you back.

Worth the asking price for your own copy, Sir/Madam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969417125', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1432980912}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a stealth exploration game. You've been stranded on a group of small islands, and tasked with finding the scattered pieces of a broken machine, which should help you escape. But the islands are home to strange robots who will attack you on sight.

There are 17 pieces to find, spread across 5 islands whose layouts are randomly generated. They can be identified by a trail of white smoke rising into the air, not high enough to see from behind a building or a hill, but obvious enough that you'll immediately notice if you're looking at it. I like that, instead of just slapping a waypoint marker on each location as some games would do, SYABH trusts the player to actually put some effort in. You might find a scanner that will beep if you're close, but I only had to use it to find the last piece. I found everything else quite easily within 6 hours of gameplay, just by conducting a methodical search.

Along the way you'll need to deal with the various types of robots. To begin with its just a normal human shaped robot with a shotgun, usually hunting in pairs. But over time, more dangerous types start to appear such as robot dogs or robot horse riders. You can decide whether to fight them or avoid them, but you can only save in specific places so you might want to be cautious.

I mostly used the open nature of the islands to keep my distance, only fighting the robots who were guarding the pieces. Guns are not fun to use, they feel slow and weak - probably by design, because the robots struggle with them as well. I had more success by first distracting them either by throwing a bottle or setting an alarm clock, then sneaking up behind and using a powerful axe. Stealth is a tricky thing to get right for me, but I enjoyed this system more than games like Thief or Assassins Creed.

Meanwhile you need to find food, because if your hunger meter reaches zero, your health will start to decrease. If you take damage during combat, your health will automatically regenerate, but only if your hunger meter is high. There is plenty of food available, but you might need to search villages, which are guarded by more robots. Searching buildings can also give various helpful items such as binoculars, matches for lighting a fire to cook raw meat, a map which helps navigation, and more.

Technically the game is solid. Graphics are what you would expect from an indie game, controls are fine on mouse and keyboard, and I didn't suffer any bugs. The most disappointing thing for me was the story. The end was very anticlimactic and failed to really explain anything at all.

Overall I enjoyed SYABH and I would recommend it, if you're looking to play something a bit different to the usual genres.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967992446', 'num_games_owned': 1178, 'num_reviews': 543, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1401721373}
review:
"Wow, this is kind of like Cockney STALKER! Boy, these pastures look like something else! Sneaking around those robots is kind of tense but I want to shoot one in the face now. Oh, hey, here's a gun! And a bunch of ammo! And enough food to keep me going from one end of the island to another! Haha, eat my lead, you British robot bastards! Oh crap, what's that? Better hide from it in this thick brush until I get close enough to shoot it in the face. Meanwhile, I'll just collect these huge plot device things that will allow me to win the game. And dramatically adjust my inventory around them. Still adjusting. Grrr."

REPEAT FIFTEEN MORE TIMES, WIN GAME, FEEL VAGUELY SATISFIED BUT MOSTLY DEFLATED BECAUSE I'VE JUST BEEN TRICKED INTO DOING THE SAME FETCH QUEST SIXTEEN TIMES, GOD DAMMIT.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968511845', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1401834655}
review:
strong indie title, with a "nice" bleak atmosphere, somewhat reminicent of the stalker games, but with a quirky sense of humor.  Its also rock hard like stalker.
Its fun experimenting with stuff like the traps, toy trains, alarm clocks, rusty trombones and what have you to set ambushes for the evil aristocratic robotic overlords.  

If you like games like stalker, theif, dishonoured etc.. give the game a try

if you're expecting a bombastic shooter in the vein of COD, give it a wide berth, it is what it is a steath / survival game.

Mostly bug free, although sometimes the generator makes wonky islands, with buildings half under water and stuff.

some might find not being able to enter buildings an anoyance, though it doesnt bother me,.

Newer updates have added the industrial and castle biomes, new enemies like the scarecrow and the lord of the manor and a class system, which is basicly a difficulty setting giving you different equipment at the start depending on what job you pick.

7/10

review:
This game is an interesting package. It's a stealth/survival game that is both cute and creepy at different times.
Walking through a graveyard at night to the sound of robots nearby is actually extremely eerie.
Even if the robots are cockney hunters puffing cigars and saying 'tallyho'

It's a good time either way.
Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068951842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1405626634}
review: Sir is a gem in the rubble that really deserves a higher metacritic score in my opinion. It achieves exactly what it sets out to do, being a survival game on a unique map each time. The only problem is the TYPE of game that it is. Could be compared to "Slender" in a way, sneaking around baddies while looking for stuff that helps you get out... Just with a lot more things to do. It calls for the right gamer. It is not the average persons cup of tea, because of the lack of story, and no abundance of action or friendly characters to speak of. There isnt a strong sence of staying power either but that is plainly because of the TYPE of game it is. This is why so many players have so few hours, but the hunger for better equipment and finding new robot types is always a blast. The game itself is perfect in my eyes, because they gave people what they asked for. The only flaw is in the type of game, not the game itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030183654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1400066572}
review:
This was original written on my blog, here: http://d-facegames.blogspot.co.uk/2014/05/my-thunks-sir-you-are-being-hunted.html

Many stealth games are somewhat of an illusion. Behind the rock throwing, sneaking and stealth assassinations there is essentially a puzzle game, designed to have a few specific solutions. This is where Sir, you are being Hunted differs, the procedural nature of the game gives you a number of situations without an obvious solution. A patrol of 4 guards doesn't necessarily have a blind spot, so completing the game without ever being seen becomes near impossible. This might frustrate some die-hard stealth fans for obvious reasons, but it feels different and somewhat realistic.

The premise is as so, you're stuck on an island with the task of retrieving 17 MacGuffins from 5 different islands. You must take the 17 items to the standing-stones in the center island to repair the "device". You really don't know anything else except you're being hunted by angry English robots.

The English robots match the theme of the environment; the fens, countryside, industrial areas, castles and forests that you stroll through will be familiar to anyone who lives in or has visited the UK. This may not sound exciting in words, but it really is, no other video-game has done anything in this setting. It's dank, dreary, usually raining and very atmospheric coupled with the ambient music. The industrial area in particular has a certain uniqueness about it, the landscape is littered with abandoned towns, villages, churches, factories and ruins. Something very awful happened in this place, and it's never clear exactly what that may have been. The robots speak a number of stereotypical English phrases even talking about their wives. It's as if the personality of the once residents of these islands has been transferred into each robot.

Unfortunately the awful low resolution textures and procedural generation take you out of the game every so often, certain placements don't make sense with roads leading nowhere, walls connected in strange ways and docks located in very small lakes. However this wasn't a large problem for me considering the world is supposed to be in a state of extreme entropy and you don't have much time to focus on the small details anyway. Why don't you have much time? When the game says you're being hunted it doesn't mean it lightly. With sprawling robots which are around every corner don't give you much rest-bite, you're constantly looking behind your back.

This is the one thing that Sir, You Are Being Hunted absolutely nails, the feeling of being on the run. You will relish moments of silence when you can't hear the sinister "bleep-bloop" of the tweed, pipe and top-hat geared robots. Another stand-out aspect is the enemy design. The basic robots can be seen from far away by their glowing red eyes, and even when they aren't in sight each enemy makes a distinct sound. This is clever because you can often get a good idea of how many robots you're facing without even seeing them. The AI is far from intelligent but I wouldn't call it stupid. Even when it does make the odd silly decision, you aren't taken out of the experience like many other stealth games because they're robots. Maybe that's a cheap excuse, but it works. As the game continues more creative enemies are added to the mix, some which create such weird and terrifying sounds you'll never want to go near them. Robots also have a tendency to shoot pheasants and rabbits for their own entertainment and at my scared confusion, wondering what they were shooting at. This creates an unexpected side-effect, making Sir, You Are Being Hunted quite a scary game at times. Avoiding the outlandish looking robots makes it all the more exciting and horrifying when you accidentally bump into them.

The gameplay consists of finding the 17 MacGuffins by following blue will-o'-the-wisps to each location. This works quite nicely as they don't give you a direct way to the MacGuffin, often taking you a longer way around. However I think there are too many will-o'-the-wisps on the islands at a time, reducing your compulsion to explore. Along the way you will find places to loot such as houses, barrels and sheds. To the dismay of many fans it was announced early in the game's development that you won't be able to go inside houses. While this makes sense for a number of technical and economic reasons, it's an obvious shame. Buildings would add a lot to the game in terms of hiding and exploration. Towns are still interesting though, providing a lot of loot and many places to hide. Each town also has a suitably randomized English name that will probably make you chuckle.

The loot consists of random useless objects (of which there are far too many), food, drink, tools, traps, weapons (both melee and ranged) and letters (which provide a bit of context). There is a vitality meter also which you have to keep topped up by consuming food and drink. If you let it drain to 0 your health will start to deplete, in addition to this the lower your vitality is the less quickly your health regenerates. This is never anything to worry about though, in my first playthrough it never went below 20. You can also cook pheasants, rabbits and raw meat on a fire with the disadvantage of the fire attracting robots. But this never becomes a necessity because there is simply enough food that you can eat uncooked.

I did find myself lacking in bandages a few times though. Some of my most tense experiences actually came from those moments when I had no bandages left. I was a sitting duck, getting seen was much more of a consequence, I couldn't risk getting shot, even once. Interestingly enough there is also quite a big chance that robots drop bandages. Giving me a few interesting situations where I risked my bullets for the chance to get a bandage. Despite those moments however there were still far too many bandages, and far too much food for these systems to be of much of an impact. I am happy to role-play a little but some players might resort to charging around the landscape chugging whiskey and eating biscuits, using the health regeneration to tank gunfire.

That said, there is still a great deal of intensity when it comes to fighting robots. Unlike food, bullets are very rare, weapons have lengthy reload times and shooting accurately isn't easy. There was one memorable point where I managed to take out two robots with a hatchet without taking any damage, I had a gun but I wanted to save the bullets. Considering you can't save whenever you want the stakes of dying are quite large too. You can only save at the standing stones where you drop off the MacGuffins and the boats which you use to travel to the different islands. There is a big risk reward element to this system. Either I can grab a MacGuffin and head straight back to a boat to save, or I can save time and head around the island and try to get as many MacGuffins at once. Even though death is usually the players fault your patience is still tested whenever you die, as you are required to do the same thing all over again. Throughout I couldn't help thinking a different save system would work better.

When you come across a MacGuffin there are a few options to get your grubby hands on it. You can throw a bottle to distract the robots near-by, mess it up however and those robots will run to you rather than where it smashed. Alarm clocks are the most effective, hide it somewhere, set the timer and wait for it to go off. Once the guards find it they'll realize it's a trick but usually that gives you enough time... 

Continued on my blog (as steam didn't give me enough space): http://d-facegames.blogspot.co.uk/2014/05/my-thunks-sir-you-are-being-hunted.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198033526935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1449918154}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971269384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1399899555}
review:
Sir, You Are Being Hunted is a relatively cheap indy open-world shooter. While the gameplay is somewhat repetitive, it is too short to outstay its welcome too much. 

At its heart SYaBH is a stealth game and you won't survive for long if you use your weapons too much. In this game, as the title suggests, you are the quarry. For those that enjoy permadeath, I think this game is well suited to it. Such an approach would no doubt add grist to the extended-play mill. 

While I quite enjoyed SYaBH, it could potentially have been a very, very good game, and the developers seem to have settled for a game that is okay to good. Various interesting items and opponents appear in the game that add to the variety, but after the first couple of hours, careful players will learn how to keep out of trouble. From then on it's just a matter of going through the motions. Nothing happens that really shakes things up. There is no second (let alone a third) act to this game. 

Like Betrayer (which I also reviewed recently, and to which this game bares some similarity) this game has oodles of flavour and atmosphere, but not a lot of variety. Unlike Betrayer, SYaBH makes your goals clearer and there is a little bit more to be found on the islands. There is also a lot more humour in this game. While Betrayer was a very pretty looking game and SYaBH falls a little short in that regard, the graphics are more than adequate to create the 'baskervillian' moors. 

Verdict: If you like sandbox (or stealth) games, you are a bit of an anglophile and the game is on special, give it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005215285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1401083064}
review:
I really like this game a lot.  Super different.  

The environments and ambience are beautfully done.  The gameplay is open-ended in a way, and you have to figure things out as you go.  I think that the reviews of this game are quite silly being that it isn't trying to be Day Z or Rust or something...it's a game.  

I think it's worth a go for some late night romping.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995030737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1399227067}
review:
I was excited to play this as I remember reading about it on RPS years ago and saw that it had just reached v1.0.

Sadly, it feels completely unfinished right down to the crackling badly recorded voice of your butler.  It essentially boils down to a walking simulator with some extremely poor combat thrown in.  The environments are ugly and featureless, there is no crafting or any reason for half the available items to be in the game at all.

Maybe v2.0 will be worth playing, will uninstall until then.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970380426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1400538312}
review:
I was bored in the Alpha... and let it go.  When version 1.0 was released, I decided to see where the game went.  I LIKE IT!  After I obtain an Oculus VR, this is going to be one of the first two games I really want to play while using it (Skyrim is the other).  The balance of the game is much better.  It can be very challenging and rewarding.  While it is better to be patient and plan your moves, you are at the mercy of your food supply.  The save system is great as it doesn't allow for a save, die, load, cheat pattern.  

The stealth is pretty good... however the only way to know you limits is to push untill a robot beeps that lets you know they heard or saw something.  If you stay still and in cover, they'll keep walking.  My constructive criticism of this game is that it's tough to understand just how stealth you are.  There is a visibility meter with an eye that gains rings as you become more visible.  They eye goes away completely when you are completely hidden.  The rings are sort of ambiguous.  They only way I see it is that you are invisible, a little visible, or visible.  Now sure what the difference between 2, 3 or 4 rings really does as far as just what the robots will notice.  Is it based on distance as well?  It's hard to tell... you do get a pretty good 'feel' for it... which might be the point.  It's not something to compute, but something to feel.  Should I take the risk, am I feeling lucky sort of thing.

Sound you make doesn't seem to equate to much of the visibility meter either.  Seems to be a whole other system of detection that goes unannounced.  I think you can just figure if you can hear them, they can hear you... sort of.  Makes it hard to just sneak up on a robot.  You're barely visible and they aren't looking in your direction as you sneak up, but all of a sudden they turn and are aiming right at you!  Guess that's the advantage to being a robot I suppose.  Can't wait to see where this game goes. and what improvements they make.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999795539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 938, 'last_played': 1406034139}
review:
Sir/Madam is a creative and unique approach to stealth-based combat in setting, aesthetics, and gameplay. If you like sneaking past guards, looting buildings, or assassining then you'll probably enjoy this. However if you like replaying 20-30 minute sessions because of the rare save points and punish difficulty, then you'll likely get frusterated very quickly. The goal of the game is to scavenge for goodies, avoid starvation and detection, and find pieces of a mysterious device in a five randomly generated environments. 

The biggest problem currently with the Mac verion of Sir is the fairly frequent yet unpredictable crashes every 90-120 minutes. These seem to occur most often in some of the more exotic areas. Being that save points are infrequent, and that there are incentives to not to save often, this gets to be a big problem.

Gameplay-wise the biggest problem is the difficulty. I'm a big fan of high difficulty games, but there is not a large skill ceiling here, so it gets very frusterating even in the early stages. However because of the limited inventory system (and consumable nature of supplies) it is almost impossible to "defeat" the game by "snowballing" large amounts of supplies later on, so while Sir is punishly hard from the beginning, it stays consitent until the end.

Another big problem is the most basic enemy type, (which is also the most common enemy type) a bipedal robot with a shotgun. Having a low tier enemy, or a common enemy with shotgun in a stealth-based combat game is very frusterating. The purpose of stealth based combat is to sneak in close proximity to enemies, either to kill them or get to objectives; but if they have a shotguns, then the closer you get the stronger they get. This creates incentives to battle from a larger distance (which isn't viable), or to avoid combat altogether (which also isn't viable). Getting killed in 1-2 shots from full health is can work if it is clearly your fault, and the stealth detection system works well, just not the inability to deal with enemies regularly.

Bandages are also another problem with Sir, being that when you take damage it is possible to start bleeding out until you die. Bleeding can only be stopped by bandages, which are uncommonly found and very rarely dropped by enemies. This makes combat frusterating because even a low-damage, grazing shot on yourself (especially with the abundant shotgun enemies) can be can be lethal if you don't have a bandage. Or if you use your bandage to stop the bleed, only to get another one put on yourself by the next shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992970282', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1403897449}

author: {'steamid': '76561198084718391', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1443988275}
review:
Absolutely awesome game! I've always been a major fan of sneaking games so when I saw this one I was fairly excited. It came on sale a while back for 10 dollars and I passed it up because it seemed a little pricey still. Well, since then it hasn't been on sale (until now that is). I saw it come up for 17 and couldn't let it pass me up again.

I made the purchase and honestly, I don't regret it. The game is very enjoyable and well designed. It does seem like it could use some optimization though. I don't have a gaming rig by any means. I run an i7 laptop, 8 gigs of ram, and a intel hd 3000 integrated graphics. I can play fairly comfortably on low settings (roughly 30 frames). There are times where I dip into the 20s and even teens but it's not very noticable due to the stealth nature of this game.

What are you missing by running low graphics as compared to high? Well, it seems that high graphics introduce more shrubbery (low grass and the such), more shadow effects, a little more general detail (kind of a given), and a further viewing distance. All these would be nice to have but I defintely haven't found that not having them hinders the gameplay or fun.

If you are thinking of buying this game, just do it! It's a ton of fun! I personally always enjoyed the Metal Gear Solid games due to their stealth element. Sir has brought me a new game in which I can enjoy the stealth element that far to many games ignore today.

A Quick summary of my first playthrough. 
I entered the randomly generated world, and looked around in wonder at the sprawling landscapes before me in every direction. I then ran into the nearest village, and stole all the boots I could find. 
After dodging a balloon, only to be spotted by another balloon, I shot a robot in the face so hard his beard fell off. 
I then hid behind a tree and ate a dead rat, which killed me. 

11/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123388634', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1652092361}
review:
It is night. It is quiet. To quiet. 
Where am I?
Where am I going?
Why?
Who?
When?
I turn around.Nothing.
My gun shakes in my trembling hands.
Then I hear it.
*BLEEP*
No, not like this. 
I see a light shine in my face.
I've been found
*BLEEP*
No.No.No.No.No.No.NO
I run.
I see a town.
I take out my binoculars. More of them. Everywhere.
*BLEEP* 
There is a ringing in my ears.
*BANG*
*BANG... BANG...BANG*
I feel pain in my side. I collapse.
I close my eyes.
I try to remember.
I don't know my name.
Then I hear a voice in my ears.
"Sir...................Hello......are you there Sir?
"Yes i'm here"
"Sir.......*static*..........You.....are-"
"Hello?"
The robots are closing in on me.
*static*
".......Sir..."
*BANG*
I cry out. 
I try to stand. it's getting harder and harder to breath.
I manage to stand.
I limp/run to cover.
It's over I think.
Then I hear it 
"Sir.........you are being hunted."

author: {'steamid': '76561198069738853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 800, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1579763366}
review:
This is an extremely fun game, dispite my computer's hard time running it. (It's pretty old.) That being said, you'd probably want a nicely running computer to play this game, because you'll need the FPS in most parts. It's still playable in my opinion, but it does make it a little more harder.
But I digress... This game is quite interesting to say the least, and since it's a sandbox, stealth game (a couple of my most favorite genres) it'll take a lot of strategy and thought. It's story is pretty cool and it's gameplay is rather smooth. (Except for me and my slow-didlydarn computer.) There are tons of items and weapons to help you against the robots that are attempting to track your every move, but even then, you'd want to try and stay out of their way, especially if there's a big robot or just a bunch of them. I personally think this game is pretty gosh darn awesome and worth checking out. And the best part? This is just the beginning of the amount of things that are gonna be in this, (including multiplayer!) so there's plenty of stuff worth waiting for. 

(BEST REVEIW TAN/TAN I'M SO GOOD YA)

author: {'steamid': '76561198044321843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1447014715}
review: You are a British gentleman being hunted by British gentleman robots, the goal is to find a number of gems scattered across 5 randomly generated islands while also avoiding your robotic enemies. The AI is absolutely ruthless and once they've seen you it will be extremly hard to remain hidden, there's a variety of enemy types so things won't feel very repetive and you will have to use different strategies to get past different sections. You will also have to find food and other resources by scavenging various buildings, if you don't eat you will eventually starve to death. If you're into the stealth genre you might want to give this a try, it is a truly challenging stealth experience that won't hold your hand at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071615810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1587118942}
review: I threw a dynamite and it killed a group of 5 robots in one go. Now some may argue that it was a quick death, but there is no doubt that there is a group of people out there that would definitely question my methods of robot killing. Maybe it was inhumane, maybe robots have a complex mechanism system in place that lets them consciously feel pain and fear, which may be like or unlike the nervous system that we humans have, or maybe the group of robots I killed whom were patrolling the church were actually a friendly group of robots, and I made a terrible mistake by generalising all robots to be savage/mindless drones, and without giving them the benefit of the doubt to explain their humaneness I killed the whole lot of them. Now I will still go on to argue that you can not kill what was not alive in the first place, I'm sure these robots did not function on a conscious basis of awareness in both their existence and life around them, and everything they did was probably out of pre-programmed coding for situationary reactions. But there definitely will be some politically correct robot-abuse advocate out there who will without a seconds doubt scold and judge me for the dynamite incident that I was responsible that day. Now what I'm trying to get at with this whole self-indulgent ponder of a steam review is that I've wasted too much time writing this, and I have no life like these robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106208804', 'num_games_owned': 923, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1013, 'last_played': 1524142766}
review:
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ This is an excellent stealth game. It isn't for everyone, but if you "get it", you will freaking love it. [i]Highly[/i] recommended.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ There isn't really a "story", but just a brief explanation of what's going on: you're stuck on the archipelago and must collect items to rebuild the thing that gets you out of there. The exploration and strategizing ways around the hunters to get what you need [i]is[/i] the game.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ You can't hide in buildings or "save anywhere". Those things may be OK in other games, but they would absolutely destroy the tension in [i]Sir[/i]. (In fact, the saving system in [i]Sir[/i] has inspired me to replay Dishonored using only the autosaves.)
When you load a save in [i]Sir[/i], all of the NPCs appear in different places and configurations from when you saved. You don't "use" saves the way you might in other games. There's no reloading in order to try various tactics against a particular group of hunters.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ If you're a stealth fan, buy [i]Sir[/i] immediately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043065411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1448151187}
review: Having played this game for a few hours, I have found it to be a rather amusing endeavor.  Having to sneak around British robots and their dogs has provided for a couple amusing weekends.  The stealth system implemented is one of the better ones I've come aross.  For the most part the game runs smoothly for me; however, I have had a problem with this game crashing on me as I move between islands.

review:
Sir (ou Madam) You Are Being Hunted Est un jeu de chasse a l'homme ou vous √™tes le chass√©. 
Ce jeu est a mi-chemin entre don't starve et dayz.

Tout comme dans don't starve, votre experience a mal tourn√©, Vous vous retrouvez sur une √Æle avec quatre iles autour (Nord Sud Est Ouest, dont les paysages varieront entre montagne, barriere, rural, chateau et industriel) pour vous √©chappez il vous faudra r√©unir diff√©rents artefact situez sur les iles, sans vous faire tuez par une arm√©e de robots, et les ramenez a l'esp√®ce d'obelisque sur l'ile centrale. 
Et tout comme dans dayz vous devrez fouiller les maisons pour trouver nourriture, munitions, soins, etc, etc, ... 

le principe est g√©nial, mais en application, il y a encore beaucoup de travail, (normal c'est un early access et c'est quand m√™me bien jouable) j'ai h√¢te de voir ce que les diff√©rentes updates vont amener donc pour ma part ce sera d√©finitivement un oui, si vous recherchez une nouvelle experience... N'h√©sitez pas :).

author: {'steamid': '76561197991103051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 252, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1399272260}
review:
Im finally reviewing this since It has officially been launched. 

This is a great idea for a game but leaves A LOT to be desiered. This game still feels like its in beta and the focus seems to be on the gunplay and killing robots instead of the stealth.

I dont like the direction they went with this and being released in this state feels like a lazy cash grab.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054951590', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1444999942}
review:
I really like the idea of this game. It's really thrilling/scary to sneak around in the wilderness with robots hunting you. The only thing that would make this game better is Coop or maybe multiplayer up to 4 players. The game can get kind of boring when walking around completely alone hour after hour...
But overall this game is worth the money!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035935233', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1399261170}
review:
I like the concept of being hunted, but the execution left me disappointed. I expected the rush of being the target of a manhunt, but got a scavenger hunt with a heavy emphasis on inventory management. The procedurally generated worlds look nice, but are often repetitive and mostly empty. Optimizing a limited, grid-based inventory can be time consuming enough to break immersion. Having limited inventory for a game like this is great, but having to reorganize a grid-based inventory to pick up an item when enough space is availabe is annoying (has anyone ever felt like they were being hunted when playing with Tangrams?). Buildings break immersion since they function as treasure chests instead of buildings. (I knew that going into the game and thought it wouldn't bother me, but I was incorrect).

Unfortunately, Sir, You Are Being Hunted fails to make me feel like I am being hunted and breaks immersion too often to maintain my interest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121653451', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1653263089}
review: This game is as fun as the world you get is. Let me explain what I mean, the procedural generation of the world allows for sometimes tense hiding and waiting to find enough ammunition to fight the menace, while other times it will either give you so much ammo that you have to stop being stealthy just to clear some inventory space of rifle rounds. Once I had a world where there was no ammo, no food, and only hatchets. But, thats just the downside of a procedurally generated world, isn't it? the game still stands on its own two feet. If you have twenty dollars and want many hours of fun, get this game. If you have twenty bucks and want another game, then it just comes down to personal preference.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968868964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1399231156}
review:
It turns out that a field of grass isn't a very interesting place to hide.

Although Sir, You Are Being Hunted bills itself as a stealth game, in reality you will spend most of your time avoiding your robotic foes altogether as you trudge over empty hills in search of the macguffins you need to escape the islands. 

This is no accident: interaction has been designed out of the game in several ways.

Foremost is the lack of any player motivation to approach the robots (save for those which guard each macguffin ‚Äì more on that later). The best the game musters is its hunger system, which encourages scavenging the abandoned settlements where robots are more likely to patrol. Alas, early on in my game I shot and cooked two rabbits. This simple task, plus occasional visits to unguarded buildings, led to me finishing the game with enough rabbit in my trousers to feed a poorhouse.

The wide open terrain also works against interaction by giving the player too much information and too many choices. There is [i]always[/i] plenty of warning of approaching bots, and there is [i]always[/i] more than enough space to hide in until they pass. When the player is spotted, running and hiding in the open are both farces.

The game compounds all of this with a thinly-spread checkpoint save system, punishing experimentation and killing curiosity. Developers: please stop doing this.

With the player relegated to an observer it‚Äôs just as well that the bots are fun to watch. Pathfinding AI is robust, with sensible group dynamics, and the designs are imaginative and distinctive riffs on various aristocratic stereotypes.

Procedural island generation is also reliable. Yet despite each biome having one special feature (Castle and Industrial, added later in development, shine in this regard) they otherwise all merge into one brown lump. The slightly different items sprinkled on top aren‚Äôt enough to create anything memorable and it doesn‚Äôt help that they offer no apparent variation in robot behaviour, type or numbers.

Which brings me to the subject of pacing. Here it is in one sentence: the more macguffins you collect, the more robots there are. You will otherwise finish the game in the same way you started: avoiding bands of robots until you find a macguffin, then killing or distracting the two (always two!) low-level robots guarding it, then scurrying back to the nearest checkpoint while again avoiding all contact with anything.

The letters scattered about try to hang a wider narrative on these bones, but they are so rare that multiple play-throughs are required to join any dots together ‚Äì and that is not a prospect I relish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089633093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1559014546}
review:
This game is AMAZING. The graphics aren't the best but still quite good. Sir, You Are Being Hunted gives a mysterious and adventurous feel. The game isn't very hard either, due to a choice of starter packs that were not originally available. However, there are other starter packs that make this more challenging. This is worth the full price and will leave you playing for hours on end.

Here's my PC Build in case you'd like to get an idea of what can run this on Ultra Settings:

CPU: AMD Athlon II X4 635 2.9GHz
GPU: Nvidia GTX 650 SC
RAM: Elpida 3x2GB 1333MHz
OS: Windows 7 Home Premium 64-Bit

I'm sure the requirements for Ultra are a lot less though.

Before I bought my new GPU I had an ATI Radeon HD 4200(768MB) and 4GB of system RAM. I had Sir, You Are Being Hunted at the time and it still ran at medium settings.
